PROCTEXT.PARA: FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY-THIRD PARLIAMENT
Pursuant to the Resolution of the Senate passed on 3 June 1983, the Senate met on Tuesday, 23 August 1983, at 3 p.m.
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 3 p.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) has been made a member of Cabinet and has been appointed Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis ) has been appointed Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Industrial Matters. I also inform the Senate that following the resignation of the Hon. M. J. Young from the Ministry on 14 July 1983 the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) was appointed Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the House, and the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) was appointed Special Minister of State.

—by leave-I understand that at this stage no further statement is proposed to be made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) with respect to the resignation of the Hon. M. J. Young. I do not wish to take the time of the Senate because this matter is being canvassed in the other place and I would expect any statement made in the other place ultimately to be repeated here. I understand that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has now indicated that he will make a statement in respect of that resignation. The original announcement in the lower House, the House of Representatives, was made in similar terms to that made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Opposition has sought a fuller statement. I understand that that statement will now be forthcoming after the suspension of Standing Orders. I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate, when that statement is available to him, to make it available also to the Senate.
—Yes.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON AUSTRALIA'S SECURITY AND INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —During the winter adjournment the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) directed to me a request, made by the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans), that permission be granted for certain pages of the Senate Hansard to be adduced in evidence before the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies.

INTERJECT.PARA: In my absence the Deputy President, Senator Hamer, in accordance with precedent , granted permission on 24 June for the pages in question to be adduced in evidence before the Royal Commission, subject to the strict observance of the principle, contained in the Bill of Rights and applying in Australia by virtue of section 49 of the Constitution, that debates and proceedings in the Parliament are privileged and may not be questioned in any tribunal. The Deputy President advised the Senate party leaders of his action.

A statement issued by the Royal Commission on 11 July on issues which it proposed to resolve included references to proceedings in the House of Representatives. Mr Speaker expressed concern to the Commission that the examination of certain of those issues might infringe article 9 of the Bill of Rights as they appeared to question actions of members of the House within the House. Mr Speaker then decided, as he is indicating to the House of Representatives today, that he should be represented by counsel when the question of parliamentary privilege was to be argued. Mr Speaker sought support for his assertion of the privileges of the Parliament from the Deputy President, who gave his agreement to the counsel, Mr T. E. F. Hughes, QC, indicating to the Commission that he, the Deputy President, on behalf of the Senate, supported the submission made on behalf of Mr Speaker. I am informed that counsel did refer to that support in his remarks before the Commission.

Mr Speaker continued to be represented before the Commission by a local counsel , Mr Walmsley, during the examination of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the former Leader of the House, Mr Young, the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes), and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). At that time I felt it advisable that I as President of the Senate should similarly be represented during the examination of the Attorney-General to ensure that nothing occurred during the proceedings which involved questioning any statements made in the Senate or the motives in making such statements. I was therefore represented by the same counsel during the Attorney-General's appearance before the Commission.

Because of the importance of freedom of speech to the Parliament and my own responsibilities to the Senate, I have taken this opportunity to inform the Senate of the actions taken to uphold that fundamental principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

Mr President, on behalf of the Opposition, I indicate our support for the steps which were taken by the Deputy President in your absence and subsequently by you on your return to Australia. The Opposition believes that the action which was taken by Mr Speaker and supported by the Presiding Officers in the Senate was appropriate action to protect the privileges of the Parliament. We want to assure you of our support for that action and any similar action that should be required in the future.

Now is not the time to debate the matters of principle which are raised in your statement but I think the statement does raise important questions of that nature. It brings out the differences between the function of this Parliament and the function of a royal commission. It makes very clear that each has a role to play and that that role is to be played properly in accordance with the legal duties which are upon each of those bodies or institutions.

As far as the Parliament is concerned, we take the view that the holding of a royal commission does not lift from the shoulders of the Parliament its responsibility for matters which go to the national interest. I make that point at this stage because there has been some debate and there have been some assertions about the freedom of members of the Opposition, and, indeed, the freedom of other elements of the community, to make comments on matters which we see as having an overriding national interest. It is important that the proper role of the Parliament, and indeed the proper role of the Opposition, is preserved and upheld at all times. It has been made clear by the Leader of the Opposition, the Hon. Andrew Peacock, that he will not be prevented from discussing matters of national interest. I believe that was a very proper course for him to take, one which certainly has the full support of the Opposition in this place. Again, Mr President, I commend you and your Deputy for the action you have taken to protect the privileges of the Parliament. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Government notes the statement made by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). As he pointed out in the course of his remarks, it is not appropriate to debate all the details of that statement at this time. We regard the statement made by the Leader of the Opposition as generally an impeccable statement of principle but, in saying that, there would be qualifications upon some of the detailed examples upon which he drew to identify particular principles which he sought to enshrine in his statement.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BUTTON; BAUME; CARRICK; CHIPP; GUILFOYLE; HARRADINE; MACKLIN; RAE; ROBERTSON; RYAN; SCOTT; SIBRAA
PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Discrimination against Women
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Button (from 121 citizens), Peter Baume (from 163 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 655 citizens), Chipp (from 22 citizens), Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 179 citizens), Harradine (from 576 citizens), Macklin (from 11 citizens), Peter Rae (from 34 citizens), Robertson (from 626 citizens), Ryan ( from 1,633 citizens), Scott (from 325 citizens) and Sibraa (from 57 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia,
Believing that men and women are equal but different,
Convinced that Australia can provide equal opportunity for all citizens without foreign treaties,
Concerned that ratifying the UN Discrimination Convention would give a Communist-dominated international committee the power to judge Australia's laws,
Humbly petition that your Honourable House will not ratify the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women
and we will always thus petition.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Maguire (from 357 citizens) and Messner (from 216 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth-

That currently discrimination in provision of work, in appointment to jobs and in promotion exists in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy, sex and/or sexual preference; and
That currently discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits is exercised against particular groups of individuals-in particular, against married women.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of individuals under federal awards, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to sex and/or marital status.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

We the undersigned are opposed to the Government's method of operation of its proposed 'MEDICARE SCHEME' because of the inconvenience of changing, the removal of freedom of choice, the loss of jobs in the Health Insurance industry and the huge cost of conversion; since the Health Funds are currently agents for 30 per cent of Commonwealth funding it seems most obvious that they should be agents for the whole scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
1. planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin
2. closing country telegraph offices
3. increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service
4. withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices
5. generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30 per cent of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your Petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides. And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the members of the Women's Services of the 1939-45 War not at present considered eligible for Defence Service Home Loans should qualify as '' Australian Soldiers'' under the Defence Service Homes Act. They volunteered for service with the Naval, Military and Air Forces, serving wherever they were sent in whatever capacity they were required and yet are refused Defence Service Home Loans.

They took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies which meant to fight His Majesty's enemies, and although not used in actual combat in war zones, they were available for that use and had a sufficiently grave need arisen would have been used, to serve with distinction as have women of other lands.

In accordance with the Acts and Regulations of the period, the women of the Military Forces had enlisted for service anywhere, some of the Naval women to sail in any waters, others with service on warships optional, while the women of the Air Force could have been sent to Papua New Guinea or other territories under the control or care of Australia.

Ex-servicemen of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force who volunteered in the 1939-45 War but were not sent to War Zones are granted home loans. Not to grant eligibility to all Ex- servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that you favourably consider amending the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment, of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Collard (from three citizens), Macklin (from 21 citizens), Martin ( from two citizens) and Walters (from four citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That all members of the Women's Services 1939-45 War qualify as 'Australian Soldier' under the Defence Service Homes Act for loans because on voluntarily joining the Australian Forces they took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies making themselves available for combat duty in War Zones, and according to Acts and Regulations of the period the Military women had enlisted for service anywhere, some Naval women to sail in any waters, with all servicewomen available for service in Papua New Guinea.

As those members of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force of 1939-45 War who were not sent to War Zones are granted loans, refusal to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939- 45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that you amend the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from seven citizens) and Harradine (from six citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Office of Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That citizens of Western Australia view with great alarm the removal of Director of the Office of Child Care and fear for the future of that office and the children's services programme which it administers.

We believe the Office of Child Care to be inappropriately placed within the Department of Social Security, where children's services are in competition with welfare services for the aged, disabled, and other such groups.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled , should take every step as necessary to obtain immediate withdrawal of the Office of Child Care from the Department of Social Security and the establishment of a Children's Commission.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Martin (from 142 citizens) and Ryan (from 99 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Division of Moore respectfully showeth:

That there is great need for the establishment of one new Community Youth Support Scheme project in the Subdivisions of Duncraig and Wanneroo, because of the high level of youth unemployment in these subdivisions, in order that the CYSS project can provide a range of activities which develop the skills, abilities and self reliance of young people resident in the Subdivisions of Duncraig and Wanneroo.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that proposals for the establishment of one new Community Youth Support Scheme project in the Subdivisions of Duncraig and Wanneroo be granted favourable and prompt attention by this Parliament and its Ministers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Fees: Overseas Students
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned students and staff of the University of Queensland respectfully showeth:
(1) that in 1979 the Liberal Government introduced overseas student fees,
(2) that those fees have been regularly increased since their introduction,
(3) that the financial burden has caused hardship for overseas students studying here, who have limited earning capacity.
We call on this Government to review the decision taken to introduce tertiary fees for overseas students.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Macklin (from 106 citizens) and Martin (from 43 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Division of Moore respectfully showeth:

That there is great need for the establishment of a new Community Youth Support Scheme project in the Subdivision of Girrawheen, because of the high level of youth unemployment in this subdivision, in order that the CYSS project can provide a range of activities which develop the skills, abilities and self reliance of unemployed young people resident in the Subdivision of Girrawheen.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that proposals for the establishment of a new Community Youth Support Scheme project in the Subdivision of Girrawheen be granted favourable and prompt attention by this Parliament and its Ministers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Klaipeda, Lithuania was the only church permitted (by the Soviet authorities) to be built in post-war Lithuania.
That the church was built by the Catholic parishioners from their own resources and with support from overseas Christians.
That upon completion of the church building in 1960, the church was not allowed to be consecrated and, in 1961 was resumed by the State for purposes other than religious.

That this resumption of the church and the subsequent persecution and arrests of the local clergy and other christians is contrary to the spirit and the letter of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenent on Human Rights.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled request the Australian Government to communicate most strongly to the Government of the USSR the sympathy of the petitioners for the plight of the Lithuanian Christians and ask that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the Catholics of Klaipeda for the practice of their religion without interference.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
1. The concerns which people around the World have for the increasing stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction;
2. The global concern that any nuclear exchange will inflict on humanity unimaginable death and suffering;
3. The vulnerability that Australians will face in any nuclear conflict between the major powers;
4. The public concern that Government should explore all avenues to ensure that the nuclear threat is eliminated.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament establish a Senate Select Committee on Nuclear Disarmament and Peace to investigate the creation of a Ministry of Peace and Nuclear Disarmament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Adelaide-Darwin Railway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That in 1911, as part of its new responsibility for the Northern Territory, the Commonwealth accepted a binding legislative commitment to construct a railway from Adelaide to Darwin-a promise which has never been fulfilled.
The lack of essential transport links has had, and continues to have, serious consequences for the economic and social development of the Northern Territory, and indeed all of Australia.

That the future expansion of new industries in the Territory and new trade opportunities for Australia, particularly with South-East Asia and the Western Pacific, depend on the development of the railway to link the port of Darwin with the rest of Australia. The railway is therefore an essential national project related directly to Australia's overall prospects for future economic growth.
We therefore protest the Commonwealth's continuing failure to construct the railway.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Prime Minister and Members of the Federal Government honour the promise made by the Commonwealth over 70 years ago , the promise made by the previous Commonwealth Government this year, and endorsed by the present Government in opposition to complete the construction of the railway by 1988, Australia's Bicentennial year. We call on the Prime Minister to give his personal assurance that the Commonwealth will honour its past and present promises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Enrichment Plant
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that your Petitioners do not want a Uranium Enrichment Plant constructed in South-East Queensland because :
(a) there is no known way of safely storing uranium waste products;
(b) there has not been an environmental impact study conducted into the effects of such a Uranium Enrichment Plant;
(c) Australia has adequate coal supplies to provide energy for industry;
(d) the risks to local inhabitants from the operation of such a plant have not been established;
(e) the products of such a plant will contribute to the prospect of nuclear war ;
(f) the local area would become a target in the event of such a nuclear war;
(g) the investment in such a Uranium Enrichment Plant would be better spent in research into clean, renewable energy sources such as solar energy.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
(a) legislate to give power to the Commonwealth Parliament to make decisions on the export of products from Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(b) reject all applications for the export of products from Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(c) legislate to give power to the Commonwealth Parliament to make decisions on foreign investment in Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(d) reject all applications for foreign investment in Uranium Enrichment Plants ;
(e) do all in the Senate's power to prevent the construction of a Uranium Enrichment Plant in South-East Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that although many occurences of sexual harrassment in the workforce have been reported to various State government authorities, such as the Victorian Commission for Equal Opportunity, the real incidence of sexual intimidation in employment will not be known, or countered, until a national policy towards sexual harrassment is determined and implemented.
We therefore submit that:

1. The National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation be commissioned to conduct a nation-wide study of discrimination based on sex, both in the private sector and the Public Service, with a view to advising the Government on the development of national policy.
2. The major priority of such a study should be to determine a legally- enforceable definition of sexual harrassment.

3. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations should bring forward in Parliament legislation, arising from such a study, to outlaw discrimination and intimidation in employment based on sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations: The Income Tax Regulations (Amendment), contained in Statutory Rules 1983 No. 111, and made under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.
(2) That the Committee report to the Senate on or before 4 October 1983.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate.
INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983 [No. 3]
Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 in relation to gifts of certain property to charitable funds .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should implement the policy on which it was elected in relation to uranium, namely:
(a) a moratorium on uranium mining and treatment will be declared;
(b) any commitment of a previous Government to the mining, processing or export of Australia's uranium will be repudiated;
(c) as a ''minimum position'', Australia's involvement in the uranium industry will be phased out; and
(d) in line with paragraph (c), no new mines will be commenced or come on stream during the period of a Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, Stage 2 of Kakadu should be declared a national park, under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should allocate the equivalent of 0.1 per cent of the annual defence budget for work on arms control and disarmament. These funds should be used to establish a Peace Development Studies Institute in Australia which would examine the ways in which disarmament and arms control can contribute to national security interests, support scholarly research, and conduct public education programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, four sitting days from today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Health Insurance Commission Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1983 No. 88, and made under the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) (a) That a Standing Committee of the Senate, to be known as the Standing Committee on Treaties, be appointed to consider all treaties laid before the Senate, and any other treaties to which the Committee may have access, and to report in respect of each such treaty-
(i) whether Australia should undertake to be bound by that treaty if that treaty is not already binding upon Australia; and
(ii) the effect which Australia's being bound by that treaty has or would have upon the legislative powers and responsibilities of the Australian States.
(b) That, for the purposes of this Resolution-

''treaty'' means any agreement or proposed agreement in writing between two or more countries which imposes or would impose rights and obligations upon those countries and which is or is intended to be binding upon those countries; and

''undertake to be bound'' in relation to a treaty refers to any action which would have the effect of making that treaty binding upon Australia, including the signing of documents, the ratification of that treaty or adherence or accession to that treaty.

(2) (a) That the Committee consist of eight Senators, four nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, two nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, and one independent Senator.
(b) That, of the Senators appointed to the Committee pursuant to sub-paragraph (2) (a), there shall be at least one Senator for each State.

(c) That, if nominations made under sub-paragraph (2) (a) are such that appointments to the Committee in accordance with those nominations would not comply with sub-paragraph (2) (b), the President shall notify the Senate accordingly and ask for fresh nominations, and if those fresh nominations are such that appointments to the Committee in accordance with them would not comply with sub-paragraph (2) (b), the President shall notify the Senate accordingly and the Senate shall determine the appointments to the Committee in accordance with this paragraph so far as is practicable.
(3) That the Committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the quorum of the Committee be four.

(5) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be two Senators.
(6) That the Committee elect a member nominated by the Leader of the Government as Chairman.

(7) That the Chairman may from time to time appoint a member of the Committee to be Deputy-Chairman and the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(8) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy- Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(9) That a Senator, though not a member of the Committee, may participate in its public sessions and question witnesses, unless the Committee orders otherwise, but shall not vote.

(10) That the Committee or any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, and to meet and transact business in public or private session and notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(11) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and that a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings of the Committee as take place in public.

(12) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint counsel to advise the Committee, and other persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee, with the approval of the President.
(13) That the Committee have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such recommendations as it may deem fit, and make regular reports on its deliberations.
(14) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Is it a fact that in the national wage case the Government has argued against the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission giving due consideration to an industry' s capacity to pay? In view of the difficulties currently experienced in many industries, can the Leader of the Government comment on the employment consequences of this position if it is adopted by the Commission in its rulings?

—I am unable to answer the detailed part of the question relating to what the Government has argued in the national wage case in relation to capacity to pay. I will obtain an answer to that from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations as soon as possible and provide it to the honourable senator. If such an argument was advanced, I assume that it would have been advanced in the context of a number of submissions which the Government put forward in relation to wages policy and the implementation of that policy and the Government's desire to establish a centralised wage fixation system. I remind the honourable senator that for some time there have been disagreements in the community about the consequences of any national wage decision which may be given this year. It is a matter of judgment to determine what the effects of such a decision are likely to be overall, having regard to a number of factors. In the light of those circumstances, the Government has made a judgment about its wages policy and the general desirability of the wages policy which it has pursued before the Commission in the light of consideration of employment and general economic recovery.

—Mr President, my question is addressed to you. It relates to the parliamentary scarves which are meant to complement the ties available to male members. Why did the House Committee find it necessary to have the scarves made in Japan, especially as the material and workmanship in them are far inferior to those of the ties, which are Australian made? Do you agree, Mr President, that the Parliament has a prime duty to use and promote Australian made goods, not only as an example to the rest of the community but also to improve employment in Australia?

—I do not know offhand whether the scarves referred to by the honourable senator were or are made in Japan. I shall have inquiries made into that aspect. I agree with the honourable senator that Parliament has a responsibility to use as much as possible Australian made and manufactured products. I will refer the honourable senator's question to the Joint House Department and obtain further information for him.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CRIMES ACT: OPINION ON POSSIBLE OFFENCE

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Attorney- General of the request made to him by the Prime Minister on Thursday, 14 July, for his opinion as to whether the then Special Minister of State, Mr Young, may have committed any offence under the Crimes Act concerning statements he made to a Mr Walsh on the evening of 21 April. I also refer him to his reply to the Prime Minister, which, I take it, was dated 18 July, in which he stated that at that stage he was not in a position to give a concluded opinion as to Mr Young's position under the Crimes Act, but for all practical purposes that would not occur until relevant witnesses had given their testimony to the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. In view of the fact that a number of relevant witnesses have now given evidence to the Royal Commission, has the Attorney-General given further consideration to the request of the Prime Minister to which I referred? When does the Attorney-General expect to be in a position to give an opinion to the Prime Minister on that matter? Will he assure the House that the opinion he gives will be tabled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that in answer originally to the Prime Minister I said that it was impossible to give any kind of answer on the substantive questions involved until the relevant witnesses had given their testimony. There were, in fact, three relevant witnesses, Messrs Young, Walsh and Matheson, all of whom have now given their testimony. The difficulty is that some of that evidence, bearing upon the issues involved here, was given in camera and it was necessary to make special application to get access to it. That has been done this week. Only in the last 48 hours have I been in possession of all relevant transcripts.

ANSWER.PARA: There are still some difficulties which confront any attempt to write an opinion on the state of the evidence simply because there is a degree of conflict in it. That creates difficulties which the honourable senator will, I hope, appreciate. Nonetheless, it is my hope that I can produce an opinion of the kind requested by the Prime Minister within a matter of days. I am certainly considering the matter in conjunction with the Solicitor-General at the moment with that end in view. I further indicate that it is certainly my intention to table that opinion in this chamber when it is finally prepared.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I refer her to an article in the Australian of 16 August in relation to pyramid selling of health foods in New South Wales and the actions the New South Wales Attorney-General, Mr Landa, has taken to ban some goods in that State. My concern is that on John Bell's Consumer Access program in Perth last week a nutritionist from the Western Australian Health Department advised that these goods are very dangerous high protein diet products which can lead to mineral imbalance and claimed that similar dietary products had resulted in several deaths in America. I remind the Minister that pyramid selling relies on the continuing recruitment of people to participate, which dramatically increases the price of goods to consumers, and that at least one of these products was found to contravene the Pure Foods Act of New South Wales, which to me at least indicates that bogus claims on labels and in advertising were being made as to its efficacy. Will the Minister advise what action the Federal Government can take under the Trade Practices Act to ensure that this insidious method of exploitation is outlawed in this country?

—I can understand the concern expressed in the honourable senator's question. Information provided to me by the Minister responsible for consumer affairs federally, Mr Barry Cohen, is to the effect that the Trade Practices Commission has received legal advice that the schemes prohibited in New South Wales do not contravene the Trade Practices Act. However, consideration of an amendment to remedy this defect in the Trade Practices Act is at an advanced stage and it is anticipated that such an amendment will be introduced in this sitting of the Parliament.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer a question concerning the withholding tax legislation which is to come into operation on 1 September. Will the Government confirm that in response to representations by the Australian Democrats it has made arrangements whereby the Australian Taxation Office will streamline administrative procedures to overcome disadvantages caused to small businesses by the introduction of the tax? Will the Minister confirm that it has been agreed that, if the arrangements made by the Taxation Office to deploy additional staff do not handle the number of applications involved before 1 September, interim rate variation certificates for a period of up to two months, showing in the case of applications for exemption a zero deduction rate, will be issued? Will the Minister also confirm that similar interim rate variation certificates for a period of up to two months will also be available to tax agents acting on behalf of clients where they have not been able to assemble the necessary information for lodgment by 1 September? Finally, if the proposed move by the Liberal Party to refer the withholding tax question to a Senate committee is successful-which it will be because we will support it-will the Government move quickly to remedy any injustices to small businesses which would be revealed in the committee's hearings by means of regulations additional to those now before the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp has asked a number of questions. I understand that he and some other Australian Democrat senators met the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and Mr Hurford last night and made representations on this matter. I have discussed the matter with the Treasurer today. As a result of the discussions last night, among other things, the Commissioner of Taxation has today issued a Press release which I will, at the appropriate time, seek leave to incorporate in Hansard. That release covers two of the three questions Senator Chipp asked. Firstly, he asked whether, because of delays by the Taxation Office in the processing of applications, an interim zero rate of variation certificate would be granted for a period of up to two months. The answer is yes. Likewise, to his second question as to whether accountants who have been unable to assemble the necessary documentation in time will, on application, be granted on behalf of their clients a zero rate of variation certificate, the answer is yes.

ANSWER.PARA: The third question concerned the proposed reference of this matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I can, on behalf of the Government, give an assurance that, if it can be demonstrated that anomalies exist in the administration of this law introduced, I emphasise, or forecast by the previous Government more than 12 months ago, the Government will , of course, give consideration to amending it. That is completely consistent with statements which have been made by me on this matter in Western Australia, by the Treasurer and by various other people on behalf of the Government. But, of course, the details of the procedures under which the Government is committed to the elimination of tax evasion, unlike apparently the members of the present Opposition, are always subject to review if it can be demonstrated that they are causing anomalies or that more efficient administrative procedures can be put in place.

I would like to make a couple more comments. The Australian Taxation Office, I am advised, by last night had received 16,000 applications for certificates of exemption or variation. The total number anticipated by the Taxation Office is in the vicinity of 30,000. By mid-afternoon on Friday just over 11,000 applications had been received. They are coming in now at a very fast rate and are being processed by the Taxation Office at a rate of 2,000 to 3,000 a day. Over 11,000 applications were processed by last Friday evening. It is almost certain that applications received by 28 August will be processed in time for the introduction of the tax on 1 September. But if, because of some unforeseen circumstance or a last minute deluge of applications, processing spills over into the next month, the procedures which I have outlined in reply to Senator Chipp's question will apply. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a 2 1/2-page statement on this subject issued today by the Commissioner of Taxation.

The Commissioner of Taxation, Mr W. J. O'Reilly, today gave the following details of applications for exemption from, or variation of, the rate at which tax is to be deducted from payments to which the prescribed payment system is to apply as from 1 September. He also explained some administrative procedures which, if needs be, will be put into operation to ease the transition into this system of collecting tax to be credited against tax ultimately assessed for an income year.

As at the close of business on Monday, 5,876 applications for exemption, and 10 ,230 applications for rate variation had been lodged, and 4,030 applications for exemption and 7,370 applications for rate variation had been approved.

263 or 4.4 per cent of applications for exemption, and 233 or 2.2 per cent of applications for rate variation had been refused. Further information had been requested in respect of 536 applications for exemption and 523 applications for rate variation.

The Commissioner said that the great majority of applications were being processed on the same day as they are received, and he added that if the rate at which applications are being lodged increases, further staff will, of course, be allotted to processing them, and if necessary, overtime will be worked, to ensure that the 'turn around' time does not increase.

The Commissioner also outlined administrative procedures being held in reserve against the contingencies that a flood of applications is received in the last day or two of August, or that tax agents indicate that they will not be able to complete and lodge applications before the 1 September commencement date.

As to the first of these contingencies, in the unlikely event that, despite the deployment of additional staff and the working of overtime, it appears that the ATO will not be able to process applications that have been lodged in time for certificates to be issued before 1 September, interim rate variation certificates for a period of up to two months, showing, in the case of applications for exemption, a zero deduction rate, will be issued, to be replaced by the actual certificates when processing of the applications has been completed.

In the second of these contingencies, tax agents who have been asked by their clients to complete and lodge applications for exemption or rate variation but who find that despite their best efforts, they will not be able to assemble the necessary information and lodge the applications in time for processing before 1 September, will be able to apply for the issue of interim rate variation certificates for a period of up to two months, to be replaced by actual certificates when applications are lodged and processed. The agents wishing to make application for interim certificates should supply with their application a list showing the name, address and file number of the taxpayer, with an indication as to the dates by which it is proposed the basic applications will be lodged. Brief reasons why the basic applications cannot be lodged in time should be given.

While these procedures would operate as necessary, the Commissioner urged taxpayers who wished to obtain certificates to lodge their applications as quickly as possible so that they could be certain about their situation under the new system.

The Commissioner also referred to some basic elements of the system. He explained that exemption certificates would be issued to applicants who can demonstrate that they are unlikely to have any tax to pay in a particular year ( for example because of losses incurred in a previous year). In addition, exemption certificates would be issued to applicants who have been in business at established premises for a significant period, have maintained satisfactory accounting and taxation records, have conducted all business financial transactions through a business bank account, and have satisfactorily complied with his obligations under Acts administered by the Commissioner. As part of the last requirement, applications for exemption certificates are to be supported by a declaration by a tax agent or other prescribed person as to the accuracy of the applicant's last income tax return and, where the applicant's records are not audited, by a source and application of funds statement reconciled with the applicant's last return.

Rate variation certificates may be issued on application by taxpayers who consider the basic 10 per cent rate will be too high for them because, for example, they incur significant expenses for material or labour. Applications for rate variation are in a much simpler form, and require the applicant to estimate his gross prescribed payments income for 1982-83, the tax that will be payable on that income and the rate, calculated from these amounts, at which tax would need to have been deducted from prescribed payments to meet the amount of tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Attorney-General and refers to his statements regarding a question of privilege in the South Australian Parliament and his warning to the media against publication of sections of a speech by Mr Peter Duncan in that Parliament. Can the Attorney-General clarify the position of the electronic and print media in relation to qualified privilege in reporting proceedings of parliaments in this country? Does an editor or working journalist risk prosecution by accurately reporting those proceedings or are such people expected to censor their reports from Parliament? If there is a risk of prosecution, is the Australian Broadcasting Corporation also liable when it carries actionable material during a live broadcast? If any existing legislation in Australia is likely to compel this type of Press censorship, will the Attorney-General ensure that overriding legislation will be introduced immediately to allow complete and uncensored reporting of parliamentary proceedings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator asks me what in effect is a series of questions seeking my legal opinion on matters of some complexity and difficulty. I think perhaps the most appropriate response under those circumstances is to seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the opinion which I have today completed jointly with the Solicitor-General and forwarded to the Royal Commissioner under cover of another letter, which I will also seek leave to incorporate in Hansard, explaining the position in my view as it affects both Mr Duncan and the media which reported his remarks. The only matter not specifically addressed in that legal opinion but which was raised by Senator Jones was, I believe, the particular question of the position of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation when it carries otherwise actionable material in a live broadcast from this chamber. In relation to that, I inform the honourable senator that the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act 1946-I think it is section 15 thereof-makes it absolutely clear that no action or proceedings of either a civil or criminal nature can be taken in respect of the ABC as publishers or distributors of what we may say in the chamber in that respect. But the issue is a complex one. Rather than endeavour to summarise that degree of complexity, I think the best thing is for me simply to incorporate in Hansard the full text of the opinion and the covering letter. I seek leave accordingly.

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to your letter of 18 August in which you bring to my attention newspaper reports of a speech by Mr Peter Duncan in the South Australian Parliament and the statement of His Honour Mr Justice Hope indicating his intention to refer matters raised by that speech to me.
The Solicitor-General, Sir Maurice Byers QC, and I have considered the points raised in His Honour's statement and have prepared in response the Joint Opinion appended to this letter.
Our conclusions may be briefly stated as follows:

(1) While Commonwealth law may in some circumstances be capable of overriding claims of parliamentary privilege in both Commonwealth and State Parliaments, neither s.6D or s.60 of the Royal Commissions Act, nor s.92 of the ASIO Act have that effect.
(2) Mr Duncan could not, accordingly, be prosecuted under these provisions even if they were otherwise applicable to him.

(3) Media reports, however, even if constituting no more than fair reports of what is said in Parliament, may as a matter of strict law be capable of prosecution under those sections to the extent that they involve:
wilful contravention of a Commissioner's suppression order;
a wilful prejudgment or prejudicial treatment of issues being dealt with by the commission; or
identification of an officer (other than the Director-General), employee or agent of ASIO.

Notwithstanding the conclusion in (3), and the possibility that the law in question may have been breached, I do not propose to take any action in relation to those accounts of Mr Duncan's speech which have appeared in the media to date . A number of accounts were published or broadcast before my statement of 18 August counselling caution by the media, when it is reasonable to suppose that the media in question were acting on the assumption that fair reports of parliamentary proceedings were fully protected. Subsequent to that caution, reasonable restraint has been exercised in all cases of which I am aware.

As we state in our Joint Opinion, there are obviously acutely sensitive questions of public policy involved in these matters. Other than in the most exceptional circumstances, we believe it to be more appropriate that reliance be placed on parliamentarians and the media exercising reasonable self-restraint than that the sanctions of the criminal law be applied to them.

We are sure that His Honour's statement of 4 August 1983, drawing attention as it does to the need of the Commission to be able to proceed with its deliberations in a calm, dignified and unprejudiced atmosphere, will have been closely heeded.

I would be grateful if you would convey the above to the Commissioner. As discussed with you, I propose-because of the intense public interest in this matter-to immediately publicly release the text of this letter and the accompanying Joint Opinion.
Re Royal Commission on Australian Security and Intelligence Agencies

On 18 August the Royal Commissioner on Australia's security and intelligence agencies, the Honourable Mr Justice Hope, referred to the Attorney-General questions relating to the interaction of federal legislation with the parliamentary privilege of a Member of a Parliament of a State. The Attorney- General has thought it appropriate that the matter be considered by both himself and the Solicitor-General.

2. The Commissioner's action followed a speech made in the Parliament of South Australia by the Honourable Peter Duncan on 17 August 1983. That speech contained a number of allegations and comments in relation to issues that are being examined by the Royal Commission, to evidence that has been given to the Royal Commission, and to the manner in which the Royal Commissioner has conducted the inquiry to date.

3. The Royal Commissioner stated on 18 August that some of the detail of the speech suggests strongly that the ultimate source for that detail is evidence given in camera to the Commission and subject to orders by the Commission prohibiting its publication. It seems reasonably clear that Mr Duncan's speech involves a prejudgment of matters relevant to a determination of paragraph (c) of the Letters Patent of 17 May 1983 appointing Mr Justice Hope a Commissioner to inquire into and report upon the matters therein specified. The Commissioner stated that, if the speech is not protected by the Parliamentary privilege, offences may have been committed against several federal statutory provisions.

4. We have considered first whether the privilege of free speech members of State parliaments enjoy under State Constitutions would provide complete immunity from the application of federal law in all circumstances. We believe not.

5. Free speech for things said in proceedings in Parliament is provided for in s.38 of the Constitution Act of South Australia. Section 106 of the Commonwealth Constitution specifically deals with the saving of each State Constitution, and provides for its continuance until altered in accordance with the Constitution of the State. However, it is relevant to note that s.106 is expressed to be subject to the Commonwealth Constitution, and it has not been treated as invalidating a law which otherwise falls within Commonwealth legislative power: Attorney-General (Qld) v. Attorney-General (Cwlth) (1915) 20 CLR 148, at 172; Engineers Case (1920) 28 CLR 129, at 154; Melbourne Corporation Case (1947) 74 CLR 31, at 83. In Stuart-Robertson v. Lloyd (1932) 47 CLR 482, federal bankruptcy law was held applicable to State parliamentary allowances payable under the New South Wales Constitution to members of the State Parliament.

6. On the other hand, we note that Commonwealth powers have been considered to be subject to an implied general limitation, affecting all Commonwealth legislative powers, that the Commonwealth cannot legislate to impair the capacity of the States to function: Victoria v. Commonwealth (1971) 122 CLR 353. We note that most recent cases dealing with the applicability of Commonwealth laws to the States have been concerned with their effect upon State executive power. They are not cases that explore the extent to which a Commonwealth law otherwise valid may affect the parliamentary functioning of a State. In an analogous situation in the United States, it was held by the Supreme Court that freedom of speech of individual state legislators must yield where important federal interests are at stake, as in the case of federal criminal statutes: United States v. Gillock (1980) 445 US 360. Whether that decision would be followed completely in Australia is not certain, but at the least it indicates that it is not intrinsically incompatable with federalism for federal laws to inhibit free speech by State legislators in appropriate circumstances.

7. Certainly if federal law is to have such an application the power supporting it would need to be commensurate with its effect. One example of how federal law might have an overriding effect could occur in the context of matters prejudicial to the defence and safety of the country in times of war; in our view a law which forbade a person, whether in a parliament or not, to make public the position of a convoy at sea and thereby to expose those manning it to the risk of death by enemy action, would be a valid law.

8. In our view, the crucial question in the present case is not the constitutional one but rather that of statutory interpretation: whether the relevant federal provisions, on their proper interpretation, extend to what is said in proceedings in the parliament of a State by a member. Whatever may be the constitutional position, it is clear that parliamentary privilege is considered to be so valuable and essential to the workings of responsible government that express words in a statute are necessary before it may be taken away: see Duke of Newcastle v. Morris (1870) LR4HL 661, at 671, 677 and 680. In the case of the Parliament of the Commonwealth, s.49 of the Constitution requires an express declaration.
9. In the light of these considerations, we turn to the relevant federal provisions. Sub-sections (3) and (4) of s.6D of the Royal Commissions Act, as amended, are as follows:
(b) the contents of any document, or a description of any thing, produced before, or delivered to, the Commission; or
(c) any information that might enable a person who has given evidence before the Commission to be identified,
shall not be published, or shall not be published except in such manner, and to such persons, as the Commission specifies.

(4) A person who makes any publication in contravention of any direction given under sub-section (3) is guilty of an offence punishable, upon summary conviction, by a fine not exceeding $2,000 or imprisonment for a period not exceeding 12 months.''

''60. (1) Any person who wilfully insults or disturbs a Royal Commission, or interrupts the proceedings of a Royal Commission, or uses any insulting language towards a Royal Commission, or by writing or speech uses words false and defamatory of a Royal Commission, or is in any manner guilty of any wilful contempt of a Royal Commission, shall be guilty of an offence.
Penalty: Two hundred dollars, or imprisonment for three months.

(2) If the President or Chairman of a Royal Commission or the sole Commissioner is a Justice of the High Court, or a Judge of any other Federal Court, of the Supreme Court of a Territory or of the Supreme Court or County Court or District Court of a State, he shall, in relation to any offence against sub-section (1) of this section committed in the face of the Commission, have all the powers of a Justice of the High Court sitting in open Court in relation to a contempt committed in face of the Court, except that any punishment inflicted shall not exceed the punishment provided by sub-section (1) of this section.''

10. The Commissioner has from time to time made orders, whenever evidence of a witness was taken in camera, prohibiting the publication of that evidence. Evidence given in public is not the subject of any order under ss.6D(3). Where a witness gives evidence as to part in camera and as to part in public, the transcript of his evidence contains passages which have been blocked out to give effect to the various orders which have been made. It is also the case that some orders originally prohibiting publication of all or substantial portions of evidence have later been varied by the Commissioner so as to diminish the scope of the prohibition.

11. The proceedings before the Commissioner are not in the nature of court proceedings. No reason thus exists to confine a direction given pursuant to ss. 6D(3)(a) so that it applies only to parties (for there are none) or to persons before the Commission. In other words, the subsection may bear its literal meaning, with the result that publication of evidence by 'outsiders' in contravention of the terms of a direction subjects the publisher to the penalties imposed by ss.(4) of s.6D. Of course, knowledge that publication is forbidden is necessary, for the sanctions are criminal ones: Cameron v. Holt ( 1980) 142 CLR 342.

12. Section 60 (1) applies to a Commission the rules that have been worked out as to contempt of court. Sub-section (1) in its first arm-that is, so much of it as includes 'insulting language towards a Royal Commission'-applies the rules relating to contempt in the face of the court, as ss. (2) would suggest. We think the remainder of ss. (1) extends to attract the rules relating to other contempts. In particular, the words 'in any manner guilty of any wilful contempt ' make it a contempt for persons publicly to prejudice issues being dealt with by the Commission where that is done deliberately: see, for example, Attorney- General v. Times Newspapers Ltd (1974) AC 273.

13. We do not think that either sections 6D or 6O of the Act can be construed as subjecting the members of the Parliament of the Commonwealth or the members of the parliaments of the States in relation to what is said in proceedings in parliament, to the penalties to which those sections refer. They cannot be construed as declarations under s. 49 of the Constitution. They contain no clear and express language cutting down parliamentary privilege. They must therefore be construed as not intending to affect it.

14. We have also considered s. 92 of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979, but if anything the conclusion that parliamentary privilege is not affected is even clearer in the case of that provision. It is apparent from ss. (2) of s. 92 that ss. (1) does not apply to statements made in the Commonwealth Parliament. When the rule requiring express removal of the privilege is borne in mind, we take it to be clear that s. 92 (1) does not apply to statements made by a member of a State parliament in proceedings in parliament. Sub-section (2) suggests, however, that those who broadcast or report State parliamentary statements may offend ss. (1).

15. There are, of course, substantial reasons for treating the prohibition in the federal provisions we have examined as also not extending to fair and accurate reports of proceedings before any parliament. The common law treats reports of those proceedings as necessary to be protected in the national interest. In defamation proceedings, the interest of the public in being informed of what occurs in parliament has been said to require that fair and accurate reports of parliamentary debates should be privileged: see Wason v. Walter (1968) LR4QB 73 at 89.

16. Nevertheless, the federal provisions in question clearly apply to media reports, which are not-despite a common impression to the contrary-themselves protected by parliamentary privilege. While, for example, s. 249 of the Criminal Law Consolidation Act (S.A.) fully protects publication in that State of parliamentary proceedings, that provision cannot stand if inconsistent with s. 6D and s. 60 of the Royal Commissions Act and s. 92 of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act.

17. There are powerful arguments of public interest which may be urged against this position. We have indicated them above. It may be that were the matter to be tried, the court might be minded to afford some protection to the media for its report of parliamentary proceedings by some extension of the principles in the Duke of Newcastle case. However, we think that, as the law now stands, the provisions of the Royal Commissions Act require the conclusion that those who publish statements made by a member of the parliament of a State which amount to a contempt of the Commission are liable under s. 60 (1) of the Royal Commissions Act if the contempt is a wilful one; and, where an order prohibiting publication has been made under ss. 6D (3) (a) and the publisher knows he is publishing contrary to an order, for a breach of s. 6D (4). We have already indicated our view as to s. 92 of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act-ss. (2 ) indicates that those who broadcast or report State parliamentary statements may offend against ss. (1).

18. It is our view, therefore, that the statements made in the Parliament by the Honourable Peter Duncan are not subject to s. 6D or s. 60 of the Royal Commissions Act, nor are they subject to s. 92 (1) of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act. We also think however that as a matter of strict law publication of those statements may in certain circumstances expose the publishers to the penalties provided by the three sections.
GARETH EVANS M. H. BYERS Attorney-General Solicitor-General

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VICTORIAN GOVERNMENT AND GENERAL MOTORS-HOLDEN'S LTD: OFFSET PROGRAM

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the statement by the Federal Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation, Mr Townsend, in relation to the Victorian Government's motor vehicle offset arrangement with General Motors-Holden's Ltd, and to the claim that this will save 40 jobs and create 150 new jobs? I ask whether it is a fact that Mr Townsend said:

QUESTION.PARA: The action by the Victorian Labor Cabinet in successfully working the offset program is one to be followed up by Senator Button in Canberra. The offset deal can work nationally.
Does the Minister agree with any such proposal and, if so, what steps has he taken or will he take to implement such a proposal?

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of comments made by Mr Townsend have been drawn to my attention, although not that one specifically. Senator Rae smiles. I think he would understand, with his knowledge of the vehicle industry, such as it is, that numerous people within that industry are anxious to draw the attention of the Government to particular points of view which they hold. Mr Townsend has been vociferous and outspoken in the interests of the members of his union whom he represents. In regard to the view expressed by Mr Townsend, to which the honourable senator has referred me, I can only say that I will see that I get some detailed explanation of that view and make sure that it is examined. Certainly I will not say in the context of Question Time in the Senate whether or not I agree with that view, because a wide variety of ramifications may have to be considered.
—When you have considered it, will you let us have a reply?
—Senator Rae asks whether, having considered the view in detail, we will let him or the Senate have the benefit of our decision in relation to any matter arising from that view. Of course we will.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to a recent statement made by the former Treasurer, Mr Howard, who responded to the Prime Minister's announcement that the Government would fund the construction of the Burdekin Dam by commenting:

QUESTION.PARA: I wouldn't have regarded the Burdekin as any more sacrosanct than other areas. I'd have put it into the hotch potch with some other things.
Does the Minister regard this as typical of the Opposition's attitude to north Queensland and could he outline the Government's plans for the all-important Burdekin scheme?

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. My point of order is that that is not a question which relates in any way to the Government's administration. It does no more than seek a comment on the Opposition.
—I do not uphold the point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin, with the wisdom of experience in the Senate, where I have sat for seven years listening to Ministers answering questions, by saying that I appreciate the great work which Senator Reynolds has done for the people of north Queensland. Every honourable senator would be conscious of the diligence she has displayed in pursuing the interests of north Queenslanders. Insofar as the question relates to the Burdekin Dam, let me say that the Government has honoured the commitment which it made during the election campaign in respect of the Burdekin Dam. That is in sharp contrast to the conduct of the previous Government, which made this promise in numerous pre- election campaigns and did nothing to carry it out. The Commonwealth has appropriated substantial funds for stage one of the Burdekin project. Some $13m has been appropriated for 1983-84. This will enable construction to commence, including the commencement of a construction village and works area, as well as other associated facilities. The credit and the money appropriated for that purpose have been appropriated by the Commonwealth Government in response not only to the general undertaking which we gave prior to the election but also to representations from local members of Parliament, such as Senator Reynolds. They are Commonwealth funds; they are not funds appropriated by the Government of Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to the particular point raised by Senator Reynolds in her question relating to Mr Howard's alternative Budget, let me just say this: I am not surprised that Mr Howard is making comments about the Budget to be brought down tonight because in a very real sense he has a proprietary interest in it; it is his Budget. The size of the deficit, which will be announced tonight, was given to us by Mr Howard. The parameters of the Budget are confined by the incompetence of the former Treasurer under the Fraser Government. When the Budget is brought down tonight that will be made abundantly clear.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I address a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I noted the settlement of the H. J. Heinz Co. Australia Ltd 11-week dispute. My understanding is that the settlement included a pay increase of some $16 a week and a $600 strike-pay payment to the employees . I ask the Minister: In view of the National Economic Summit Conference communique and the understanding that we had with regard to a centralised wage fixing system and the suppression of sectional claims, will the Government be making any submission to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in its hearing of the national wage case, as comments have been made that regardless of the Arbitration Commission's ratification or not of this new settlement this money will be paid? It seems to me that this cuts across the understandings that we had of the benefit of a centralised wage fixing system and the Government's approach to it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In some ways I and the Government agree with the view put by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in terms of the implications of her question. In the recent national wage case the Government put to the Arbitration Commission that it should require a commitment from every trade union to abide by the 'no extra claims' provision before the union would be eligible for any increase awarded by the national wage bench. The Government, along with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Confederation of Australian Industry, believes that a suppression of sectoral wage claims is essential for the successful operation of a centralised wage fixing system.
