Therefore, the Government does not condone the activities of the union in relation to the Heinz employees or the settlement which was reached between the company and the union.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the Government's approach it will be necessary, of course, for the Commission to satisfy itself as to the consistency or otherwise of this settlement and whether it is in accordance with the principles which the Commission has been asked to bring down in the course of the national wage case decision. The question of whether the members of the union who are employed by the Heinz company are eligible to receive the national wage case benefits will be dealt with by the Full Bench of the Arbitration Commission. The Government has asked the Bench to deal with that matter in a particular way.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I seek a clarification of the last comment made by the Minister. Does the Government intend to make a submission to the Arbitration Commission against the ratification of the settlement which was made recently?

—The Government has made a submission in relation to all sectoral wage claims outside the centralised wage fixation system. If the Government's view prevails with the Arbitration Commission, as we hope and believe it will, any sectoral claims which appear to be outside the national wage case decision will be referred to individual deputy presidents or commissioners of the Arbitration Commission to be dealt with in the light of the national wage case decision. In that circumstance the Government would certainly intervene in those proceedings, which would be the appropriate proceedings to deal with a particular sectoral matter which went beyond the national decision.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PAYMENT OF UNEMPLOYMENT BENEFIT TO UNION WORKERS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to a dispute in Murray Bridge in South Australia between the staff of Charles David Pty Ltd and members of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. Is the dispute one over manning levels? Is it a fact that the staff members of the company are prepared to work under the existing award conditions for the industry but that the company will not let them do so unless they accept a new work situation? Does not this action of the company in effect amount to a lock-out? In the light of this will the Minister consider approving the payment of unemployment benefit to the families of the workers involved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Bolkus has said, there is a dispute in the abattoir run by Charles David Pty Ltd at Murray Bridge. It has been going on for some weeks. As is often the case in disputes of this type in the meat industry it is difficult to determine whether this dispute is the result of industrial action by the union or, as Senator Bolkus would imply, there is a lock-out in the abattoir.

ANSWER.PARA: My Department has spent some time trying to determine the facts of the situation and, I understand, it has only today received from the company concerned-having received information from the union at the end of last week-a suggestion that it will employ people who are willing to work under what it considers reasonable award conditions. In those circumstances the Department of Social Security has, as Senator Bolkus knows, decided that these people are out of work as a result of industrial action and will not receive unemployment benefit.

However, as the information that my Department has received does not coincide with information from the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union and other sources, I will, after Question Time-I received this information only on my way into Parliament-ask my Department to look further at the situation to see whether it is a lock-out and, in those circumstances, whether the unemployment benefit will be paid. I expect the Department's problems in this area to be settled in the next couple of days.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, concerns the way in which non-government schools will be funded following the abandonment of the percentage link which relates grants to costs in government schools. Will the Minister guarantee that under the new formula which is proposed to replace the percentage link, schools will not be worse off?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can certainly guarantee that under the new formula that will replace the percentage link those schools which need improved standards will not be worse off. Clearly one of the objectives of changing the arrangement of the funding of non-government schools is to achieve a fairer distribution of funds. That implies that some schools which have been receiving a very high level of Commonwealth subsidy but which do not need that level of subsidy will lose some of it. This has already been the case with some of the decisions I have announced. It will continue to be the case under the new formula.

ANSWER.PARA: The new formula will be worked out by the Commonwealth Schools Commission over the next few months in consultation with representatives of all school organisations which are relevant, with State government departments, Catholic education commissions and so on. Some mysterious formula will not be pulled out of a hat and applied to schools. The consultation processes have already begun. As well as that, of course, consultations are being carried out at State level through State planning and finance committees and the results of those consultations will be fed into the process by which a new and more equitable formula can be sorted out.

It is very clear to anybody who takes an objective look at what has been happening with Commonwealth funding of schools that the old percentage link formula did not achieve our objective of raising standards in those schools which were badly off and the establishment of an acceptable community standard throughout schools. There was no way in which the gaps between those schools which were operating at a very high standard and those which were operating at a very low standard were being closed by the application of the percentage link formula. So this new formula, the aim of which is to achieve an equitable distribution of funds and ultimately a satisfactory standard of education for all Australian children, will proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Now that the Minister has said that some schools will be worse off, will she identify which schools they are?
—If Senator Baume had paid attention to the answer, he would not have asked that supplementary question.
—I listened carefully. Which schools?

—The schools which will receive less by way of Commonwealth support will be those identified as a result of the new formula as not needing Commonwealth grants. As we do not yet have that formula, clearly it is impossible to name particular schools, but in the development of that formula all schools which are recipients of Commonwealth grants will have an opportunity to participate. The general answer to Senator Baume's supplementary question is that those schools which are able to operate well above what is established as an acceptable community standard for all schools will receive reductions in their grants.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. How effectively is the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service operating? What plans are there for the future of the service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has a very strong commitment to providing facilities and services to the veterans of the Vietnam war. That is what prompted the Government to act very quickly to establish a royal commission into the use of herbicides in Vietnam. The Government also has a strong commitment to continue the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service initiative which was begun some 18 months ago and has proved to be a very popular and acceptable form of government assistance to veterans. I point out that something like 15 per cent of all Vietnam veterans are already in receipt of benefits from the Government. In addition, the counselling service provides a very important emotional backup to the wives and children of veterans. It has proved to be popular and the Government has agreed to extend the service to Townsville and to Hobart in Tasmania.

ANSWER.PARA: During the recess I had the opportunity to move around the various States and to talk to those operating the counselling service. They are providing a remarkable service to those who served in Vietnam. Accordingly, there is no doubt that the service will continue for some time and that it needs to be extended to those who live in outlying areas.

The Commonwealth Government has established a system whereby veterans are able, at no charge, to make an STD call to the service, and that has proved to be a very important adjunct to the counselling service. There is no doubt that those who served in Vietnam want to know whether their state of health today is a result not only of reaction to the use of chemicals in the war but also of their involvement in a war with a difference, an unpopular war, and a war which clearly has created a number of psychological problems. To that extent the counselling service has a future, and one which this Government agrees will be extended as far as finances permit.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the recent Australian Council of Trade Unions and Confederation of Australian Industry task force which was set up by the Government to examine the Government's changes to superannuation. In view of the Treasurer's commitment to allowing maximum possible time for the widest possible debate on the Government's changes, will the Minister release to the Senate the report of the task force? Finally, given the continuing confusion about the present status of the Government's actions in this area, will the Minister advise the Senate what other committees, working groups and/or independent studies consisting of departmental and/or union and/or industry representatives the Government has initiated and when they are expected to report? Will the Minister undertake to table those reports when they are available?.

—Of course, I cannot release the Australian Council of Trade Unions and Confederation of Australian Industry report to which Senator Messner referred because I do not have it. What I can and will do is ask the Treasurer whether he cares to release it either here or in the House of Representatives. I will also ask him whether any other reports are in existence and whether he intends to release them. With reference to the latter part of Senator Messner's question, I dispute his suggestion of continuing confusion regarding Government policy in this matter. There is no continuing confusion. From the time that this announcement was made on 19 May, it was stated necessarily that the fine details of these proposals could not be spelt out or discussed and negotiated with interested parties prior to the announcement of a broad commitment of principle. The reason for that ought to be self-evident, even to members of the Opposition, because, if the Government had made an announcement that it was about to renegotiate or change the taxation rules with respect to lump sum or other superannuation payments, the irresponsible members of the Opposition, led by the discredited former Treasurer, would have attempted to start a run on the superannuation funds in the same way as they started a run on the dollar- regrettably successfully-prior to the election and at great cost to the Australian nation and the Australian taxpayers. The most responsible comment from members of the Liberal Party of Australia in the last Parliament on this matter came from the former member for Moore, who said quite unequivocally that in tackling the thorny question of superannuation payments and taxation, the present Government had done what the previous Government would have done years before if it had had any courage. Of course, courage was an attribute that was sadly lacking in the previous Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. The Department of Social Security published in May of this year the national guidelines for conducting investigations into domestic circumstances. Will the Minister tell the Senate whether the investigations into private habitats and habits of Australians have resulted in many or any differences in social security payments? How many alterations, if any, that he knows of have been made to benefits paid? Is there any estimate of the administrative costs of following up de facto type cases of couples or coupling?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Crowley said, in May the Department of Social Security , under instructions from the Government, released the national guidelines for the conduct of investigations into domestic circumstances. This is a difficult area of social security which has caused much heartburning over the years to various Ministers for Social Security and members of this Parliament. The action in May of publishing these guidelines was, I believe, the first time that a government had allowed the people who were involved to understand the criteria used by field officers when conducting enquiries. At the same time, field officers have been instructed to conduct any inquiries with sensitivity and care . Single pensioners are now given, as a matter of right, the criteria taken into account when decisions are made about their pensions. They receive such details when they receive their pension so that they know where they stand.

ANSWER.PARA: Over the last couple of years, decisions of the Federal Court of Australia and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal have specified several concerns, which include financial, social and sexual relationships which could be taken into account when determining rights which involve domestic relationships. The advice that single pensioners are given stresses that these inquiries are sometimes necessary but are to be conducted with sensitivity. They are advised that home inspections are not to be made. Field officers have been advised also that home inspections are not to be made. Single pensioners are also told of their rights of appeal. They are told that interviews need not be conducted at home. These investigations are difficult. They are difficult for those conducting them and they are difficult for those being investigated, but we believe it is extremely important that the system be fair and be seen to be fair, that social security clients receive their maximum payments and that taxpayers' funds are, in fact, protected.

It was unfortunate that when the guidelines came out a large section of the Press took them to be the first guidelines which had been issued and, in fact, reported them as being part of a crack-down on social security beneficiaries and , in particular, on single pensioner beneficiaries. It was equally unfortunate that some people, on reading these articles, but without reading the new guidelines, chose to criticise both the Department and the Government for what they saw as a sudden crack-down in this area. This was not so. The guidelines were drawn up after considering the views of the various courts, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the various Social Security Appeals Tribunals. They represent an advance in civil liberties in this country. I believe that they have clarified the situation considerably. Fortunately, other journalists, realising the mistake that had been made by their careless colleagues, corrected this. I hope that in future we will continue to modify the guidelines in the light of experience and in the light of views we have from the various courts and the various appeals tribunals.

In relation to the second part of Senator Crowley's question, I do not have details of how many pensions and benefits have been taken off people under these guidelines. I will certainly see whether that information is available although I must say that I think it would be very difficult to obtain it at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. It relates to the fact that the Senate will debate the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983 tomorrow and on Thursday. Is it not a fact that when Bills of this nature have come before the Senate leaders on both sides of the Parliament, including former Senator Murphy, have indicated that a free or conscience vote would be allowed? Is it not a fact that the Government has taken the unprecedented step of denying a conscience vote or a free vote to members of the Government in relation to the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983 and thus has bound them to vote for it in totality, including the divorce by post proposition? Did the Minister instigate that step? Does that direction bind members of the Government from voting against, firstly, any amendments to the amending Bill, the nature of which would not yet have been notified to the members of the Government, let alone the arguments for them, and, secondly, any amendments which were circulated during the 1982 debate and which were designed to give realistic legislative support for the institution of marriage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has always been the case that certain aspects of family law legislation have been quite properly regarded as proper subject matters for a conscience vote. In particular I refer to issues relating to the grounds for dissolution of marriage, which have been controversial in the past.
—The whole Bill; all of it.

—That is true. Indeed, it is the case, as Senator Missen and miscellaneous other people who are joining him in his reaction have said, that that is so as far as the whole Bill is concerned. One of the difficulties about the whole Bill being treated as a non-government measure of an ordinary social policy kind, notwithstanding that the overwhelming bulk of its provisions is uncontroversial, both in the original version and certainly so far as the amendment Bill now before the Senate is concerned, is that it has been impossible to get debating time for the Bill in question because managers of business on respective sides of the Parliament have been unable to request of their troops the kind of discipline that normally prevails in relation to Government measures. We have had the absurd situation, as a result, that a family law Bill has been around the Parliament in one capacity or another now for nearly three years. Certainly that long has expired since the recommendations which have given rise to this Bill were prepared and it has not been debated, even though the overwhelming bulk of it is utterly uncontroversial as even the most conscience-stricken squawker on the other side of the Parliament would agree. As a result, we simply want to get the Bill through in the interests of those many people who are being disadvantaged by the present inadequate operation of the law and by the inability of the courts to give the kinds of remedies required. I refer in particular to problems in the property jurisdiction, and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: Against that background, I recommended to my Party-I did indeed initiate this, Senator Harradine, and I make no apology for it-that the Bill be treated as a social policy measure of an ordinary government kind, save and except insofar as any individual Caucus member wanted to raise, within the Parliamentary Labor Party, the propriety of any particular clause in the Bill being treated in that way. Agreement was reached, without any dissent in the Labor Party room, that the Bill be treated in that particular way with the opportunity being given to honourable members to raise any particular clause of the Bill, as it was then before them and the Parliament, which they thought should attract a conscience or an undisciplined party vote and that the Caucus could then determine that the matter be dealt with in that particular way. No one has raised any objection to any particular matter that is in the Bill in the form in which it has been brought forward. I do acknowledge that a question will arise--

TALK.START.PARA: —You would not have got away with it if Senator Mulvihill had been here.

—I ask Senator Walters to be patient. I am doing my best to get to her. I trust I will answer all of the points which are in issue. There is a question that may well arise in the course of the Committee stage of the debate relating to amendments. Notwithstanding the enormous notice honourable senators opposite have had about the amending passage of this legislation, amendments may be brought forward at the last minute which do manifestly raise conscience issues or issues which are felt to be appropriately so described by particular members within the Labor Party. If that arises, it is my intention to seek the adjournment of the Committee stage vote on any such particular clause in order that the Party can make the appropriate decision about freeing up what otherwise would be a disciplined vote in respect of such matters. The intention is not to ram through in any way, shape or form any particular aspect of this legislation. The intention is, however, certainly to try to expedite the passage of important social legislation which is long overdue. We are in receipt of innumerable representations to this effect from responsible bodies around the country to get the particular legislation through so that people will in fact get the kind of family law that, notwithstanding the best intentions of certain honourable senators opposite, they are not getting at the moment.

—Mr President, I ask the Attorney-General a supplementary question by reason of the fact that he did not respond to the last part of my question. I asked: Does that direction bind Government members from voting against amendments about which there has been ample notice given, which were canvassed in the 1982 discussions and which are designed to give realistic legislative support for the institution of marriage? There are three at least of those particular amendments that have been circulated quite broadly.
—I do not think the Caucus decision should be taken as in any way referring to those amendments which have been previously foreshadowed but which are now formally before us.
—Not formally yet.

—Not formally yet, but which the honourable senator has foreshadowed, as he says, on numerous occasions. I take it that the content of those amendments is reasonably well known to my colleagues, but to the extent that it is not and any of my colleagues wish for an opportunity to be taken for a vote to be freed up in relation to any such matter, I am sure they will draw that to my attention and we will follow-
—They are bound to vote against it.

—No, they are not bound to do so; that is not what I am saying. If any individual wants the matter dealt with in that particular way, as I have indicated, I hope that the procedure to be applied is that that matter will be raised with me. Accordingly I, having the conduct of the legislation on the Government's side, will seek the adjournment of any such matter in order that a party room position on it can be worked out.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Government still monitoring the trial of Father Brian Gore in the Philippines, a trial which has evidently been mounted to intimidate those who work on behalf of the poor and oppressed suffering under that odious regime? In view of the assassination of Senator Aquino while surrounded by military officers and security police of the Philippines Government, what hope does the Minister hold for a fair trial for Father Gore? Will he insist to the Philippines Government that there be no extra-judicial execution of this troublesome priest?

—The case of Father Gore remains of deep interest to the Government and of deep personal interest to the present Minister for Foreign Affairs, who advises me that he and his Department are continuing to monitor the situation there very closely. It is the intention of the Government to give Father Gore all appropriate assistance to ensure that he has the opportunity to clear his name in accordance with the due process of Philippine law. The situation at the moment is that consideration by the presiding judge of a bail petition is proceeding in the relevant Philippine court, but that cannot commence until newly appointed prosecution lawyers submit a memorandum summarising the prosecution case. I understand that a 30-day extension of the normal deadline for such a submission has been sought by them. That expires in a couple of days time-on 26 August. All the available information indicates that due processes of law within the Philippines are being followed in this matter. Certainly, at this stage Father Gore has required no additional assistance from the Australian Government. If that situation should change in any way-as I say, we are monitoring it very closely-we will certainly make sure to the best of our ability that that assistance is provided.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and refers to the answer he gave in response to a question from Senator Reynolds this afternoon and to the statement which was part of that answer, namely, that the Fraser Government did nothing to bring about the building of the Burdekin Dam. I ask Senator Button: First, does he assert that no Commonwealth money was allocated to this project by the Fraser Government? Second, does he say that there was no agreement between the Commonwealth and Queensland governments for the financing and building of the dam? Third, what money did the previous Government allocate for the Burdekin Dam, what was its commitment and what amount was allocated by the Queensland Government for this year? Fourth-I ask this whether or not the Leader of the Government is able to answer any of the foregoing specific questions-is it not a fact that the Minister has misled the Senate in his answer to Senator Reynolds?

—A sum of money was appropriated by the Fraser Government last year, I think, in respect of preliminary works and feasibility studies on the Burdekin Dam. In my answer I was referring to the simple fact that for some seven or eight years pre-election commitments had been made in respect of the Burdekin Dam which were not honoured in the period immediately following the election campaign in which those undertakings were made. At the time the Fraser Government went out of office there was no agreement with the Queensland Government in respect of the building of the Burdekin Dam. There was an exchange of letters but no agreement had been entered into. As I said earlier, over a period promises and undertakings had been given which had not been followed up in the period following the election.
—I ask a supplementary question. Is it a fact that in the last Budget $6.5m of Commonwealth money was provided for this project-not for preliminary works but for the dam itself?

—I am unable to answer the second part of the question precisely but the figure sounds correct. I hear the former Minister who was responsible for many of those undertakings chortling away at the back of the chamber. I think the figure is correct.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. Is it a fact that the Australian Electoral Office in the Northern Territory is conducting a postal campaign directed towards those who did not vote in the last Federal election? Is he aware that this postal method of conducting the inquiry has no regard for the lifestyle of the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory? Many Aboriginal people will be denied a vote in the next Territory election as their place of residence is constantly changing. Will the Minister undertake to investigate the situation and perhaps look at alternative methods of carrying out the investigation to ensure that Aboriginal people are not disadvantaged?

—I have had the campaign to which the honourable senator refers drawn to my attention. I certainly share the sentiment underlying his question-I am sure the Government as a whole does-that there should be no suggestion whatsoever that any enrolment exercise which is proceeding following the last election should be conducted in such a way that it may in fact have the effect of disadvantaging Aboriginal Australians. With that sentiment very much in mind, I will certainly draw the honourable senator's question to the attention of the Special Minister of State to ensure that an immediate investigation of the situation is in fact carried out.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, concerns the proposal by the Government to issue children of 14 years of age with their own personal Medicare cards. Does the Minister not feel that this will further erode communications between parents and their children, especially with regard to sex education? I ask the Minister whether this proposal is not further evidence of the destabilising of family life in this country. Further, apart from the most obvious and well publicised problem of allowing children of 14 to be issued with a prescription for the pill without parental consent or knowledge, how can any government justify allowing these children to be given access to birth control measures when it is in fact a criminal offence for any person to have carnal knowledge of a child under 16 years of age?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a serious matter. A great deal of unwarranted concern has been generated in regard to the Government's policy on the issue of Medicare cards. I am sorry to hear someone like Senator Bjelke-Petersen adding to that problem. The Government in no way seeks to interfere with the doctor-patient relationship as defined by the various State laws, nor can it do so. The Medicare program in fact simplifies the administration of the payment of hospital and medical benefits. Nothing in this system is designed to hinder or facilitate the rights of all Australian citizens to seek medical advice, and Senator Bjelke-Petersen should remember that. If at present a medical service is sought and lawfully obtained from a medical practitioner, the Government has certain obligations under the health insurance system to pay any medical benefit arising out of that consultation or service. This will continue to be the case under the Medicare program following its introduction on 1 February next year.

ANSWER.PARA: The Medicare card in no way entitles a person to receive or disqualifies a person from receiving medical advice. The card is a convenient and permanent record of the Medicare number which will facilitate the payment of the medical benefit. The Government, like Senator Bjelke-Petersen, strongly prefers that wherever possible Medicare cards should be issued to family groups. I expect-I am sure the Government also expects this-that the overwhelming majority of enrolment applications will be filled out by the head of the household to include his or her dependent children. However, in those few cases where there is a need for a child to be issued with a separate card that will be done provided the Health Insurance Commission is satisfied that a genuine reason exists. If Senator Bjelke-Petersen does not believe that sometimes a genuine need exists, I suggest that she consult her colleague Senator Walters, who I am sure will tell her that in our investigations into the homeless youth of this country we found that unfortunately there are cases in which such a need exists.

However, the Medicare legislation will not affect in any way whatsoever the present State laws regarding the treatment of children by medical practitioners and the consent of parents or guardians which may be necessary under the different State laws before such treatment can be obtained. For the Commonwealth to take any other position than that which I have just outlined would be to introduce into an administrative area questions of morality and community standards which would more appropriately be dealt with elsewhere. I believe that the community is not assisted in this matter by the sort of alarmist behaviour exhibited by people like Senator Bjelke-Petersen and others when referring to an unfortunate but small number of people in our community who deserve our protection as much as does anybody else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier during Question Time Senator Elstob directed to me a question concerning the manufacture of scarves issued by Parliament House. The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows: The parliamentary scarves to which the honourable senator referred were selected by the Joint House Committee as the most suitable for the purpose intended. Senators and members are, by the very nature of their occupation, required to travel extensively. The material of the scarves was required to be of a type that was light and fashionable, also easy care, non-iron and wrinkle free. The material chosen was 100 per cent polyester. The Joint House Department sought samples from a number of different suppliers and manufacturers, from which the material selected was obtained. However, it was not able to locate an Australian manufacturer who made the type of material which was selected as being suitable. Consequently, an imported scarf was made according to the Committee's specification. The Joint House Department did have regard to Australian manufacture. However, in this case, it was not able to locate a source of supply .
—by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. On 21 April this year in answer to a question in the Senate I made the statement that the communique--
—Was the Senate sitting?

—I was, as will emerge. On 21 April in answer to a question without notice I said that the communique adopted by the National Economic Summit Conference had been adopted unanimously, with the exception of Mr Bjelke- Petersen, the Premier of Queensland, and two representatives of the Law Council of Australia. I have been advised by the Law Council of Australia that that answer was not correct in that both of its representatives endorsed and supported the communique that was issued at the end of the Summit. Accordingly, I retract that part of the answer which I gave and apologise to those two representatives of the Law Society, who very wisely endorsed the communique issued by the Summit.
—For the information of honourable senators, I table the resolutions adopted at the Australian Constitutional Convention held at Parliament House, Adelaide, 26 to 29 April 1983.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In doing so, I make some very brief comments. As indicated shortly after the Adelaide meeting of the Australian Constitutional Convention, the Government viewed the outcome of that Convention with mixed feelings. On the one hand, there was the unfortunate tendency on the part of the Opposition to approach the Convention in a partisan manner and to make use of stacked delegations from Queensland and, slightly more subtley, from Tasmania. On the other hand, the Convention did achieve some positive albeit modest progress; for example, in relation to advisory opinions, conventions of the Constitution and the endorsement of a four-year term for Parliament with a Senate term equal to two terms of the House of Representatives-that is, with simultaneous elections.

Four of the Adelaide Convention resolutions-resolution 2 on advisory opinions, resolution 5 on practices that should be included in the Constitution, resolution 6 on terms of the Parliament, and resolution 15 on the interchange of powers-are, as I announced yesterday, to be put to referendum early in 1984, in the event, of course, that the referendum Bills are passed through this Parliament. It should be noted that resolution 5, the recognition of practices which should be included in the Constitution, is embodied for the most part in the removal of outmoded provisions proposal which is part of that intended referendum package. All of the substantive Adelaide resolutions are now thus being implemented as a result of this particular initiative. It should be said also that the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill gives effect to much of the 1976 resolution of the Hobart Convention on that subject. So we are cleaning up, gradually, a number of the outstanding affirmative resolutions of the Constitutional Convention.

A large number of matters that were referred to the Convention Standing Committee are now under examination by sub-committees which have been set up to examine the judicature, the structure of government, external affairs, industrial relations, fiscal powers and constitutional amendment process issues. The Commonwealth Government and the Opposition are represented on each such sub- committee and provision has been made for representation of the Australian Democrats on the Executive Committee of the Convention.

So, Mr President, despite the setbacks at Adelaide, the Convention's committee system is now working well, I believe, and the signs at this stage indicate that all governments will be approaching the next scheduled Convention, in 1985, with a more constructive and open minded attitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does little to advance any matter to play fast and loose with the truth. The Attorney -General (Senator Gareth Evans), in speaking to this matter-I understand he was trying to build some common support-again, in his usual way, referred to stacked delegations. I wish to remind the Senate of discussion which took place in the Senate and elsewhere about the composition of the delegations which went to the Constitutional Convention. I remind the Senate and the Attorney-General of the composition of the Tasmanian delegation, which followed a pattern established by a State Labor Government in Tasmania. That composition has been followed at a series of conventions and reflects the unusual parliamentary composition of that State. The fact is that there is a large number of independents in the Upper House of that State. That was acknowledged by the State Labor Government. It is also a fact that there have been some changes, with people moving from being party representatives to independents. The pattern of representation with respect to Tasmania that I remember particularly well is one which extended over many years and which was never stated by the Federal Australian Labor Party, when the Labor Party was in power in Tasmania, to be a stacked arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I wish simply to put the record straight again because I believe that this piling of folklore upon folklore to create quite false impressions is totally unhelpful and is the sort of reason why the present Attorney-General will fail in his task of constitutional reform.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I have noted the second report which has been presented on the operation of the Salaries and Wages Pause Act. During the recess I noted the difficulty that had occurred in some States with regard to the spending of Federal funds and the action of the Government in that regard. I am pleased to see the statement which has been made today with regard to the expenditure that has now been undertaken and the claims which are to be made in the future. When the States agreed to the guidelines on 19 January, it was expressed by the Government that the object of the wages pause was to provide employment on projects which would make a worthwhile contribution to the community and to promote greater equality and opportunity for the unemployed who are disadvantaged in the work force.

After a great deal of discussion those guidelines were agreed to by all States. I note that the Minister at the time said that he was pleased that they would be able to develop community projects. As I understand it, this has occurred in many places throughout Australia. The guidelines were purposely flexible so that the States had the greatest degree of diversity for projects which they believed were of worthwhile community development. I think that is the outcome of the funds that were released by the wages pause in the Australian Public Service.

It is of interest to note that the June quarter rise of average weekly earnings was only 0.9 per cent. Surely this is evidence of the effectiveness of the wages pause which was undertaken. That rise of 0.9 per cent is the lowest quarterly increase in male total earnings for four years. I think it would be agreed that this is substantially, if not entirely, due to the wages pause. While the low rise for the June quarter is welcome, the annual June-on-June rate of 6.8 per cent in rises in average weekly earnings means that our wage levels have been rising at roughly double the rate of those of our major trading partners.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have thought about that last year.
— It is very easy to talk about last year, but I think we have to look very hard at next year.
—Come on. It was 18 per cent in 1982.

—Yes. What we are looking at now is something that is still very much out of kilter with the competitive market that we would be seeking for our products. I believe our competitive position would be considerably worse if the wages pause had not been undertaken when it was. If we are to receive the full benefit from that lower June quarter rise in average weekly earnings, it would seem that we ought to be looking at a continuation of the wages pause so that this lower and more competitive approach to our trading partners would be able to be sustained.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to use this opportunity at the time of the presentation of the brief second report on the outcome of the wages pause and the spending by the State governments of the expenditure to point to that effect in the June quarter and also to point to the fact that we still have wage levels which are considerably higher than those of our trading partners. The cost of living rise of 2.1 per cent in the June quarter, resulting in a 4.4 per cent rise in the first half of 1983, has made very difficult the wages policy that is being pursued by the present Government as far as competitiveness is concerned. These comments are made in the constructive belief that the wages pause has given an opportunity for employment around the community to a number of people who would not otherwise have had access to those programs which have been developed with State governments. I welcome the report that has been brought foward. As I say, I believe that a continuation of the wages pause would have been in the best interests of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIES ASSISTANCE COMMISSION AND TEMPORARY ASSISTANCE AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of Papers Nos 2, 3, 4, 6, 9, 12, 13 and 14.

These reports are of a non-rural nature. Senator Scott will deal with the rural reports. These deal with three basic subjects in relation to protection policy and the Industries Assistance Commission. They can be grouped together regarding the question of developing country preferences, rural related matters and forms of protection for iron and steel products and certain other products. I propose to deal with the first and third reports fairly briefly, but to draw attention to a few matters. Regarding transformers, it is noticed from the report that the IAC found that transformers imported from Korea and Taiwan at developing country preference rates were not causing or threatening to cause injury to Australian industry. Local industry increased sales and profits over the past two years and employment levels remained steady. However, the Government rejected the IAC's findings and withdrew the preference because of the rapid market penetration from Korea and Taiwan, as indicated by the IAC and information received since the IAC's report. Imports at concessional rates were adversely affecting industry. On that basis the Government took steps, as it did in certain other matters, to alter the developing country preference, which has been a matter of very considerable importance. I hope that the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) will agree to a specific debate taking place at some stage in relation to the developing country preference and Australian attitudes towards it.

The second matter which was dealt with by the IAC concerned gelatin and involved Brazil. As a developing country, Brazil was able to export gelatin to the Australian market at concessional rates. The question became one of whether this procedure threatened to cause injury to Australian industry. The IAC based its finding on information supplied by a Brazilian manufacturer that supplies from that country were limited; that Brazilian imports, even at 250 tonnes per annum, would account for just over 10 per cent of the estimated Australian market; and that that was the maximum it was likely to be able to export to Australia because of its need to export to other markets and its limited production. However, in that case the Government rejected the findings and removed the preference as a result of more recent information that indicated that Brazilian imports had exceeded expected levels since the report was given to the Government. In other words, that is a similar position to the one concerning transformers. This affects substantially the application of the developing country preference being given to the manufactured goods of certain countries.

The IAC report on alkylxanthates recommended that these products from Yugoslavia and the People's Republic of China be removed because of the threat of injury. The Government accepted the recommendation and said that the market situation would be monitored for a 12-month period and prompt action taken should it become evident that duty free imports from alternative developing country sources were causing or threatening to injure the local industry. That is one instance of the Government accepting the report of the IAC in relation to that matter.

The theme running through these reports appears to be that the Government has considered the information available to the IAC; it has then considered whatever information may have come onto its possession after receiving the IAC's report, although the source and the full nature of the information is not necessarily disclosed; and it has made a decision either to agree or disagree with the report, basing that decision substantially on the further information which it has received. I would be interested to hear whether that is to be the practice of this Government in dealing with IAC reports. The IAC report on the steel industry is perhaps a better known and more publicised one in view of the recent steel industry package.
The DEPUTY PRESEDENT-Order! the honourable senator's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the way in which we are dealing with some nine or ten items together, Mr Deputy President, I wonder whether I might have a brief extension of time.
—I have indulged the Senate. It was your wish that the reports be all tackled together. Are you agreeable to an extension of time being granted, Senator Button?

—Mr Deputy President, I have no objection to that but, of course, it is not for me to say. I would be quite happy for Senator Peter Rae to finish his speech, but it may be that other honourable senators want to speak on the reports. I would be happy for an extension to be granted.
—Is leave of the Senate granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

—This course has been followed in an attempt to save time overall. I thank the Senate for its co-operation. There is a significant difference between the IAC recommendations with regard to steel and the package which has been developed in consultation between the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button), the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and the trade unions involved in the steel industry in Australia and also in consultation between the Steel Industry Advisory Council and the downstream users of steel. Reference has already been made to the fact that the package is a short term proposition which appears to enable BHP to obtain some preference for a period in return for one desirable and one perhaps less than desirable element.

SPEECH.PARA: The desirable element is the negotiation of a productivity agreement and the apparent insistence of the Government and acceptance by the trade unions involved that the quid pro quo for protection must be productivity. I believe it is highly desirable in Australia that there be an acceptance of that view. Otherwise protected industries could act as pacemakers in industrial awards which create terms and conditions which are quite unreal and which only exacerbate the problem for which protection was given in the first place, rather than reducing it.

The less than desirable aspect of the agreement, I believe, is that it is for a period of five years only, during which time there is to be an investment by BHP , which is regarded as firm to $500m and possible up to $800m, at a rate of investment which is less than that at which BHP itself has been investing over the last three years and which, on BHP's own very well publicised case over the past 18 months or so by way of both submissions to the IAC and the publication of various documents, advertisements and everything else is very much less than that which will be required over a period-it suggested ten years-to give Australia a modern, competitive and efficient steel industry. The amount which would be involved is $2.8 billion. Of course, this will take the steel industry in Australia only a short way down the path.

There are other aspects of the matter which on another occasion I could comment on. In speaking very briefly to these reports I wished to draw attention to those aspects and to invite a response in due course from the Minister to the points I have raised. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to speak further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking only as a back bencher who does not come from a steel town, I believe it would be well to put on record very briefly some of the responses from the well-informed Press around Australia to the steel package which was negotiated by the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, which saved that industry from possible extinction as a feature of our national economic life. In the Australian Financial Review of 12 August the compiler of an article said:

SPEECH.PARA: With the steel industry plan announced yesterday, Senator John Button has done what few politicians have ever managed-combined industrial reality and political necessity into a compromise package that might work.

Nothing less, of course, could be expected of a Minister of Senator Button's ability and standing, but it is good to see it acknowledged in the responsible economic Press of this country. It has been acknowledged by the responsible economic commentators not only as a compromise but also as one that has every possibility of working. Even more, of course, has saved three steel cities from a situation in which grave depression would have descended on many families and many workers at present residing in those cities. We had the spectre of large- scale unemployment hovering over those cities. It has been dispersed in an arrangement which allows the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd shareholders and the market generally to invest in the steel industry as conducted by BHP at a rate which-I agree with Senator Peter Rae-is perhaps not a rate which many of us would think necessary, and which on the statements of BHP's management earlier this year, would seem to be necessary to make it internationally competitive. One wonders why BHP was not more forthcoming in its proposals to put money in it at a minimum rate of $500m a year. One wonders whether it is enough to achieve the level of investment that is needed to bring BHP into an internationally competitive position.

Nevertheless, when one combines that with the productivity agreement which has been negotiated-I think Senator Rae was correct to point to this as one of the essential quid pro quos of the trade union movement-I think there is cause for hope. As I understand it, whilst management has agreed that there will be no retrenchments once the plan is in place, unions for their part have agreed not to oppose unreasonably increases in productivity running at some 2 per cent above the national trend rate. I understand that agreement was reached with the executive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I believe it is a key part of that negotiating process. What we faced, of course, was a combination of BHP and the unions, who could have exercised sufficient industrial and political muscle to create a situation in which the Australian consumer of steel products was once again supporting an industry which was not prepared to put in the necessary investment and employment situations which did not have regard to the need for improved productivity. I believe that not only did the downstream users for once coalesce into a force which made it possible for the Government to withstand some of the pressures which BHP, and naturally its employees, were bringing to bear, but also in the overall package we now have a situation in which bounties will be publicly monitored by the Parliament in a way which is more beneficial to public scrutiny than is perhaps the case with tariff protection.

I believe that with the report to the Parliament of the monitoring authority that has been established in place of the IAC to supervise the implementation of this package we will have a public opportunity to see how the bounties which, as I said, cannot be disguised are operating in support of the revitalisation of this industry, a revitalisation which I think most commentators would agree is an achievement of this Government which is well regarded throughout the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on item 13 , the Temporary Assistance Authority report on fluorescent and filament lamps. I draw the attention of the Senate to an anomaly which exists in Western Australia and which the Authority has overlooked. Unfortunately, it results in a very poor service to the people of Western Australia. The anomaly concerns lamps which are imported specifically to meet the requirements of Western Australia, where the voltage is generally 250, as compared with 240 volts in most of the other States . To accommodate that and to look after the demand, and particularly because of the poor performance of Australian-made lamps, which last only about 1,000 hours , in Western Australia a company was established to import lamps which were rated at 260 volts. That company was helping the consumers in Western Australia. It was well received and well supported until a multinational manufacturer with a base in Australia sought and gained support for the protection of its products , which were not made to look after the Western Australian market. A by-law which gave access to the Australian market to imported lamps with a 260 volt or higher rating was changed and the minimum rating increased to 280 volts, which took them out of the range of necessities for most people in Western Australia. I think it needs to be recognised that the 260 volt lamp which was being imported by the Western Australian company had a rated 3,000-hour life-this was reported on by the Australian Mineral Development Laboratories-compared with the rated 1,000 hours of the other product available to the people of Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We have suffered in Western Australia as a result of this restriction on the importation of the most suitable lamp for our State, and I should have thought that the Temporary Assistance Authority would have recognised that. However, the contrary was the case, and this seems to be typical of the approach of so many organisations which look at the macro aspect and ignore the smaller businesses of Australia, which do help consumers. The Authority's response to an application by Lighting Supply Co. Pty Ltd that a recently revoked by-law which had admitted lamps with a voltage rate exceeding 260 volts be reinstated was that a new by-law had been issued which restricted by-law entry to those lamps rated over 280 volts. As the company's evidence was submitted by statutory declaration, received after the public hearing had been completed, and therefore the Authority was unable to obtain the comments of other witnesses, the Authority did not consider that there was sufficient basis for any recommendation concerning the company's request. I think that that indicates a lack of consideration not just towards small business but to the people of Western Australia, and it needs to be recognised.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of Papers Nos 5, 7, 8, 10, 11 and 15.

I wish to make a brief comment on the six papers relevant to primary industry. No. 5 is the report on rural adjustment. The Industries Assistance Commission in its report has recommended that there be no change in the rural adjustment scheme to meet the immediate adjustment problems consequent upon the severe drought which in most places, although not all, has now concluded. This report is dated April, when the drought was still raging. The Commission suggested that perhaps there had been unnecessary generosity or advantage to those who were not fully efficient producers or husbanders of stock and that matters relevant to fodder subsidy, interest rates and so forth perhaps had been abused. I must say that almost any matter that is relevant to the survival of an industry will in some measure be abused, but basically the provisions were well received, they were generous and, very significantly, they were needed by an important industry .

We sometimes lose sight of the fact that the drought which brought about the introduction of these provisions was the most severe both in extent and climatically that this country has ever seen. Perhaps we also forget that many people who, on the surface, should have been better equipped were relatively young operators who had very significant debts and were in the early stages of their time on whatever land or property they may have had. Basically, Australia' s primary producers are the most efficient in the world on a per capita basis, and we need to make sure that, as the drought recedes into the background, the necessary incentive is made available to enable the community on the land to survive the impact of droughts. That sort of incentive comes from a proper measure of tax deductibility in areas such as facilities for the storing of fodder, conservation of soil and water, depreciation, income equalisation deposits, which already have been tampered with, and the investment allowance, which has proved to be just as important to the metropolitan and commercial areas of rural Australia as it has to the rural properties themselves. It is in these areas that we need to establish a proper direction, thus creating the sort of capacity necessary for defence against droughts if and when they occur.

Paper No. 7, which refers to the dairy industry, merely relates to an extension of underwriting for the 1983-84 season. This extension applies to leviable dairy products. Basically, the money has not been required, but its presence is of great importance to the stability, strength and confidence of that industry. The recommendation of the IAC is that it be applied again for the 1983-84 season.
I believe that Senator Macklin will refer to Paper No. 8, the IAC report on the sugar industry. The industry has suffered significantly as a result of the drought and the downturn in overseas prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—I seek leave to continue my remarks for five minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In referring to the sugar industry one can never fail to refer to the tragic circumstance that the European Economic Community still refuses to become a party to the International Sugar Agreement, and consequent upon that are many of the price problems that confront this industry. However, the Commission has recommended no alteration in support for this industry. The pricing arrangement which applied in 1979 for a five-year period will remain basic to the circumstances of the remainder of this year and to the middle of 1984.
