PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 June, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I suggest that it may suit the convenience of the Senate to have a cognate debate covering this Bill and the Migration Amendment (Emigration of Certain Children) Bill 1983 as these are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the Senate to have a general debate covering both measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is about to commence debate on fairly extensive amendments to the Family Law Act and to debate cognately the Migration Amendment (Emigration of Certain Children) Bill which proposes to incorporate into the Family Law Act certain provisions of the Migration Act. Before commencing debate on these Bills, I refer to a very disturbing situation which has arisen as a result of answers given by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to Senator Harradine at Question Time today. In my experience it has been traditional for the Senate, and indeed the Parliament, to consider family law matters as matters of conscience and to accord to senators and members a free vote and complete freedom for debate on these matters in the chamber. That was certainly the approach which the Opposition parties took when we were in government and which we intended to take on this legislation which was in fact introduced by me when I was Attorney-General in the previous Government. Despite the fact that it was introduced by me as Attorney-General it was certainly intended that it would be treated as a Bill on which senators would be given a free vote. Certainly the Opposition approaches this matter in the same way and will give its senators a free vote.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it has transpired from answers from the Attorney-General at Question Time today, to which I have referred, that the Government, and presumably the Caucus, have decided that this legislation will not be given that traditional standing in this chamber or in another place. It is regarded as a Government measure and Government members and senators will be bound to support it as they are bound by their Caucus vote to support all Government measures regardless, presumably, of conscience or of major disagreement with the provisions of the measure. It is bad enough in itself that the traditional way in which family law matters are debated in this chamber should be so grossly changed in such a peremptory and autocratic way by the announcement of the Attorney-General but it also overlooks the fact that other matters may well be raised in this debate as proposed amendments, which by their nature will be very different from the provisions of this legislation and will be clearly matters of conscience. The Attorney-General has informed us that, if something like that does arise, the legislation will go back to Caucus for a debate on whether it will be accorded the status of allowing a free vote. Debate in this chamber will have to be adjourned to enable this process to take place. Government senators will not be free to express their views on proposals at the Committee stage without the permission of Caucus, which will sit outside this chamber and will tell Government senators how they can approach matters of such a sensitive and traditionally a conscience character.

I believe this is a most serious step. It is a most unfortunate way in which to commence debate on a measure of such sensitivity as amendments to the Family Law Act. Senator Evans's reasons for it are specious in the extreme. He said that that was the only way that he was able to have time allocated to the legislation , so that the time could be controlled and Government senators participating in the debate disciplined in a rigorous way by the Whips. Apparently it was only by that sort of guarantee being given that the matter was able to be allotted parliamentary time. He referred to the difficulty in getting this legislation brought on, following its introduction. In fact, a Bill substantially in the form of the present measure was introduced in October 1981. That Bill gave effect to a large number of the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. It also gave effect to a number of recommendations of the Family Law Council and to certain matters which had been identified by the Attorney-General's Department and others as suitable for early amendment. It was an extensive Bill. Because it was treated by the previous Government and by me as Attorney-General, as warranting free vote and free debate, a decision was made to let it lie on the table for some time so that the public generally, and expert bodies such as the Law Council of Australia, could have the opportunity to propose further amendments. They made full use of that opportunity. Certain senators like Senator Missen, who had a particular interest in this matter, also took the opportunity available to them at that time. A great many amendments were submitted by various organisations, senators and people in the community. A tremendous amount of work was done during the first part of 1982 to try to sort out all these amendments, and decide which of them to incorporate in the Bill, which the Government wished to present to the Parliament in the tidiest form possible. That is why progress was delayed during 1982.

When that process seemed to be nearing completion it was hoped that parliamentary time might be found to debate the matter in the Budget session of last year. It is worth noting that a great deal of the Parliament's time then was taken up by motions of Senator Gareth Evans and other members of the former Opposition attacking the Government, and me in particular, over the Costigan report. So a great deal of time that could otherwise have been available for debating the Family Law Amendment Bill was wasted. Senator Gareth Evans, who now complains about the delays that have occurred, chose then to use the precious time of the Parliament to make political points against the former Government rather than debate this measure. Since then, because of the early election and other factors, there has not been a further opportunity to debate it. That is the only reason for the delay.

I want now to say a few words about the Bill and about amendments to it that may be considered during the debate. I say at the outset that the Bill is substantially a machinery measure. The Bill makes changes which seem desirable as a result of the workings of the Family Law Act since it came into operation in early 1976. The Act had been in operation for several years when, on my initiative, a parliamentary committee was set up to consider its workings. The committee reported in August 1980, after the Act had been in operation for several years. Of course, we have had an even greater opportunity over the years since to see areas where there have been difficulties. I repeat, many of them are of a machinery, rather than a policy character. By and large the object of the Bill is to give effect to such matters as I have described. Therefore, it would be more suitably debated at the Committee stage rather than at the second reading stage. It is clearly a Bill which should be given a second reading without lengthy consideration. By and large attention should be focused at the Committee stage on matters of detail. However, some broad general questions, no doubt of a non-political character, should be raised in the second reading debate. I propose to raise them.

The Family Law Act, which was the subject of great consideration-certainly in this Parliament in 1974 and 1975 and by a committee of the Senate for some time prior-was, without doubt, a major piece of social legislation, indeed a revolutionary one in many respects. The abolition of the concept of matrimonial fault represented the single most important step taken that had been taken in matrimonial legislation in Australia. Indeed, although it was not the first legislation of its kind in the world, it certainly was in the forefront of reform in the matrimonial-family law area. The establishment of a no-fault basis for family law and of the Family Court of Australia represented two most profund changes in this field. The proposals which became law and which took effect in early 1976 were clearly ones which needed to be watched carefully. They were, in many respects, experimental. That is why I, as Attorney-General in the previous Government, proposed that the Parliament should review the operation of the Act. It did so in 1979-80 after the Act had had a reasonable opportunity to operate.

The question that I think must be considered, although it is not directly raised in the Bill, is: How successful has that experiment been? The parliamentary committee took the view that basically it had been successful. It did not recommend either the abolition of the Family Court, which a number of people had severely criticised, or the introduction of fault grounds for divorce . Might I say that I entirely agree with those views of the parliamentary committee. However, I think I am bound to say that, over recent years, great disquiet has been developing in the community about the social effects of the Family Law Act, in particular the effect that it has had on parents in regard not only to their marital responsibilities and their responsibilities to their children but also their responsibilities to their marriage partners, regardless of the question of children. There are, I think, two aspects to it. Whether or not it is fair to blame the Family Law Act in such a severe way, as many people do, for a number of these ills that are perceived in the community, the fact remains that the Family Law Act does remain a focus of attention by many people for these reasons. Profound social, moral and religious questions are involved. We are all very well aware of the major changes in social and moral values, changes which have become much more widespread in recent years and which may well account for matters which are giving such concern to large numbers of people in the community. I believe that it is more these factors than the Family Law Act which have contributed to this state of affairs.

I think it is incumbent upon us as members of parliament responsible for these laws to scrutinise them, to consider them and to determine whether there are any aspects of this legislation which may be contributing to the wider breakdown of marriage-the breakdown of marriage has been with us for a long time-and to the more widespread neglect of one's duties not only to one's marriage partner but also to the children of the marriage. During the years that I was Attorney- General I received an enormous amount of correspondence from people concerning the problems they had encountered under the Family Law Act, and, indeed, in the Family Court; problems, naturally enough, of such a kind that people would be seeking to blame institutions for them rather than themselves. But I do not think we can get away from the fact that a large section of the community, a very responsible section of the community, feels that the Family Law Act, the philosophy of the Act and even the institution of the Family Law Court and the approach of the Court, have in some way accelerated this process. They feel that they have not bolstered the institution of marriage but have contributed to a weakening of these ties and responsibilities.

I want to mention several matters, all of which need attention in this debate and, I hope, in the Committee stage. When this Family Law Amendment Bill first appeared in the Senate, Senator Chaney and I moved an amendment requiring a two- year separation instead of one year as the ground for divorce. We moved that amendment because we felt that moving so quickly to one year separation would be seen as the Parliament giving the imprimatur to what is occurring-the breakdown of responsibilities to spouses and to children. In the event, that amendment was not accepted but I still believe that expansion of the period of separation is a question that should be considered in this debate. There is no doubt whatever, I think, that people see the ground of separation for one year as an easy way out of a marriage. It does not encourage them to work at their marriage and to give deeper consideration to their responsibilities.

Then there is the question of counselling for reconciliation. I am bound to say that section 14 of the Act, one of the fundamental sections of the Act, which requires judges and those dealing with matters under the Act to give consideration to the possibility of reconciliation, is a dead letter. I do not know that much effect has ever been given to it. I was very concerned when talking to counsellors under the Act. The provision of counsellors was one of the major new steps that this Act introduced. The Family Court pioneered this field and the role of counsellors is very important. I am not criticising it; nor do I want to be seen as criticising them. Nevertheless their approach was this: 'Well, it is too late at this stage to do anything. The parties have decided that they want a divorce and the best thing we can do is to ease them through it as painlessly as possible'. That is a very worthy objective, I know, but I think there ought to be more attention given to this aspect, particularly when we have this very easy ground for divorce-one year's separation. It would not be too much, and it would not be too late, for better efforts to be made to counsel people towards reconciliation. I think some attention should be given to that matter in this debate.

Another matter which I think is of great importance-I propose to move an amendment in regard to it-is the fact that far too many people are now able to slough their responsibilities to their spouses and to their children on to the taxpayer. This is because of the provisions of the Act which say that in considering maintenance and property settlements the Court shall take into account-not may but shall take into account-the eligibility of either party for a pension under any law of Australia or a State. I believe that the long term effects of that provision in this Act have been very unfortunate indeed. I believe that it has resulted in more and more people being able to take a much more cavalier attitude to their responsibilities. They know that the supporting parent's benefit or the widow's pension is available and at dissolution of marriage they can so structure their financial arrangements and their liabilities to each other in such a way that they can maximise the benefits which can be obtained from the State, from the taxpayers. The great expansion of cost to Government of welfare payments, in particular the supporting parent's benefit, has been well documented. I do not intend to go into it. It was accepted as a very worrying fact by the previous Government and is so accepted by the present Government. I notice that Senator Evans in an interview published in the Australian of 11 April this year spoke about this problem. In fact, he foreshadowed in this debate the very matter I am mentioning. He said:
Any changes to the Family Law Act would probably include removal of a section which directs courts to take welfare payments into account when setting maintenance payment levels.
He said that he had set up an internal inquiry within the Attorney-General's Department to develop the proposal. He continued:
I'm expecting a report from this inquiry in two or three months.

I would like to know from Senator Evans what is happening about that. It was certainly a matter about which the previous Government had been concerned for some time. In fact, the Attorney-General's Department had been looking at this matter for some time, long before Senator Evans became Attorney-General. Therefore I do not know why this proposal seems somehow to have been bogged down . The Joint Committee also referred to this problem in its report. It said:
. . . . relatives should not be in a position to transfer their obligations to support relatives to the community at large . . .

This is obviously a matter which must be seriously considered in this debate. Senator Chaney, who was then the Minister for Social Security, and I indicated in a statement on 21 January this year that we would be proposing this amendment . We were then Ministers in the previous Government and we intended to introduce an amendment of this kind had we had the carriage of this Bill through the Parliament. Therefore, I foreshadow that amendment. I think that is something which will bring home to people their responsibilities. It will affect their hip pocket nerve and may well, in the long term, reverse the cavalier attitude to marital and parental responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you proposing an amendment?
—That is an amendment I will be moving. It may have been circulated, I do not know.
—It has been circulated.

—I wish to speak about one other matter. I refer to the proposal in this legislation with regard to divorce on the papers, which is the correct way of describing it, although it is known popularly as divorce by post, which it is not. For the sake of convenience I will refer to it by its popular description. I introduced this proposal in the original Bill. It is contained in that Bill and in this Bill. After the Bill was laid on the table for consideration I was very much impressed by the widespread criticism of this provision. Although from a mechanical point of view it is a very sensible proposal, the perception of it is very bad. I think the Senate should give consideration as to whether this proposal should proceed. In this area we are concerned with perceptions of social and moral responsibilities. I think there is a question mark about the way in which the Family Law Act is working in respect of these very sensitive matters. I do not think we should take any steps further down the road which may be seen as the Parliament giving approval to lessening the social and moral obligations that partners in marriage have to each other and to the children. (Extension of time granted) I appreciate the indulgence given to me by the Senate. I will not abuse it. I have nearly finished.

SPEECH.PARA: I have suggested that in this debate it is incumbent upon us to give some broad consideration to the role of the Family Law Act in relation to the social and moral obligations which the partners in marriage have to each other and to their children in addition to a close consideration of a large number of machinery matters that this legislation brings forward and which I support overwhelmingly. I have said that the Act was a great and revolutionary socal experiment. We should be looking at the legislation in a broad way at this stage. A parliamentary committee has done so, but I believe it is the obligation of this Parliament to do so as well. I have indicated that in my opinion there has been a worrying decline in standards of marital responsiblity. There is widespread concern in the community that this process of decline has been occurring. Whether or not the Family Law Act can be blamed is another issue altogether. But I think that the perception of the Family Law Act is important because legislation is the way in which this Parliament is called upon to discharge its responsibilities to the community. The views that it expresses through its legislation carry some weight not only in political matters, but also in social and moral ones.

I have suggested some ways which ought to be considered by this Parliament which can bolster the institution of marriage. I do not think any of us believe that we should be quite deliberately doing anything which will weaken those obligations. We would all want to see those obligations strongly held to and observed. In this debate we should look at ways in which we may positively take some steps to give a directon to the community by our views on these matters. At the same time I do not think we should be taking any steps in this legislation which will further accelerate the weakening of those obligations. Certainly we do not want to do anything in or to the Family Law Act which may weaken the role of the Family Court and the Act itself. Therefore, on reflection, I think it would be better if we did not adopt that particular recommendation. I put it only in that broad perspective, not on its own. In this Parliament we should be giving very deep consideration to the very sensitive matters that are dealt with by the Family Law Act. Regrettable as it is, these attitudes are widespread in the community. Marriage breakdown does occur. We may regret it, but we have to have legislation to provide for it when it occurs. But our legislation should be designed to bolster marriage and not weaken it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Family Law Act was passed originally in 1975 after a heated debate which met its climax after a very heated public discussion. Much of the heat was generated by misapprehensions, ignorance and the belief in myths about marriage and its dissolution. It has been interesting to see in the public discussion on these amendments over the last few months, that ignorance and misapprehension are still much alive on these issues and that the myths persist. We have heard some of them in the last few minutes. In 1975 I remember hearing from the visitor's gallery in the other place the dire predictions about social collapse voiced by those whose consciences impelled them to oppose the Family Law Act. Eight years on and those predictions can be seen to have been, at the least, grossly exaggerated.

SPEECH.PARA: Any legislation which has extensive profound social implications, as this has, needs to be in operation for some time before it is clear what changes are desirable. In 1978 a joint select committee of both Houses was appointed to review the operation of the Family Law Act. That committee reported to Parliament in 1980. In 1981 the then Attorney-General introduced the Family Law Amendment Bill, but this had not passed the second reading stage when the election was held in March this year. I am pleased that we have been able to move fairly quickly and bring this matter on for debate early this session.

I am speaking on this Bill not as a lawyer but as a former student counsellor who counselled many children and their parents before, during and after their involvement in family court proceedings. So I have been able to observe the way in which the provisions of the Act and the work and procedures of the court affect families and particularly the children of those families. I have worked with those families to minimise the trauma of the whole process of family breakdown long before, as well as after, court proceedings. It is from that perspective that I wholeheartedly support the amendments now before the Senate, more than half of which seek to implement the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. Many groups and individuals in the community have also contributed usefully to this set of amendments. I understand they are still doing so. The public discussion in the period since the Committee report was presented has had this positive result.

As I said earlier, there are some prevalent myths still being aired which need to be dispelled. I will mention two before going on to discuss some provisions of the Bill. The first is that the Family Law Act itself has contributed to family breakdown and has been the cause of rising divorce figures. Divorce rates have risen in the last decade but I believe that there are many, many reasons for this, including recently the stresses caused by unemployment and resultant poverty. If the Family Law Act has contributed, I suggest it is because it has enabled relationships to be ended with more decency, less complication and at a lower cost than was possible under the previous provisions. In other words, the marriage breakdowns which were hidden by lack of money or reluctance publicly to prove guilt have now been able to be decently buried. I assert that countless Australians and their children are the better for having been released from a dead or destructive relationship.

The second myth is that children are always better off in an intact two-parent family. It is a tragedy that many parents maintain a destructive marriage relationship, often in their eyes for the sake of the children when those children are often all too aware of the tensions that their parents believe are hidden and express relief when the breach finally comes. I welcome the changes in social and religious attitudes which have lessened the stigma of seperation and divorce, particularly for the children. Yet I have been amazed how often, even up till this year, teenagers believe they are different from their classmates because their parents have parted, when it is certain that many of those classmates also belong to one parent families, or, these days, often to blended families.

I deal now with some provisions of the Act which seem important to me, again from my perspective as until recently a counsellor working with the people whom the amendments in the Bill aim to help. I welcome the widening of the definition of a child of a marriage to include all children who are recognised to be members of the family, including adopted or ex-nuptial children of either partner and children who are born as a result of artificial insemination or in vitro fertilisation.

I welcome the proposal that proceedings be heard in open court. This was the subject of dissent from the original Joint Select Committee report. I would have agreed with that dissenting view if safeguards had not been made very tight, as I believe they have been made in these amendments. There are considerable advantages in open hearings. Firstly, justice is seen to be done and the operation of the court is open to public scrutiny. This may help dispel misconceptions such as that men never get custody or, conversely, that maintenance provisions always disadvantage women. Open courts could also minimise the fear of the unknown, which I think is very important in any court. At present most people going into a family court situation have no idea, and no way of knowing, exactly what is going to happen and what the procedures of the court are, unless they are represented by a very conscientious solicitor.

Such an arrangement would also give those who may be called to give evidence in the court some knowledge of procedures and thereby would overcome the reluctance of some of these people, such as the teachers of children involved, to take part in proceedings. This should help the court in its deliberations. The risk of identification and the invasion of privacy is minimised by the rules about publication and the heavy penalties for breach of those rules, including the ban on the publication of court lists. However, I think that the provisions in respect of open hearings will need to be watched very carefully when they start operating and may need to be amended further.

I am pleased that the distinction has been drawn clearly between counselling to assist parties to resolve differences, which is confidential, and the counsellor 's report to the court as a guide to the judge's deliberation. I hope that strong efforts are made to explain this distinction to the parties involved. The situation has been muddied at times. It is difficult for the counsellor to delineate both parts of his or her role, particularly a counsellor who lacks experience outside a court setting, and many do. It is clearly much more difficult for the other parties to understand what is to be regarded as confidential and what is not. I know that this has led to feelings that trust has been betrayed.

Clause 25 gives due regard to the rights of children. We must remember that custody orders apply until age 18 years which many people now regard as getting out of the range of what is regarded as a child. It is proposed that in custody proceedings the court will be required to consider the expressed wishes of the child or the child's preference not to express a wish. I think that is very important because the necessity to express a wish about whom one wants to live with puts very great pressure on children. Where practicable, all parties must attend a counselling conference or series of conferences, the exceptions being in cases of urgency or where counselling facilities are not available.

It is proposed that custody or guardianship be awarded to two or more persons and not necessarily the partners of the marriage. Therefore-and I have had cases in which this obviously would have been the correct solution-grandparents would be able to be awarded custody or guardianship because they are the ones who really care most about the future of the children and have the facilities to look after them. Right of access, similarly, could be granted to persons who may not be a party to a marriage.

The range of restraining injunctions is extended in the Bill to include the entrance to the home or place of work of the party or the place of work of a child. I hope that this provision also includes schools, which are often placed in a very difficult position when teachers are confronted by an angry and demanding non-custodial parent and a child who clearly does not want to see that parent. There are a number of provisions regarding maintenance, two of which I would like to draw to senators' attention. It is proposed that in ruling on maintenance a court must take into account the eligibility for pensions, including overseas pensions and superannuation, and the financial circumstances of cohabitation-for example, it will no longer be possible to avoid maintenance by giving up work and living with a wealthy partner. I refer here to men as well as women.

In property settlements, it is provided that account must be taken of contributions other than financial contributions, and that is something that is very important to women. They must also take into account the effect of the order on the earning capacity of the custodial parent. In many cases the parent who gains custody of the child has to alter his or her job or work pattern or even place of residence so as to look after the child, and these factors will now be taken into consideration. Further, the Bill provides that proceedings concerning the property of parties to the marriage will no longer have to be postponed until the marriage is dissolved. This will be of great benefit to children and the parent who has their care. Under the law at present, a family may be forced to leave the matrimonial home. Frequently for the parent and the child this means leaving the local school and social network although they may be able to move back in a year's time or longer. From the children's point of view this may be at least as painful as the final break-up of the parents' marriage.

Lastly, I come to the provisions for proceedings in the absence of parties of the marriage-what has been most erroneously referred to as 'divorce by post'. Proceedings in the absence of the parties to the marriage will be able to take place under very strict conditions. This may occur firstly, in the case of where one party institutes proceedings for dissolution, the case is undefended and the applicant requests that the court proceed without the presence of the respondent . The other provision in this case is that the respondent has not objected to this course being taken. Secondly, where dissolution proceedings are instituted jointly, where both partners are asking for dissolution and one requests that the court proceed in their absence, to which the other does not object, or where both request proceedings to take place in their absence, it is possible for that to happen. In other words, there are ample safeguards to protect the people concerned and many would consider it a civilised way to end a marriage with dignity.

TALK.START.PARA: —And saves money as well.

—It saves money as well. These provisions will in many cases save considerable cost to the parties and to the Commonwealth, incidentally, where legal aid is involved. It will save inconvenience and loss of income where the parties are separated by distance. Most importantly, it will save the emotional upset and even possible aggressive behaviour which can result when two people meet in those circumstances, perhaps after a lengthy separation which has been accompanied by much bitterness. One group has put it to me that divorce proceedings are somewhat analogous to a funeral in helping to resolve the grief of the partners and so it is helpful for them both to be present. I do not believe that this analogy is valid. There may well be no grief by that stage. If there is grief, it is unlikely to be helped by the court process which in no way resembles a funeral ceremony or a wake. A confrontation in court may well open old wounds or inflict new ones.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the benefit to the partners-I remind honourable senators that both partners must agree to such a hearing in their absence-there are benefits in reducing the waiting list for other defended actions. Waiting time will also be reduced by the delegation of some of the court's more routine work to officials other than judges. Any reduction in the waiting time before coming to court must benefit all parties but particularly children who, in my experience, often express the wish that it all be over so that they know where they stand or with whom they are going to live. Incidentally, pre-1975 it was not necessary for the respondent to be present in an undefended case.

Finally, I will mention the argument relating to proceedings in the absence of the parties which has also been used about all other reforms in family law; that is, that it encourages people to take the break-up of marriage lightly. Some people apparently believe that making divorce difficult will make people more careful about contracting a marriage. My impression is that people are more thoughtful about deciding to marry now than they were when divorce was infinitely more difficult. The counselling provisions of the Act are a step forward in safeguarding the possibility of preventing final breakdown. However, if couples feel that they have foolishly rushed into divorce there is no bar to remarriage.

I have two minor reservations about the provisions of the Bill. The first is the difficulty in ensuring that penalties will prevent publication of matters which may identify parties in Family Court proceedings. This will need to be closely monitored, especially in the early stages. The other reservation I have concerns the expertise and the time available to the court counselling service. I hope the Attorney-General's Department will make sure that that service is able to meet the increased demands upon it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in joining this debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983 and the Migration Amendment (Emigration of Certain Children) Bill 1983 which are being debated together. The latter Bill amends emigration laws. It is purely a case of bringing into family law provisions to protect children who may be taken from Australian jurisdiction. I will confine myself to the major Bill. I do not propose to make a long speech in regard to this matter. It is not that I do not regard it as a most important Bill-I do indeed and I believe the whole subject is of great importance-but it will be realised that some debate on the 1981 Bill commenced last year. In the course of the debate on the second reading of that Bill I made a speech which appears at page 160 of the Hansard for 18 August 1982. I hold the same views today about the matters which I raised during that debate but some developments have taken place which I think should be commented on briefly.

SPEECH.PARA: I join with Senator Durack in being concerned that members of the Australian Labor party do not have a completely free right to tackle this matter in a non- party way. I can understand their difficulties. I also understand that it is very important that these matters should not necessarily be considered as matters of conscience. They are not matters of conscience. It is a matter of what are the best provisions to put into the Bill. This Bill is loaded with provisions designed to improve the operations of the Family Court and to operate the family law system more successfully. I think it is a pity if members of the Parliament on all sides cannot openly join in the debate without the cumbersome procedure whereby they have to obtain some leave from their party.

Moreover, of course, as one who has given notice of a number of amendments to this Bill, I hope that members of the Australian Labor Party too will take the opportunity, overnight at least and before the debate resumes, to look at those amendments to consider whether they merit support. I say that not because I have proposed the amendments but because, in most cases, they are ideas which have been put forward by a number of bodies including the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, the Family Law Council and the Law Council of Australia, through its family law group. I think these ideas ought to be put into the Bill to improve the workability of the Family Court system. We know, of course, that this whole arrangement has taken a long time. The report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act which I have here is the result of an extensive and long investigation by a Committee of this Parliament. It has formed the basis of the proposals that are now before us. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 5.58 to 8 p.m.
