TALK.START.PARA: —The provision, as I said, does not deal with the question of property. Unfortunately, that undertaking does not go that far. But it certainly does extend to ex-nuptial children. I regret that I do not know of any move in Victoria since that time to implement the undertakings given. I hope the States will do that because even if all we are attempting to achieve in this Bill holds up we will not succeed in overcoming that lack of power, which is essentially a constitutional power. It is a problem which the States could cure. They do not want the use of the power. They do not want to deal separately with these children. I cannot understand that.
—They opposed it at the Convention.

—I regret to say that at the Australian Constitutional Convention in April the attitude taken by some of my colleagues in this chamber with respect to this matter was not satisfactory either. For years when in government honourable senators now on this side of the chamber pressed for the reference of powers but apparently some honourable senators lost interest in this matter at the Constitutional Convention and did not press on with it.
—I moved it.

—I accept that, but the fact is that we did not show that continuing desire which we urged on the States for years. Honourable senators on both sides of the chamber should be urging that the reference of powers be given . I say that in passing because I believe that whatever we do in this Bill we do not cover that altogether.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not propose to speak at any length on this matter. I will move a number of amendments to the Bill which is before us. When the previous Bill was debated in the Senate I provided a list of amendments which were a mixture. The amendments came from the recommendations of the Joint Select Commitee on the Family Law Act , the Law Council of Australia and the Family Law Council. They were identified in that list. I am pleased to say that the Attorney-General and the Government have accepted a considerable number of those amendments. There were 32 in all. The Government has either accepted them or put them into different phraseology. For example, a report was prepared by Mr Justice Watson and his Committee on the question of wardship and what powers should be given to the Court in that respect. It has been done in a different way. I think that the proposals of Mr Justice Watson are preferable to what the Joint Select Committee proposed. Consequently, that list of 32 amendments is now reduced to 12 amendments.

A further list of amendments was prepared by Mr Phillip Ruddock, the Chairman of the Joint Select Committee. He and I proposed to support this list in the two Houses of Parliament. These were solely recommendations of the Joint Select Committee. Because of the Government's acceptance of a number of those 13 amendments they are now reduced to six amendments. The two lists called list A and list B have been circulated to members of this chamber tonight. I hope it will not confuse honourable senators if I point out that the lists are being consolidated at the moment. Another list will be issued tomorrow which will contain all the amendments in one list. The list will be basically the same with corrections to one or two clauses where the wrong number is given. Consequently, we have in this Bill an opportunity to bring in still more amendments recommended by the Joint Select Committee after 15 months of study.

The Attorney-General has also included in the Bill a number of amendments which the former Attorney-General, Senator Durack, proposed to include in the Bill early last year. The Attorney-General has also included a further group of minor , nonetheless useful, amendments that have come to light in discussions with various groups since that time. Although the delay in the passage of this Bill has been unfortunate I believe the Bill has been strengthened and improved as time has gone on.

I do not propose to go into the provisions of the Bill in detail, except to say something about two things that I think have been subject to some criticism. Senator Durack referred to one proposal, divorce on the papers or what some propagandists like to call 'divorce by post'. Once again, I do not intend to go into that in great detail. In the last day or so the Attorney-General circulated a statement which I think it would be useful to have incorporated in Hansard at this stage for the information of honourable senators. The Attorney-General's statement is dated 17 August and is headed 'Divorce by Post'. In it he sets out the salient features of those provisions. He says that it does not really add to the rights. It does not, of course, mean that people will not have to prove what they have to prove at the present time. It will lead to convenience and a saving of costs. It will mean that the Court can concentrate on other matters where there is nothing in issue left for the parties and where in fact they have satisfied the Court by the presentation of documents and other means that the children of the marriage are being properly cared for. For the sake of convenience, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the Attorney-General's statement dated 17 August 1983 headed 'Divorce by Post'.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Senator the Hon. Gareth Evans Attorney-General, Parliament House, Canberra, A.C. T. 2600
17 August 1983
TO ALL SENATORS AND MEMBERS OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVESFAMILY LAW AMENDMENT BILL 1983
'Divorce by Post'

The following notes may be of assistance in your consideration of, and your answering of representations in relation to, the proposed amendment to the Family Law Act allowing undefended divorce proceedings to be determined by the Family Court in the absence of the parties or their legal representatives.

The proposed amendment is contained in clause 47 of the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983 which I introduced in the Senate on 1 June 1983. I have attached a copy of clause 47 to these notes. Clause 47 is only one of many amendments proposed by the Bill and will insert a new section 98A in the Family Law Act.

It has been suggested that the proposed amendment will introduce a 'divorce by post' procedure. The description 'divorce by post' is somewhat misleading. New section 98A will in fact enable regulations to be made giving the Family Court a discretion, in certain circumstances, to determine undefended divorce proceedings (whether commenced by one party or jointly by both parties) without the necessity for the parties or their legal representatives to attend a court hearing.
The circumstances in which the Family Court is to be able to exercise the discretion will be where-
(i) the proceedings are undefended, i.e. not contested;
(ii) one party has requested the court to determine the proceedings in the absence of the parties; and
(iii) the other party has not requested the court not to so determine the proceedings.

The precise procedure in such cases, dealing with such matters as service and the giving of appropriate notices, is to be the subject of regulations to be made pursuant to new section 98A, although another provision of the Family Law Amendment Bill will make the procedure ultimately the subject of Rules of Court to be made by the Judges of the Family Court themselves.

The proposed amendment will provide benefits to parties to Family Court proceedings in two ways. First there will be significant cost savings for those parties who do not wish to be present or to be represented at undefended divorce hearings. Secondly, there should be a considerable saving of court time which will enable the more difficult contested proceedings relating to children and property to be heard and determined more speedily.

There has been some criticism of the proposed amendment since it was first recommended by the Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act in 1980. It has been said that, given the seriousness attaching to the termination of marriage, both parties should be present in court when the decree is pronounced. At present, however, parties are not required to be present in court but need only be represented by a solicitor. In fact, in undefended divorce proceedings this is only required of one party-the applicant. Moreover, in my view the requirement of 12 months separation necessary to establish irretrievable breakdown of marriage is of far greater importance than a brief court appearance in bringing home the consequences of divorce to intending divorcees.

It has also been said that divorces will be easier to obtain under the proposed procedure. Whatever the precise procedure under the proposed amendment, the Family Court will still have to be satisfied on the basis of evidence before it that the ground for granting a divorce has been established and that there is no reasonable likelihood that cohabitation will be resumed. At present, the evidence upon which the Family Court grants the great majority of undefended divorce applications is mainly in documentary form, consisting of application forms and supporting affidavits. It will, of course, remain open to the Family Court to decline to grant a decree if the evidence before it is insufficient.

Further, there have been claims that divorces will be granted under the new procedure after parties have been reconciled. I do not consider that this will occur. New section 98A will only enable the Family Court to determine the proceedings without a hearing where one party has requested it to do so and the other party has not objected. It can be expected that the precise procedure to be specified will require the giving of appropriate notices by one party to the other, to minimise any chance of error. In the unlikely event that a decree nisi of dissolution of marriage is made in error, the decree does not normally become absolute until the expiration of one month from the making of the decree and it would be open to the parties to apply to the court to rescind the decree nisi on the ground that the parties have been reconciled.

Finally, the proposed amendment will not affect the present duty of the Family Court in relation to the welfare of children. In this regard, a decree nisi of dissolution of marriage under the Family Law Act does not become absolute unless the Family Court has declared that it is satisfied that proper arrangements have been made for the welfare of any children of the marriage under the age of 18 years of that special circumstances justify the decree becoming absolute notwithstanding that the court is not so satisfied. The Family Court will still be required to make such a declaration and, of course, should the evidence relating to the arrangements made for the children be insufficient it will be open to the court to require either further and better evidence or the attendance of the parties before it.

In summary, the proposed amendment will not bring about a dramatic change in the way an undefended divorce application is determined by the Family Court. The Government is convinced of the value of the amendment as an important development towards streamlining the procedures of the Family Court and reducing costs to litigants.
GARETH EVANS

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I agree with the arguments raised by the Attorney-General. I believe they are soundly set out in that document and I do not propose to expand further on them.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another matter in this Bill with which I find myself in some disagreement. I refer to the provision in regard to closed courts and publicity. I do not intend to delay the Senate at any length on that matter because it will be raised in my later amendments. When the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs recommended against open courts in 1974 it was of the belief that people's private rights should be protected and that it was not necessary for courts to be open. But one now comes to the conclusion that even the judges say that they feel they might do better under public scrutiny. I do not propose to continue the forlorn fight to protect people if judges think in that way about closed courts. I do not think it matters very much that persons can come into the courts. But the question of publicity is a different matter. Having studied this matter and having seen what the Family Law Council has said at times about the provisions for publicity, it is my belief that the unscrupulous purveyors of rubbish in this community-I mean some of the newspapers that thrive on the ordeals of people-will have no trouble riding roughshod over the restrictions imposed on them. Restrictions will be imposed on the identification of people but they will not cover witnesses or the circumstances of what has happened. Those details can still be broadcast on television and so forth. I have no doubt that the provisions are quite inadequate and I am therefore certainly, in default of any very considerable amendment, desirous of trying to take that provision out of the Bill. I will come to that in the course of the Committee stage.

It is my belief that we have here a Bill which is long overdue for passage because it contains in it a great number of very useful amendments, if one takes them quite en masse. I have no doubt other amendments will be adopted in the course of the debate. It is more important that as soon as possible we get into the Committee stage of the debate rather than my speaking at length, as I do not intend to do, about my belief in our system of family law. I recognise that every system is fallible. It is administered by fallible people and the people who come before it are fallible. Very often they have found themselves in difficulty and therefore cannot believe that they received justice. Overwhelmingly I believe that the system which we have created since 1974 has been a good one. These amendments will sharpen it up still further and will improve it in the eyes of the public. They will lead further to Australia being seen as the country which has the leading and best system of family law in the civilised world. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats normally have speakers on various Bills who put a party viewpoint. That is not the case with those Bills over which there are substantial disagreements amongst us on the major provisions. The Family Law Amendment Bill is one such Bill and therefore the comments that I make will be personal comments directed at this stage to general issues. In the Committee stage I will direct specific comments to particular matters as they come up. A very large number of amendments will be proposed. I make the comment that in regard to legislation such as this members of the Australian Democrats will not cast what is traditionally called in this place a conscience vote. Personally, I believe that is a rather odd enunciation. Presumably all other votes are not matters of conscience. I regret that the Australian Labor Party has not seen fit to follow that rather quaint procedure, simply because the debate to date on this issue had been rather interesting. I was looking forward to some unpredictable divisions on various Bills but presumably that is not to be.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to raise only general issues now, the first being that I have always thought it very odd that when we are discussing a marriage Bill, particularly the elements dealing with divorce, somehow or other it is felt that if we make it more difficult for the people involved when a marriage is coming to an end then we are somehow enhancing the status of marriage or the operation of family life. Indeed, if one takes the analogy of companies, presumably when companies were at a bankrupt stage we would make it very difficult for them to liquidate, thereby enhancing company law or the operation of companies. That seems to me to be patently absurd. Companies need help in their operations and certainly at their beginnings. I believe families and marriages need help at the beginning, and far more assistance of both a counselling and financial kind ought to be given to people coming into marriage, particularly people with young families. If a marriage breaks down we ought not in any way seek to make that operation difficult. Consequently, I will be supporting the various controversial procedures in relation to the divorce measures that are contained in the amending Bill.

However, I also make a point in regard to maintenance. I believe that that area is an utter blot on the entire system. In most cases, at least up to relatively recent times, we have had extraordinary amounts of evasion in this area. I believe that where there is a responsibility, particularly where there are children of the family, it ought not be constantly the responsibility of the State to pick up the tab. I have thought for a long time that a simpler system would be that no spouse who has care of children ought to be put in the very demeaning, often frustrating and degrading situation of trying to get money out of his or her spouse. I believe that the spouse ought to be automatically entitled to payment from the State but that the State in turn ought to recover in full from the other person, through the taxation system-this would not involve the confidentiality of tax returns-the amount of money that the person ought to be paying for the maintenance and support of his or her own children. I have no idea why this has never been done and I welcome the statement made a couple of months ago by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that he at last would move on it. I hope that in this session some diligent moves will be made so that people who have the care and custody of children where a marriage has broken down are freed from what I believe is in most cases a very trying and disturbing aspect of their lives which are difficult enough as it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would apply to both parents, then?

—Yes, both. The current situation is that the majority of people looking after children are women but increasingly family laws have given custody with the interests of the children as the main prerogative, so whether the husband or the wife has custody is not at issue; the spouse who no longer has the care of the children has to provide the sustenance.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to a matter which will not come up in the debate on this legislation in the Committee stage but it is an important aspect of the current operation of the Family Court of Australia. This is to do with the removal of the no fault clause but the substitution in many judges' judgments of a phrase which is often called 'gross and obvious misconduct'. The reason I raise this is that it is an element which, if one looks at the way the courts have been operating, discriminates against women in particular. I will come to that point a little later. To outline what I am talking about, the adoption of the irretrievable breakdown of marriage as the ground for divorce has removed that fault component . That seems to me to be a major advance which presents us with a totally different picture of what we are about in regard to the Family Law Amendment Bill. The secular divorce operation was built on some fairly basic rules-at least the fault operation was built on some basic rules-which were devised in the ecclesiastical courts which felt it was entirely appropriate to inquire into the obligations that married people had one to the other.

When the 'no fault' clause was removed the fundamental operation of the Act had to be revised, but from what has gone on in the courts that does not necessarily seem to have occurred. Basically, what we are talking about here are financial proceedings, property settlements, where the major problems arise. If indeed we are not to follow the ecclesiastical tradition, we must make some fairly radical changes in our thought patterns. While the law has changed, I do not believe that the thinking of many people has changed. This presents difficulties in regard to some of the judgments that must be made. For example, it follows that married people might now legitimately establish a relationship which is mutually satisfactory to them but which formerly would have included matrimonial offences . An example of this might very well be that a couple may encourage each other to have sexual relationships with people outside the marriage. That is something which I believe has not been grasped but really ought to be grasped. In Australia a considerable diversity of values now exists in regard to practices relating to family life. This ought to be accepted, including by judges in the family law courts. Basically, as I see it, the problem with the misconduct notion is that it relates to conduct of which the judges themselves disapprove. Married people are bound, as are others in the community, by ordinary laws regarding crime, contract, torts and so on. For instance, if there is an assault in marriage it may attract a criminal or civil sanction. No such guide is currently provided in relation to financial adjustments.

If one looks at some of the ways in which the notion of misconduct is applied one notes the following examples: One judge was not prepared to characterise as gross and obvious misconduct the behaviour of a wife who had an affair with a youth who was half her age while her husband was recovering from an operation. However, another judge was quite happy to see a husband's adultery with his daughter-in-law as obvious misconduct. The conduct of a wife in taking a half share in a house acquired while she was having relationships with other people was felt to be misconduct. The conduct of a wife who fired a shotgun through a keyhole at her husband was not so regarded. We are getting some very odd results from the operation of this notion. In one case, the court paid no attention to the fact that a husband had been callously unkind and brutal towards his wife but, in another case, a wife's bad temper was considered to be something which had to be taken into account in the property distribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —She was female and the judge was male.
—That was the point I raised previously, Senator. The judge was male.
—And such types of judge have to be removed.

—One judge went so far as actually to define such conduct as conduct which would cause an ordinary male to throw up his hands and say: ' Surely that woman is not going to get away with any money'. I think that these types of judgments in property settlements are trying to re-introduce through the back door-
—Male judges.

—A male judge, definitely. One gets the feeling that we may very well be going back to notions such as that of the guilty wife who should be fed with the bread of affliction and the water of adversity.
—Is that a direct quote?

—No, Senator, except from the Bible. The conjuring up of images of outraged ordinary mortals seems not to be a suitable basis upon which analyses for property settlements can or ought to be made. I believe that we need to be careful. The Joint Committee on the Family Law Act actually advocated that we look at this notion further. Luckily the proposal was not accepted, and in combing through the myriads of proposed amendments I have not encountered any such proposal. However, I would not say that one of that kind will not arise. Given the fact that new amendments are placed on my desk every hour, doubtless it will be amongst them. If it is we might have to re-open this whole debate. It would be extremely detrimental if we allowed that fault notion to continue in a different guise.
—It would be even more discriminatory than usual.

—Yes. We probably need-I do not perceive this to be the appropriate time-having removed that notion entirely, to move forward and try to seek a modern family law Bill geared specifically to achieving future harmony, the reduction of bitterness and humiliation when marriages break down, and the removal of the notion of misconduct as having no general relevance to modern financial arrangements. In a modern world we are faced with an agreement or partnership arrived at between a couple when they enter into marriage. I do not believe it is any longer appropriate to look at a distribution. Problems have occurred in regard to notional distribution which I do not believe should any longer be inquired into by law. The way in which people go about their division of labour is something to be contained entirely within the marriage and property settlements ought not be based on whatever arrangements they may have come to. If that were taken into account I think that for a long time to come it would be to the disadvantage of women, not men, in the marriage situation. One hopes that at some future time that may not be the case, but I perceive that for a considerable time to come it would be.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to an item raised by Senator Missen, one which is extremely important to me, concerning ex-nuptial children. At the Australian Constitutional Convention, Mr Landa moved:
That this Convention recommends that the Constitution be amended to enable the Commonwealth Parliament to legislate with respect to:
(a) the custody and guardianship of children, but not so as to detract from the powers of the States to legislate with respect to the protection and welfare of children;
(b) the maintenance of children, and the payment of expenses in relation to children and child bearing; and
(c) rights and liabilities in relation to property, being rights and liabilities of husbands and wives arising out of the marital relationship.

This has been a long standing issue. I was bitterly disappointed that during the debate at the Constitutional Convention political divisions were allowed to rise yet again to destroy something that most people believed would have been acceptable. We have lost another opportunity to do something about a matter-

TALK.START.PARA: —Temporarily?

—Temporarily-which judge after judge, in all sorts of jurisdictions, has commented on as representing an utter blot and a disgrace on the community. Indeed, cases were raised during speeches at the Convention illustrating that judges did not even know under which jurisdiction they fell. Some judges have suggested that probably they do not fall under any. At least no judge wants to take on the issue. Other instances were cited in which cases had to go to at least two jurisdictions with all the ensuing costs and problems involved in moving between courts. That seems to me to be an absurdity that ought not to be allowed. The Convention was derailed on a very sensible proposal , one which most people thought was non-contentious. In relation to that I moved an additional amendment as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: the definition of the relationship between parents and children, and the determination of issues concerning the parentage of any person;

I said that that also should fall under Commonwealth jurisdiction. I believe we have already had sufficient warning on this but I suppose we will allow ourselves to get into diabolical trouble over, for example, the problems with in vitro fertilisation and surrogate mothers. There are so many problems in those areas and we know they are there. Members of the Law Reform Commission have spoken time and again about them on public platforms and in conferences. We know that we will be faced with absolutely horrendous legal problems; not only us, the oldies, as it were, but also, and more importantly, the children. They will be faced with enormous difficulties. I can see that cases will end up in the divorce courts with these problems not settled, in many cases to the detriment of the children. Unfortunately that amendment was also not acceptable.

We in this country have not moved one whit forward in the last few years towards taking a sensible attitude with marriage. Problems associated with the breakdown of marriage and the children of such marriages must be solved in a legal sense. The legalities must be simplified. We must have a coherent body of law that can be applied in a single jurisdiction. I would have thought that we would have reached that stage by 1983 yet we have found that the whole problem has again been derailed. I must admit that I cannot share Senator Missen's optimism that it is only for a short period. I hope it will be, but I do not believe that to be the case. If anything, we had our best chance this year to do something about it.

If the proposed amendments, including the reference of powers, are carried that certainly will make this job a lot easier. But then again, we are still confronted with the intransigence of a number of States. I do not know how one overcomes that. I do not really care whether it is dealt with at a Federal or State level. I believe it would be much simpler at a Federal level, for a whole host of reasons. However, now I think I would even settle for it to be done at a State level. That might be regarded as heresy, but I wish it were all in one place and I wish we could heed the problems that have been raised in regard to many children. This Bill cannot address those problems; it is unable to do so in a constitutional way. We do know that we will face some fairly substantial problems-many of them have already arisen-with children who are born as a result of new medical procedures of one kind or another or new forms of relationships that previously have not been available. Their availability now means that we must take a much more open and sympathetic view.

I believe-again, this may be heresy to many people's ears here-that we must finally rid ourselves of the ecclesiastical approach to marriage. This chamber, this Parliament, is not an ecclesiastical institution any longer. We must seek, finally, to establish a marriage law based on modern legal principles. The morality of people's lives in this regard must be left to themselves. That might also be argued on theological grounds if anyone were interested to do so. As legislators our concern ought to be legal principles only. We should not try to introduce by the back door method various other moral principles that we may abide by. We should not seek to impose them on the rest of the community.

I believe we have moved a long way but I was extremely disappointed with some of the amendments that were proposed to be moved in the previous Parliament. However, some of the proponents of those amendments are not in this Parliament and therefore we probably will not see many of the more extreme versions which were suggested by certain former senators. When we reach the Committee stage I believe we will probably move back into many of those moral arguments. I hope that the majority of senators will not seek to delay these genuine and much needed reforms by harkening back to those old debates. Rather, let us move ahead and make sure that the marriage laws, as they apply, can be applied fairly and equitably and without discrimination. Above all, they should provide for the maintainance and sustenance of the unfortunate children of broken marriages. Those children should be cared for in the best way that we can manage from the legal point of view.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to add my comments in support of the Family Law Amendment Bill 1983. I appreciate the great advantage of the Family Law Act and the contribution it has made to the whole process of family law, divorce and so on in this country since it was introduced. I am also very appreciative of the fact that laws, particularly those dealing with human activities, need to be re-appraised from time to time. That is exactly what has happened. The Bill addresses the amendments that were proposed in large part by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. My only comment initially is that while I appreciate the amendments that are before us I feel that in some areas they fail to go far enough. I hope there will be a continuing review of this most important area.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to add a few comments on behalf of people who are affected by family law as distinct from the judges or the people involved in the court process. I presume that is the emphasis that most people in this debate are presenting. From my own work and from my time as a senator, although that is short to date, I have taken a lot of account of people's reports of what happens to them when they go to the Family Court. It is not always a satisfactory tale. Evidence brought before me in my work as a counsellor before I became a senator indicated that for some people the Family Court was a place of terror or fear; certainly one associated very often with an unhappy outcome.

I allude to a couple of points those people raised on a number of occasions. The most important and recurring example relates to court injunctions. I am very pleased to see an amendment in this Bill addressing itself to the provision of the power of arrest in association with injunctions. However, I wonder who will implement the provision. That is a problem. The Australian Federal Police addresses itself to the requirements of the Family Law Act very effectively in the States but police officers are spread very thinly. In our State there is any amount of evidence that the Commonwealth police are required to take a supervisory role over people attending court. They also have to take a supervisory role in respect of people attending counselling in the Family Court area. Very often they are involved in problems associated with access arrangements for people who have separated or divorced unhappily. If we now add the power of arrest to injunctions-an amendment I thoroughly approve of-do we have sufficient Commonwealth police to cope with the result? As far as I know there is no satisfactory referral of power from the Federal Government to allow the State police to pick up this matter. I make the comment that, while I thoroughly approve of this provision, I hope that sufficient thought will be given to who is going to effect it and that it will be effected adequately. It is no comfort to people to know that they can now attach arrest to injunction if , as before, it does not happen. While it may be written in the law books, that is not very convincing to the people in the electorate if it does not happen.

Another point to which I particularly wish to draw attention is the emphasis in the amendments to due regard being given to the welfare of children. That is quite right and proper, of course, but in reading through the amendments I note a considerable absence of the word 'parent'. I suppose that if I were to argue the best care for children, it would be a case of optimal outcome for parents, whether those parents lived together or apart. I think that parents are of prime importance in the provision of welfare arrangements for children and that any arrangements, and many of the amendments in the Bill address themselves to this matter, should lead to a more harmonious outcome. A less unhappy outcome for the parents therefore would be of advantage to the children.

I cannot stress enough that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in his second reading speech made the point that the arrangements and proposals for the Family Court on the occasion of marriage breakdown depend on equitable distribution of property, the proper level of maintenance and, of overwhelming importance, the best arrangements for the welfare of any children of the marriage. Again I ask: Do we give due consideration to the parents and to the welfare of the parents? Perhaps it is unnecessary to say it, but because of my dealings with children I return again and again to the point of the welfare of parents being paramount to the welfare of children.

This leads to another consideration that is addressed in part in these amendments, and I refer to the provision of adequate counselling for parents and children in the course of custody considerations. I think that not enough has been said about this matter. Counselling is extraordinarily important, and it needs to be of adequate quality. Some consideration should be given to the fact that, while we have counselling provisions, we do not have adeqaute counsellors. Secondly, we do not have counselling over a sufficient length of time. It is important to note that the arrangements at the time of divorce or marriage breakdown may not be the same in 12 months time, and perhaps provision needs to be made for the ability to return to counselling in association with the Family Court at times subsequent to the initial contact. However, the amendments in the Bill do address themselves to provisions for custody arrangements to be considered under the Family Court jurisdiction, and the Family Court does provide counselling. That is vastly better than the situation in the State courts, where there is no such counselling. In passing, I make the comment that many people who come to the Family Court do not have English as their first language. Particularly in the case of divorce and custody, where people are clearly upset or tense or anxious and are often very puzzled, there is a great need for adequate interpreters, both in matters of law and in the counselling area. Counselling in such cases too needs to be available over a longer period than that required for appearances in court.

In summary, my reason for talking to these amendments is to congratulate the Government for introducing them in this way. The amendments certainly meet the needs of many of the people who have spoken to me about the changes they have found necessary or have wanted in the Family Court and family law area. However, I say again that one of the things that becomes apparent when one focuses on the welfare of children-it is a point that I do not think I can stress enough-is that maybe the welfare of parents is forgotten. I refer to much more than the financial welfare involved in money and property considerations. Very often the greatest need of the parent is counselling for support, reassurance, information and care, thus ensuring the prospect of reasonably contented adults, which is the best guarantee for the welfare of children.

I wish to make a short comment about proceedings being open. A number of people who have spoken to me about the prospect of court proceedings being open have taken great heart from this proposed amendment. They have no fear of finding out what goes on in the Family Court. In fact they have a great need to know what goes on. I think this provision will serve two purposes. Firstly, it will demystify what happens in the Family Court and make it more a matter of common or popular discussion. I think that is very important. The Family Court is still a source of great fear to many people. Secondly, I think a number of people feel that they are not adequately represented in the Family Court and they would like the comfort of knowing that allies, friends or supporters are in the court listening and and can support them, if not in fact then, at least psychologically.

I wonder a little about the absence of a clear definition of de facto arrangements being treated in the same way as legal marriages. Many people one meets in the community have not necessarily gone through the legal marriage arrangements but to all intents and purposes have a marriage. An anomaly exists in that our welfare system acknowledges de facto relationships for the payment of benefits but the Family Law Act does not address itself to this matter in the same way. I commend the amendments, particularly those dealing with changes in the law associated with injunctions and those that reduce the amount of legal difficulty and therefore make more likely an optimal outcome for parents. Of course that will have great benefit for children. I am happy to support the amendments.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —During the winter recess Mr Guy Smith, the Clerk Assistant ( Committees), left the service of the Senate to accept the position of Clerk of the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory. Mr Smith has a record of dedicated and loyal service to the Senate and its committees, commencing with his appointment in March 1958 and spanning a quarter of a century. Among the highlights of his career in the Senate I list his service as Black Rod, when he was responsible for the organisation and conduct of six openings of Parliament, including two by Her Majesty the Queen, and when he accompanied two Governors- General during the ceremony of their swearing in.

INTERJECT.PARA: During the period of his service with the Senate Mr Smith served the Senate, senators and fellow staff members well and will always be remembered with affection for his cheery personality as well as his great depth of knowledge. I am sure that I speak on behalf of all senators, as well as expressing my own feelings, when I thank Guy Smith for his service to the Senate and wish him well in his new career in the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the statement made by the President in regard to the retirement of Mr Guy Smith from the Senate. I take this opportunity to speak on behalf of many senators on this side of the House in commending Mr Guy Smith for the work he has carried out here over many years. As you have said, Mr President, Guy Smith came to the Senate as a clerk, as one of the lowly officers of the Senate, perhaps, in 1958. Like so many of the staff and Clerks of the Senate, over 25 years he has given very dedicated service and risen through the ranks, which is the role of many who give their dedication to the Senate. He became a senior Clerk at the table of the Senate. He will be remembered for his cheerful manner and for the way in which he has assisted so many senators over the years. But Mr Guy Smith's life in the parliamentary field is not over. If one says that one is the meat in the sandwich it is because one feels that one is in a difficult situation. In this situation I feel that I am like the meat in the sandwich but in a most pleasant way because Mr Guy Smith came to me and asked: 'What is the Territory like? What is the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly like?'
—I hope that you did not tell him.

—Well, I must admit that having had 16 years in the Legislative Council and the Assembly of the Northern Territory, I do have some very kindly feelings towards that body which is going through an interesting stage. I was able to assure him that I thought that the step that he was taking while being a loss to the Senate in Canberra was certainly the Territory's gain. Of course, on the other aspect of this meat in the sandwich, the people in the Northern Territory, in relation to the position, asked me: 'Do you know this Guy Smith?' I said: 'Of course I know Guy Smith'. They asked: 'How would he fit into the role as Clerk of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly?' I was able to assure them that, if they obtained the services of Mr Guy Smith as the Clerk of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, they would be doing extremely well. I support you, Mr President, in your remarks and in doing so I commend Mr Guy Smith for the work he has done here in the Senate and I look forward with extreme interest to seeing the work and the role that he will carry out in the Northern Territory in the years to come as the Territory progresses in self- government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleague Senator Kilgariff, not as the meat in the sandwich but in some kind of dual role. We want to commend Guy Smith for the contribution he has made to the Senate in the past few years and to wish him well in the role which he is going to fill in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. Like my colleague Senator Kilgariff, I feel divided in this. I feel we have lost a very competent officer of the Senate but it will be a gain for the Northern Territory. Mr President, you have just plotted his path through the Senate and no doubt just as most privates feel that they have a field marshal's baton in their knapsack so most officers in the Senate would want to go through the ranks to have their own chamber, preferably the Senate chamber. Guy has chosen a different path in moving to his chamber in the Legislative Assembly in the Northern Territory. We commend him for this choice. As you will appreciate from your visits to the Northern Territory, Mr President, there is no doubt that the Northern Territory Government, the Parliament and the whole of the Assembly, is a very exciting area because it is the latest area of growth in Australia. The Assembly gained its independence only in 1978 or, if we can use this word, its autonomous self-government. But, as Senator Kilgariff has indicated, for some years we have had in the Northern Territory an Assembly in which he served with some distinction. It is interesting that we can join with him in commending Guy Smith for taking this decision.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to mention one other point and that is the fact that the last position that Mr Guy Smith held here was in charge of the Senate Committee Secretariat. We are very proud in the Senate of our committee system and, I think, with some justification. It is interesting that Mr Clerk and I attended in Alice Springs a conference or seminar called 'Small is Beautiful' where he and I talked about the Senate structure and the need for a committee system. We pressed upon the members for the Northern Territory the need for a committee system in their structure. They indicated that at that stage they thought they were too small. Now that they have increased their numbers to 25 and, at the moment, as they have an experienced man in this field, I hope we will see a growth in the Northern Territory of the committee structure starting, we hope, with public accounts and then moving on to other areas where the committee system can be of so much assistance. I do not want to detain the Senate. I want just to commend Mr Guy Smith for the contribution he has made to the Senate, and to me personally in the time that I have been here, and to wish him well in the Northern Territory. I think that both the Northern Territory Assembly and Mr Smith have made an excellent decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleagues in commending Guy Smith for the work he has accomplished in this place and wish him well in his further career. There is very little I can add to what has been said already and so I thought I would speak on a slightly different aspect of his going. I refer to the promotion of Anne Lynch as Acting Clerk Assistant (Procedures). She is the first woman to enter this highly lauded position as a Clerk at the table. I am absolutely delighted on her behalf. She is one of the most competent persons I know. She has already proved her expertise in the first day of this parliamentary period. She has done work for several of the senators in this place already and I am sure my colleague Senator Lewis will be able to tell us a little more about her experience on the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and her assistance to him as Chairman of that Committee, a position he held for some time. I was a member of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee for only a short time but I certainly learned to appreciate her experience and the co-operation that she gave to the Committee. She is a delightful person. I wish her well and I am so delighted that she is the first woman to sit at the table in the Senate.

—I join those in the Senate who have spoken, firstly, about Mr Smith. I, too, have found him to be of great assistance to me from time to time and a worthy officer of the Senate. I wish him well. But I rise in particular to support the remarks of my colleague Senator Walters in relation to Miss Anne Lynch. I too congratulate her on her appointment as an Acting Clerk Assistant. I recognise what Senator Walters has said about Miss Lynch as a woman but I know that Miss Lynch does not wish her promotion to be seen in any way in regard to her sex. She seeks to be recognised simply as an officer of the Senate and she has proven over the years to be a very worthwhile officer of the Senate. The Senate is very well served by its officers, ranging from the Clerk, through the Deputy Clerk and the Clerk-Assistants, to the lower levels. The high standard of our officers is one of the great things about the Senate. As a former Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances I wish particularly to speak of her work on that Committee. I know that I speak on behalf of every member of the Committee who has worked with Miss Lynch over the years and I am sure I speak on behalf of the current members when I say that she has served the Committee extraordinarily well. She has shown her competence in so many ways that we are all proud of our association with her. Although we welcome the appointment of the new Secretary to the Committee, Dr Uhr, we certainly regard her moving away from us as a loss. I am sure all the other members of the Senate agree with me that we wish Miss Lynch great success in her future career in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-On behalf of the Government I wish to thank Mr Guy Smith for his services to this place and to congratulate him on his new appointment. On behalf of the Government I also congratulate, as have other senators, Miss Anne Lynch on her consequential elevation. Whilst I am not sure that Anne Lynch would regard her appointment as striking a blow for progressive feminism, her appointment is, nonetheless, a unique one in the history of this place and represents a great credit to her.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.30 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 22 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the normal manner in which Federal Court judges and judges of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission are paid their salaries.

(2) Are one or more Federal Court judges or judges of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission paid their judicial salaries as a gross figure, without any tax being deducted, or in any manner different from the normal manner in which persons on the Government payroll receive their salaries; if so, who are the persons involved and what is the manner of payment involved.
(3) What are the special circumstances involved in each case in which deductions have been varied pursuant to section 221D (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Federal Court judges are paid their salaries monthly as are presidential members of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

(2) and (3) Except at the request of the person concerned, deductions for income tax are not made from the salaries of Federal Court judges as they are not considered to be 'employees' within the meaning of section 221A (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. I understand that a similar practice is followed in relation to presidential members of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I believe that it is not appropriate for me to answer that part of the honourable senator's question relating to the manner of taxation payments of individuals. Those arrangements are properly a matter between the person concerned and the Commissioner of Taxation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) The brand names of cars used by the Governor-General are Rolls Royce , Daimler and Ford LTD. The Commonwealth does not hold information on the cars used by State Governors.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Defence familiar with a Press report broadcast on Australian Broadcasting Commission radio news on 25 January 1983, in which the introduction stated that the former Government was to make a determined effort to enter the multi-billion arms sales industry and would concentrate its efforts on countries in the south east Asian region; if so, (a) has that marketing drive begun, (b) what countries are being canvassed and (c) will the Government be continuing these efforts to sell arms to South East Asian countries.

(2) Did the previous Government sell $12 million worth of small arms, spares and clothing to the Indonesian military forces last year; if so, what types of small arms were involved in the sales and what was their source of supply and/or manufacture.

(3) Does Australia export military small arms to any other countries overseas; if so, (a) what are those recipient countries, (b) what types of weapons are involved and (c) what are their sources of supply and/or manufacture.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia is not a large scale exporter of arms or defence equipment. The Government maintains stringent control over such exports. Each individual sales request is examined on its merits, and Ministerial decisions are taken after careful evaluation of whether the proposal is in the national interest. There has been no change in this policy, and no significant increase in marketing or sales activity in the period in question.
(2) No sale of small arms, spares and clothing was made to the Indonesian military forces last year.

(3) In the period from January 1982 to date, military small arms exports have consisted of 7.62 mm rifles and spares manufactured by the Government Small Arms Factory at Lithgow to Barbados, Brunei, Canada, Fiji, Hong Kong, Jamaica, New Zealand, Trinidad, United Kingdom and United States.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the attention of the Minister for Science and Technology been drawn to an article in the May 1983 edition of 'Australian Penthouse' entitled 'I Spy' by Dr Geoffrey Smith, which raised many important questions about the Pine Gap Space Base; if so: (a) have extremely high atmospheric fluoride readings other than those reported by Dr Smith been recorded in the Alice Springs area, what are those readings, and what is the cause of those high readings; and (b) when were the samples taken and by whom.

(2) Was there ever a road accident in the Alice Springs area as has been suggested, where a load of fertiliser caught fire and could this accident have been responsible for Dr Smith's high fluoride readings; if so, (a) where did the accident take place; (b) on what date; (c) who was driving the vehicle; and (d) who owned the truck.
(3) Has a report been called for on the magazine article claim that there could be a massive leakage in a faulty nuclear reactor at Pine Gap.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has supplied the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have read the article. To my knowledge only Dr Smith has claimed to have recorded high atmospheric fluoride readings in the Alice Springs area. I note that in the article it is reported that an analytical chemist from the University of New South Wales was taken to Pine Gap for the express purpose of confirming Dr Smith's findings but was unable to do so.
(2) I have no knowledge of the alleged road accident to which Dr Smith refers other than his own account of it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 4 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What will be the effect of ratification of the Australian-Papua New Guinea Border Agreement on the employment opportunities of Torres Strait Islanders in fishing and other industries.

(2) Will the Department of Aboriginal Affairs take whatever steps are necessary to enable Torres Strait Islanders to participate in the more competitive fishing activity in their own waters which will follow ratification of that agreement.
(3) When will the Australian-Papua New Guinea Border Agreement be ratified.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Ratification of the Australian-Papua New Guinea Border Agreement, usually referred to as the Torres Strait Treaty, is not expected to have a substantial impact, of itself, on employment opportunities for Torres Strait Islanders in fishing or other industries. The Treaty, however, places emphasis on protecting the livelihood of Torres Strait Islanders.

(2) The Department of Aboriginal Affairs in consultation with other authorities will continue to monitor opportunities for Islanders to participate in commercial fishing activities. The draft fisheries legislation currently being considered by the Government creates a special category of commercial fishing designed to encourage and facilitate participation by Australian traditional inhabitants. The Aborginal Development Commission, through its purchase of Keriba Lagau Pty Ltd and the mother ship 'Paluma' has already taken an active role in fostering Islander interest and involvement in the commercial exploitation of the Strait's fisheries.

(3) The Government is conscious of the need to ratify the Torres Strait Treaty as quickly as possible and is actively examining the steps that should now be taken to enable Australia to do so. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and his Papua New Guinea counterpart recently foreshadowed ratification once all implementing legislation was in place in both countries. Papua New Guinea has indicated that it expects to have draft legislation ready for the August sitting of its Parliament. We expect that Commonwealth legislation will be introduced to Parliament in the Budget sittings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 5 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Was a Commonwealth Ford Falcon station wagon, number plate ZDE 693, on official business at Rosehill Racecourse in Sydney between 3.00 pm and 4.00 pm on Monday, 2 May; if so (a) what was the nature of the business, (b) what was the name of the driver, and (c) who authorised him to be at the racecourse that day.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: A Commonwealth vehicle, registration ZDE 693 was present at Rosehill Racecourse between 3.00 pm and 4.00 pm on Monday, 2 May. The vehicle belongs to the Australian Broadcasting Commission. It was driven by a Commission driver and was on assignment, at the time, for the Public Affairs Radio Department.
