QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 11 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What measures are to be undertaken by the Department of Social Security to recover the overpayments detailed in the report of the Auditor-General dated May 1983.
(2) What instructions will the Minister for Social Security issue to prevent further overpayments.
(3) How much overpayment is classified as 'incorrect payments'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) In accordance with the requirements of the Audit Act, there is an ongoing process of recovery of overpayments, that is, any payment in excess of entitlement which is deemed to be an incorrect payment.

The incorrect payments shown in the Auditor-General's Report are a measure of the consolidated outstanding debit at the time of reporting. Many of the aspects mentioned in the report had already been detected and action to correct them was already underway.

Although pension and benefit payments total some $11.5 billion annually, the amount the Department of Social Security has outstanding for recovery is less than one half of one percent of the total amount, despite the fact that the Department deals with over 4 million clients and issues over 60 million cheques every year.

In addition to the continual surveillance of pension and benefit payments the Department has recently moved to strengthen its advice in this area through the creation of a Performance Monitoring Branch with responsibility for examining areas of concern such as those referred to in the Auditor-General's Report.

Many instances of increased payments arise because the Department becomes aware of the pensioner or beneficiary's changed circumstances, and this necessitates a recalculation of earlier entitlement. The nature of these occurrences is such that they cannot be prevented by issuing instructious.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, upon notice , on 5 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has there recently been a number of delays, some up to three months, in the assessment of students applying to the Commonwealth Department of Education and Youth Affairs' Brisbane Office for TEAS allowances;
(2) Are many students disadvantaged by this delay and do some face financial hardship; if so what steps, if any, does the Government intend to implement to reduce this delay in payment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The majority of students who applied for a TEAS allowance through the Queensland office this year received their first payment within five to seven weeks of lodging their applications. Where an incomplete application has been lodged and it has been necessary to seek additional information from the student before payment of allowance could commence, processing time has been extended. Delays of up to three months have occurred only in exceptional cases where the assessment was unusually complex or the applicant experienced difficulty in providing the additional information requested.

(2) I appreciate that delays in processing applications for TEAS allowances have caused hardship for some students. Applications for student assistance schemes for 1983 have been greater than was expected which has placed a strain on the staffing and ADP resources of my Department. Where a student who is eligible for assistance has been experiencing hardship because of processing delays and the situation has been brought to the attention of the Queensland Office, arrangements have been made to expedite the first allowance payment. I have asked that the situation overall be reviewed with the object of reducing processing times in the longer term.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 18 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do water shortages exist at Mount Morgan because of the Queensland Government's refusals to allocate a greater percentage of funds available under the Water Support Resources Scheme.
(2) Have several approaches been made to the Queensland Government to make Mount Morgan a 'high priority' area.
(3) Is the local council forced to transport water from Rockhampton at a weekly cost of $1200 of which it must pay 25 per cent of the cost.
(4) What action will the Federal Government take to rectify this situation such as declaring Mount Morgan a disaster area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Mount Morgan has suffered water problems in recent times, but these have resulted from the lengthy drought conditions prevailing in the area and in fact throughout most of the State. A return to normal weather patterns should overcome many of the recent water supply problems.
(2) Until quite recently the Shire of Mount Morgan had not approached the Queensland Government to include a Mount Morgan Water Supply proposal in its National Water Resources Program submissions.

(3) During the recent drought period, the Council found it necessary to transport water to the town for a period. Under the Disaster Relief Arrangements , the Council was required to contribute 25 per cent of the cost of this transport.
(4) Declaration of disaster areas is a matter for the various State Governments . Mount Morgan was declared a disaster area and consequently received Commonwealth assistance.

Commonwealth assistance for natural disaster relief is provided under long standing natural disaster relief arrangements which provide for Commonwealth financial assistance to help the States and the Northern Territory meet the unpredictable and sometimes large costs of providing natural disaster relief. The arrangements recognise the State's primary responsibility for the administration, provision and funding of relief measures, in line with their constitutional responsibilities in this area.

The Commonwealth's role is confined to providing assistance on a $3 Commonwealth to $1 State basis for expenditures by each State on approved relief and restoration measures in cases of 'major' disasters where such expenditures exceed a State's assessed financial capacity as represented by an annual base amount of expenditure.

Such relief is a temporary measure to alleviate the considerable hardship experienced during disasters such as the recent drought and does not address the long term problems involved. The government has recently announced a Community Employment Program within which funds will be available for a Country Towns Water Supply Improvement Program aimed at improving water infrastructure in small towns and at the same time increasing much needed employment opportunities in these areas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are community information and advice centres which provide valuable community services well funded in all States, by State and local governments, except in Queensland where only four centres presently receive funds from Commonwealth and State governments.

(2) Do these centres in Queensland rely heavily on voluntary services and are they forced to engage in fund raising exercises to cover operating costs which greatly hinders their successful operation.

(3) How much money does the Commonwealth Government presently contribute to the funding of these centres in Queensland and will the Government introduce a co- ordinated funding system to aid these centres.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I am not aware of the detailed funding arrangements for all community information and advice centres on a State by State basis, or of the extent to which some Queensland centres are involved in using voluntary services or are engaged in fund raising activities.

(3) In recognition of the services provided by community information services in meeting the information needs of children and families, the Commonwealth, under the Childrens Services Program, contributes towards the support of nine centres, four of which are in Queensland.
The Commonwealth contributes a total of $12,116 annually towards the ongoing expenses of the four Queensland centres.
There are no plans for the Commonwealth to adopt a co-ordinating role in funding arrangements for the four centres in Queensland.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister for Social Security said that fees will be income-related for child care services; if so: (a) to whose income will the fee be related, (b) what will be classed as income and (c) will the fee be calculated by an income, means or assets test.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) to (c) The maximum fee for care in Commonwealth assisted day care services will be set by service operators having regard to the full cost of providing care less operational support subsidies provided by the Commonwealth together with other factors. Services will be able to offer fee rebates on their maximum fees for economically needy families and the Commonwealth will provide separate assistance for this purpose. These fee rebates will be income related and the Commonwealth has issued income testing and fee rebating guidelines to services.
Under the income test guidelines the relevant income for the purpose of fee rebating is the gross income of the responsible parent and his or her spouse including de facto spouse.

Income includes gross salary, maintenance payments, bank interest, dividends, business allowances and pension or benefit payments but does not include family allowance or handicapped child's allowance. The guidelines allow deductions for actual housing costs of up to $100 per week and for each dependent child of up to $30 per week. This procedure gives an assessed family income.

Services may offer a total fee rebate i.e. free care for families with assessed family incomes below $65 per week, and rebates on a sliding scale for families with assessed family incomes between $65 per week and $250 per week.
The test to be applied is an income test. No account will be taken of means or assets.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 17 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Board of the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) decide, in November 1982, to subordinate the directors of radio and television news to the managers of the radio and television branches of the SBS.

(2) Is such a decision contrary to journalistic practice in Australia and the United Kingdom, where it is an accepted principle that journalists perform their duties under the direction of an editor, and that the editor is answerable to the publisher or chief executive of the media authority only.

(3) Does the decision put in jeopardy the independence of the news services: if so, will the Minister for Communications intervene to ensure that this decision is not implemented, at least until discussions have been held with the Australian Journalists' Association.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Special Broadcasting Service:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Special Broadcasting Service has introduced new administrative arrangements with regard to news services but the directors of radio and television news continue to report directly to the Executive Director on matters of editorial policy. They will report to the Head of Television and the head of Radio in operational and functional matters only.

(2) The Board of the SBS does not consider that its decision is contrary to journalistic practice in Australia and the U.K. There are a variety of practices in both countries; for example, it is not uncommon for news editors to work to station managers.

(3) The SBS does not believe that independence of the news services is in jeopardy, since the editorial link between News Executives and the Executive Director has been maintained. Discussions between the SBS and the Australian Journalists' Association are proceeding.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Australia grant $6,033,000 in foreign aid to Ethiopia last year.
(2) Has the Government of Ethiopia just ordered two Boeing 767, 210-seat jet aircraft from the United States at an all-up cost of $128 million, for delivery by mid-1984.

(3) Are there any satisfactory means of monitoring the actual uses that recipients of Australian foreign aid put these grants to, and whether the people of these countries are receiving any direct benefit.
(4) Is there any requirement for recipient countries to purchase materials and equipment from Australia with Australian financial aid or are they free to purchase from our competitors if they wish.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia did provide goods and services to the value of $6,033,000 to Ethiopia in 1981-82.
(2) I am unaware if this is true.

(3) With the exception of aid to Papua New Guinea, all Australian bilateral aid is given for specific developmental purposes. For example, in the case of aid to Ethiopia in 1981-82, we provided food aid totalling $5,486,000. This consisted of 24,400 tonnes of Australian grain, the bulk of which was channelled through the UN High Commissioner for Refugees to feed refugees and displaced persons. A further 900 tonnes of wheat and 100 tonnes of high protein biscuits was channelled through World Vision. Australia met the freight costs amounting to $1 ,300,000 associated with these consignments. In addition, grain storage facilities were provided at a cost of $489,000 and assistance totalling $55,000 allowed some 9 Ethiopians to study in Australia.

Requests for assistance are assessed to ensure that our aid corresponds with recipients' development needs. The impact of Australia's aid on our recipients is continuously appraised, monitored and evaluated.

(4) Apart from aid to Papua New Guinea, which is given in the form of an untied grant for budgetary support, almost all of Australia's bilateral overseas aid is given in the form of goods and services from Australia. As with all Government purchasing, public tenders must be invited where the estimated cost of the goods exceeds $10,000. Contracts are awarded to the lowest tender which meets the specifications after adjustment of the tender price to accord with preference for Australian content.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 18 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Queensland Government awarded a tender for the construction of stage one of the African Nile perch research and quarantine project at Walkamin Research Station on the Atherton Tableland.

(2) What guarantees exist, or will exist, that breeding ponds will be sufficiently secure to prevent the accidental discharge of fish, larvae or eggs into the environment during the quarantine period of this research program.

(3) Will measures be undertaken to ensure that the proposed introduction of African Nile perch into Queensland waterways will not result in a similar environmental disaster to that which was caused by the introduction of the European carp, and what would be the advantages of introducing Nile perch at all .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Stage 2 of the project will incorporate a water treatment plant, including the installation of stainless steel micro-screens to filter waters discharged from the ponds and the pond surrounds to prevent the escape of fish or eggs of fish from the ponds. The intention is to test the whole system using indigenous species of fish during the 1983-84 wet season and if any modifications are found to be necessary these will be carried out before the introduction of Nile perch, proposed for July 1984. All quarantine requirements of the Commonwealth Department of Health will be met before such introduction is permitted.

(3) The Queensland Government has not proposed the release of Nile perch into Queensland waterways at this stage. Any such proposal would only be made after an extensive period of research and investigation into potential impacts on the natural environment and this work may take four or five years. Any proposal to release Nile perch would then be subject to consideration by Commonwealth Government authorities and the Australian Fisheries Council.

The advantage seen by the Queensland Government in introducing a species such as Nile perch is the provision of edible sporting fish suitable for stocking the growing number of freshwater impoundments in the State.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Products Sold by Natural Therapists or Health Food Stores

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Was the recommendation contained in the 'Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Chiropractic, Osteopathy, Homoeopathy and Naturopathy' brought down in April 1977, that-'all products distributed by natural therapists or health food stores should be subjected to quality control in the same manner as pharmaceutical products generally distributed through the pharmacist' accepted by the former government; if not, will the Government be adopting that recommendation and will the same products have their ingredients listed on labels and packages.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The former government recognised that in fact many of the recommendations arising out of the 'Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Chiropractic, Osteopathy, Homoeopathy and Naturopathy' were very much the province of the State health authorities. This comment applies to the recommendation referred to by the honourable senator since many of the products sold by natural therapists or health food stores are locally manufactured. The State governments were made aware of this recommendation through the National Therapeutic Goods Committee. In respect of those products imported into Australia for which therapeutic claims are made the Department of Health examines the labels to ensure compliance with standard labelling requirements prior to granting approval to import. This includes a requirement that the ingredients be listed on the labels and packages.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister for Health consider legislation to ensure that food manufacturers indicate the levels of sodium or salt in their products' packages and labels as a large section of the community is concerned about health hazards associated with the consumption of excessive quantities of these substances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: My Department in its publication 'Dietary Guidelines for Australians' includes in its eight dietary guidelines to improve the health of Australians the following:

Food legislation in Australia including the labelling requirements for packaged foods is the responsibility of the States and Territories. However, one of the functions of the National Health and Medical Research Council is to inquire into , to advise and make recommendations to the Commonwealth and the States on matters of public health legislation.

A working party of the Council has recently completed a review of all available data on sodium in the Australian diet and its report will be considered at the next session of the Council in June 1983. The working party has recommended that although the adverse effects of excess sodium intake cannot be stated conclusively, pending further research, the community should be encouraged to reduce consumption of sodium. It also recommends that the sodium content of packaged foods should be indicated in the label in a way the consumer can understand.

The National Health and Medical Research Council at its Ninety-fourth Session in October 1982 noted the need for a review of the content of sugars and related substances in packaged foods and recommended that a working party be established to inquire into the compositional aspects and declaration of nutritional information in the labels of packaged foods including the declaration of the content of sugar and salt. It will develop a report on these aspects, in consultation with other specialist committees of the NH & MRC.
After consideration of this report the Council will make recommendations to the States and Territories on these labelling aspects for adoption into their respective food legislations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Comonwealth Government ever published comprehensive material on nutrition on a wide basis to the Australian public; if so, is it made available to schools, clinics, health insurance agencies, surgeries, etc; if not will the Minister consider the preparation and distribution of such material, perhaps in conjunction with, and promoted with, the introduction of the Medicare program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Department of Health publishes a comprehensive range of nutrition material, which is available to the Australian public, either from the Nutrition Section of the Department or from the Australian Government Publishing Service.

A number of these publications are widely distributed in the community, especially through schools, tertiary institutions and health centres. The publications, for which there is most demand, include 'Dietary guidelines for Australians' (a 20-page booklet, discussing a healthy diet and fat, sugar, salt and alcohol consumption); 'Eat better for less' (a 52-page booklet on the selection of a nutritious diet at moderate cost); 'Your health and your figure' (a 72-page book on weight control); and 'A food guide for good health' (a full- colour poster, illustrating a nutritious food group plan).

The honourable senator's suggestion that appropriate nutrition material be distributed in conjunction with the introduction of the Medicare program is worthy of consideration and I will ask officers in my Department to investigate this matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 18 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: When will the Minister for Veterans' Affairs table the report of the inquiry instituted by the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs into the manufacture and supply of artificial limbs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Copies of the report have been made available to the honourable senator and to Senator Messner. Copies have been placed in the Parliamentary Library and have been made available to commercial manufacturers of artificial limbs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Government introduce a Constitution amendment which would provide such electoral justice as envisaged by the Premier of Western Australia in his proposal to the recent Constitutional Convention, namely:

(a) that every Australian citizen over the age of 18 years who is of sound mind and who complies with reasonable residence conditions imposed by law, shall have the right to vote at elections for the House of the Commonwealth Parliament and the Houses of Parliament of States and Territories, and

(b) that unless otherwise required by the Constitution, no law of the Commonwealth or a State or Territory shall discriminate between the voting rights of people so entitled to vote or deny equal value to all votes cast, except in the case of a Division of the whole electorate into electoral divisions returning equal numbers of members. In such cases the number of electors in a Division shall not depart from a quota ascertained by dividing the total number of electors by the number of electoral divisions to be chosen to a greater extent than one-tenth more or one-tenth less.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government strongly supports the substance of the proposed Constitution amendment envisaged by the Premier of Western Australia, to which the honourable senator has referred. At the Adelaide meeting of the Australian Constitutional Convention the Deputy Prime Minister seconded and spoke in favour of the motion by the Premier of Western Australia. Due to the disproportionate numbers of non- Labor delegates in the delegations of Queensland and Tasmania and the block vote against the proposal by all Liberal and National Party delegates, the motion was defeated. The Government does not at present propose to introduce a Bill embodying the proposal of the Premier of Western Australia.

The Government is, however, committed to ensuring by appropriate amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act, electoral justice to all voters in respect of elections to the Commonwealth Parliament, and to this end has established the Joint Select Committee of Parliament on Electoral Reform to investigate and report by 31 August 1983 on a range of electoral questions which encompass, in relation to the Commonwealth Parliament, the matters on which the Premier's motion focuses.

When that Committee's report has been received it will be carefully considered by the Government and the question of introducing a Bill to give effect to the Western Australian Premier's motion will be further examined.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 19 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has there been some discussion on the possible relaxation of plant quarantine restrictions on traffic between New Zealand and Australia as part of the Closer Economic Relations agreement which is of grave concern to the Australian horticultural industry.

(2) Can the Minister for Health give any assurance that the level of safety in the New Zealand horticultural industry has not been affected by at least two factors: (a) the influx of South Pacific Islanders into New Zealand, many of whom bring with them meat, dairy products and vegetables; and (b) increased horticultural trade between New Zealand and Japan, much of it in various South American plants, including cacti, shipped via Japan where quarantine restrictions may not conform to Australian standards.

(3) Is the Minister aware that a group of Australian nurserymen who recently visited New Zealand found several plant diseases, including some seven diseases of roses, common in New Zealand but as yet unknown in Australia.

(4) What safeguards exist to ensure that New Zealand plants which are exported to Australia as tissue culture specimens have in fact been completely grown in the medium in which they are shipped and not grown as seedlings, washed and shipped in a tissue culture medium.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In discussions with New Zealand on closer economic relations it has been made quite clear that there will be no relaxation of Australian quarantine standards.

(2) The Australian Government can give no assurances on the effect of trade on the levels of safety in the horticultural industry of another country, but the New Zealand Agricultural Quarantine Service operates to a similar high standard as does Australia, and I am confident that a high level of safety will be maintained.
There are no special concessions for imports of plants from New Zealand. These are subject to the same quarantine procedures that apply to imports from any other country.
(3) No. However, as stated above, imports of plants from New Zealand are treated in the same manner as imports from other countries.

(4) Simple inspection will show whether the cultures have been growing in the sterile medium or if they have been recently transferred. If the plants can be seen to be growing in the medium, and the cultures are sterile, they are released. If there is evidence that the plants have been recently transferred, or the cultures are contaminated then entry is refused. This is the same procedure required for imports from all countries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 May 1983:

ANSWER.PARA: I am presently undertaking a review of the Criminal Investigation Bill 1981 and expect to be in a position to introduce a revised version of the Bill into the Senate later this year.

(2) What was the annual percentage air traffic growth at Adelaide Airport in each year from 1979-80 to 1981-82.
(3) What was the annual percentage air traffic growth in each year from 1979-80 to 1981-82 for the following capital cities: (a) Perth, (b) Melbourne, (c) Sydney and (d) Brisbane.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Aviation does not collect statistics on capital city domestic terminals in the form envisaged by the question. The statistics collected by the Department:
(a) relate to revenue passengers, for example, statistics are not kept on aircrew being positioned or children in arms;
(b) relate to scheduled domestic and commuter airline services. Statistics are not kept on non-scheduled services;

(c) relate to embarkations and disembarkations, for example, statistics on disembarking passengers would include Perth/Melbourne passengers who transit Adelaide and therefore do not pass through the domestic terminal;

In summary, the statistics collected are those for domestic and commuter airlines revenue passenger movements on scheduled services.

An aircraft movement is a take-off or a landing. On this assumption, the information sought is as follows:

If, however, the question relates only to growth in domestic passenger movements, then subject to the definitional qualifications outlined in the answer to (1) above the information sought is as follows:

per cent per cent per cent

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have the Defence facilities at Woomera been examined for longer-term use by the Commonwealth Government; if so, what form of Commonwealth Government presence is planned at Woomera.
(2) Is it feasible for Defence facilities at Woomera to be used as an operating or training base for the Royal Australian Air Force.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Future Australian Defence Force and other requirements for the Defence Support Centre Woomera were reviewed in a Defence study of the future management and control arrangements for the Centre which was concluded recently. The future Commonwealth Government presence at Woomera will depend on departmental and subsequent Government reaction to the recommendations arising from that study.

(2) RAAF currently uses Woomera facilities for trials associated with Aircraft Research and Development Unit activities and will continue to do so in the future. To meet this commitment RAAF has identified certain facilities ( including the airfield runway) which it plans to maintain in an operational state. Whilst it is feasible to use Woomera as an operating and training base for the RAAF, significant expenditure would be involved in upgrading facilities to increase RAAF activity levels above those which are currently conducted there .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

(2) South Australia had the highest monthly unemployment rate of any State from January 1980 to November 1981, excluding February 1981.

Informal Total Percentage Votes Votes Informal

(2) Does the Government intend to give prior selective briefings to members of Parliament rather than informing all members of both chambers on important budget matters.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was Mr K. C. Henne, an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs, questioned last October by security officers of that Department.
(2) Was the interview recorded; if so, will the Minister for Foreign Affairs supply a copy of the interview.
(3) How did the security officers obtain the private document addressed to Senator McIntosh about which Mr Henne was questioned.
(4) Were Mr Henderson and Mr Bowden also questioned and why did Mr Henderson fail to supply Mr Henne with an explanation for what happened.
(5) What are the proper duties of the security staff of the Department of Foreign Affairs.
(6) What are the names and ranks of the officers who interrogated Mr Henne.

(7) Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs support an inquiry by the Ombudsman into the Tehran embezzlement and cover up as suggested by Messrs Witheford and Henne in their letter to Senator McIntosh; if not, why not.

(8) Will the Minister suspend both Messrs Henderson and Bowden pending such an inquiry; if not, will the Minister direct Mr Henderson to stop providing inaccurate material to the Parliament on pain of dismissal.

(9) Will the Minister provide details of all contacts between Mr Henderson and the former Permanent Head of the Department of Administrative Services, Sir Peter Lawler, concerning the police investigation of the Tehran affair.
(10) Has Sir Peter Lawler been offered an ambassadorial posting; if so, is Sir Peter not already beyond the age limit for diplomatic appointments.

(11) What effect has Mr Henderson's handling of the Tehran affair had on the Department of Foreign Affairs' morale and efficiency and does Mr Henderson enjoy the respect of his staff and their unions.
(12) How many official visits did Mr Bowden make last year, what countries were visited and what were the costs to Australian taxpayers in each case.

(13) Why was a proposed official visit by Mr Bowden to Adelaide last year cancelled at short notice, and can the Minister provide a full program of activities proposed to be undertaken during that visit and an estimated cost of the proposed visit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)-(9), (11) This part of Senator Primmer's question relates to the handling within the Department of Foreign Affairs of Mr Witheford's allegations of financial impropriety in the Australian Embassy in Tehran and matters arising out of those allegations including conspiracy to cover up the matters alleged involving senior officials of the Department. I refer the honourable senator to my statement in the House of Representatives on 26 May 1983 and to my answer to part (1) of Senate Question No. 195 in which I replied to these allegations.
(10) Sir Peter Lawler has been appointed Australian ambassador to Ireland and Australian ambassador to the Holy See. There is no mandatory age limit set for appointments of Australian ambassadors.
(12) In the calendar year 1982 Mr Bowden made three overseas visits:
to Port Moresby from 15 to 19 February to chair the regional information and cultural relations conference for South Pacific posts-total cost $1633.42;

to Nairobi and New Delhi from 11-26 September to chair regional information and cultural relations conferences for posts in Africa and South Asia and to lead the Australian delegation at bilateral cultural relations talks with Indian officials-total cost $4828.94;

to London, Paris, Ottawa and Washington from 16-31 October to lead the Australian delegation to the meeting of the Mixed Commission under our Cultural Agreement with France (Paris); to lead the Australian delegation for discussions with Canada on cultural relations (Ottawa); and to discuss consular policy issues and passport matters relevant to the Stewart Royal Commission report and passport policy (London, Ottawa and Washington)-total cost $13061.03.

(13) Mr Bowden's responsibilities included supervision of the Department's State Offices. In accordance with these responsibilities, he had planned an official visit to inspect the Adelaide and Perth offices and had proposed to take two days leave in Adelaide for personal reasons following the Adelaide inspection. I am advised that in order, however, to avoid any possibility that any inference be drawn that he would derive personal benefit from his official travel to Adelaide, he revised the planned arrangements. He travelled to Adelaide and back to Canberra at his own expense on 5 and 6 May and made the planned official inspection visit to Adelaide and Perth from 12-14 May. There was no effect on costs to the Commonwealth as a result of this change in plans.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) By whom, on what date and by what means was the former Minister for Foreign Affairs advised that Mr R. J. Smith had not made any threat against Mr D. W. Witheford, and has this matter been adequately investigated. (See answer to Question No. 3140, Hansard, 28 October 1982, p. 2028).

(2) Will the Minister provide details of all relevant departmental files and documentation that are missing, together with an indication of what efforts have been made by the Department of Foreign Affairs to locate these, and does the Minister believe that Mr Witheford or any other ex-Tehran staff hold the mission documents of files, if so, on what grounds.
(3) How many people have complained about the police mishandling of the Tehran investigations.
(4) Will the Minister outline the nature of the complaint made to the Ombudsman .
(5) What has been the role of the Department of Foreign Affairs on this matter.

(8) Does the Minister believe that Mr Henderson's evidence to Senate Estimates Committee D on 10 September 1982 was full and truthful; if not, what action has been taken to correct the situation and prevent any recurrences.

(9) Are the officers withdrawn from the Tehran Embassy by Mr Henderson at Mr Bowden's request satisfied that their careers are no longer damaged on that account, and what information can the Minister provide about the attitude of the Administrative and Clerical Officers' Association and the Foreign Affairs Association on this question.
(10) Will the Minister table documents concerning the payment (or non-payment) of Mr Bowden's servants which the former Minister said on 26 August 1982, were left in a metal box.
(11) Will the Minister establish suitable channels of communication for use by staff with serious allegations against senior officers.
(12) Why were documents such as the submissions of 22 March and 8 April 1982 omitted from the Finance report and why did the Department of Finance not have access to Mr Bowden's personal files.
(13) On whose recommendation did the former Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, sign his totally misleading letter of 5 March 1982 to Senator Primmer.
(14) What, if any, legal action has been taken or threatened against the Canberra Times be senior Foreign Affairs officers involved in the Tehran allegations.
(15) Does the Minister believe that the allegations concerning Mr Bowden's expenditure claims relating to liquor and servants were thoroughly investigated.
(16) Does the Minister condone the submission of false accounting certificates by ambassadors overseas, as in the Bowden case in Tehran.

(17) Will the Minister join a number of honourable senators in seeking early consideration of the Tehran affair by the Public Accounts Committee, and can the Minister ensure that witnesses from the Department of Foreign Affairs are not influenced or intimidated in any way.

(18) Has the Minister been informed of the malicious rumours spread around Canberra with the aim of discrediting those people who provided evidence against Mr Bowden, and is the Minister aware of any evidence that these rumours are the work of senior officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2), (6)-(8), (10), (12)-(18) The subject of this part of the question is one of the matters which Senator Primmer has raised in previous questions and statements in the Senate relating to allegations of financial and other wrongful actions in the Australian Embassy in Tehran and elsewhere. I refer the honourable senator to my statement in the House of Representatives on 26 May 1983 Hansard pp 1043-1046). In that statement I informed the House of the conclusions of a report by the Australian Federal Police into these allegations and of the conclusion of that investigation. I referred the House also to the conclusions of an investigation conducted by the Department of Finance into these allegations, and quoted that report's conclusion. I went on to say-

For my part, I know nothing personally of any of the matters which have been raised. I have relied entirely on the investigations conducted properly by the established and experienced bodies to conduct those investigations. I find myself persuaded on the face of the material which has been produced by those reports that the complaints of Mr Witheford, and those of Senator Primmer on behalf of Mr Witheford, are without foundation.

(3)-(5) In the statement referred to in (1) above, I informed the House that the Commonwealth Ombudsman was conducting an investigation into complaints made by Mr Witheford as to the conduct of police in their interviews of Mr and Mrs Witheford arising from Mr Witheford's other complaints about officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs. That investigation is not yet complete and it would not be proper for me to comment on matters raised in that complaint until it is complete.

(9) In the statement referred to in (1) above, I informed the House that the Public Service Board had appointed a very senior officer to investigate whether Mr Witheford, who was withdrawn from the Embassy in Tehran, had been unfairly disadvantaged in his career by officers of the Department. That investigation is in progress at present.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what dates did Mr Ivor Bowden, Mr Peter Henderson and Mr (later Sir) Nicholas Parkinson join the Department of Foreign Affairs.
(2) When was Mr Parkinson appointed Secretary of the Department.
(3) Was action taken in 1979 by Mr Peter Henderson and management services staff working under him to prepare and process an invalidity retirement by Mr Parkinson.
(4) Was Mr Parkinson examined by Commonwealth Medical Officers, and if so, with what results.

(5) Do Commonwealth superannuation regulations contain provision for continued employment at a lower salary supplemented by a partial invalidity provision and was consideration given to employing these with respect to Mr Parkinson.
(6) What would have been the difference at that time in terms of annual pension and other benefits payable to Mr Parkinson as between invalidity and normal age retirement.

(7) Did the position of Ambassador in Washington become unexpectedly vacant in July 1979 owing to the retirement of ex-Secretary Mr Alan Renouf; if so, did Mr Renouf retire on an invalidity or age basis.
(8) Do all Foreign Affairs staff have to undergo a medical examination before long term overseas postings.
(9) Did Mr Parkinson undergo such an examination in 1979 and was he judged fit to serve at the Washington post.
(10) On what date did Mr Parkinson retire from the position of Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs and was he replaced by Mr Henderson.
(11) Did Sir Nicholas Parkinson serve as Ambassador in Washington from November 1979 to early 1982.
(12) What salary and allowances did Sir Nicholas receive whilst in Washington.
(13) How much sick leave did Sir Nicholas take during his stay in Washington.

(14) Was action recommended by Mr Henderson on Sir Nicholas' return to Canberra to process him for invalidity retirement; if so, was he examined by Commonwealth Medical Officers and (a) what was the result, and (b) what were the names of the medical officers concerned.
(15) Did Mr Henderson approve Sir Nicholas going on indefinite sick leave following his return from Washington at a weekly payment of approximately $1,400 .
(16) Did Sir Nicholas retire on an invalidity basis on 11 March 1983.
(17) What annual pension and benefits applied to Sir Nicholas as at the date of his retirement.
(18) What annual pension and benefits would have applied to him had he retired on the same date on the normal age retirement basis.
(19) What is the actuarily calculated total potential extra cost to the taxpayer of Sir Nicholas' retirement on an invalidity basis.
(20) Is the Minister aware of reports that the former Minister for Social Security, had withdrawn the invalid pension from a Wollongong man who had lost both legs in an accident.

(21) Will the Minister support an investigation by an impartial body into the circumstances surrounding Sir Nicholas' various retirement proposals and Mr Henderson's involvement in these; if so, will the Minister table the results of such an investigation at the earliest possible date.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (21) On 14 December 1982 the honourable senator in a statement in the Senate alleged that there had been impropriety committed in connection with the retirement of Sir Nicholas Parkinson on invalidity grounds and that Mr Henderson had been implicated in this impropriety. This allegation was immediately referred to the Australian Federal Police for investigation by my predecessor. As I informed the House on 26 May 1983, I have now received a letter dated 15 April 1983 from the Special Minister of State which states:
On 1 and 20 December 1982, the former Minister for Foreign Affairs asked that certain allegations by Senator Primmer in the Parliament be investigated by the Australian Federal Police (AFP).

These allegations principally involved the former Australian Ambassador to Tehran, Mr I. G. Bowden, the former Australian Ambassador to Bonn, Mr H. M. Loveday, the former Australian Ambassador to Washington, Sir Nicholas Parkinson and the Permanent Head of the Department of Foreign Affairs, Mr P. G. F. Henderson.
I am informed that the AFP has now completed its investigation and has found no evidence that would substantiate any criminal offence against any person named in the allegations.
I am satisfied with this advice from the responsible Minister.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Police Investigation into Activities of Ex-Ambassadors

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the Minister for Foreign Affairs provide details of the latest police investigations into the questionable activities by the ex-ambassadors in Tehran and elsewhere, and have all relevant officers been questioned.

(3) Can the Minister advise whether documentation has been provided by the Department of Foreign Affairs to Mr Bowden to enable him to reduce his tax liability; if so, (a) did any of that documentation purport to certify that Mr Bowden had overspent his representation allowance; (b) was any of that documentation provided by Mr Peter Henderson or staff working under his supervision and (c) will the Minister provide full details.
(4) Can the Minister provide full details including costs concerning a piano and other furniture transported for Mr Bowden from the Tehran Embassy to Australia.

(5) Was the file on the above matter sent by the former Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, to the ombudsman for investigation; if so, why was there a three weeks delay in sending the file to the Ombudsman and who had custody of the file during those three weeks.
(6) Why was the file taken away from the Ombudsman and on what date and on whose approval was this done.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) See answer to Senate Question No. 197.
(2) See answer to part (9) of Senate Question No. 195.
(3) See answer to part (1) of Senate Question No. 195.

(4)-(10) The police investigation referred to in the answer to Senate Question No. 197 included investigation into an allegation of impropriety concerning the transportation of a piano owned by Mr Bowden from Tehran to Australia. The police found no evidence that would substantiate any criminal offence in this regard. I see no justification for further investigation of this allegation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 May 1983:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 May 1983:

Commonwealth Senior Officials' Meeting, Arusha, Tanzania.
Meeting of Australian Heads of Mission in Africa, Nairobi.
Post Liaison Visit, Australian High Commission, Nairobi.
Post Liaison Visit, Australian Embassy, Pretoria.
Post Liaison Visit, Australian High Commission, Lusaka.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the recent 'Kiddigate' scandal in the United States, whereby children of high ranking officials and politicians were given lucrative jobs for which they had no obvious qualifications.

(7) Which Division of the Department handled the recruitment and apparent processes in respect of Mr Adam Smith.
(8) Will the Minister take any action over this matter and does it warrant an impartial inquiry.
(9) Will the Minister supply details of the involvement of Mr P. G. F. Henderson in the recruitment process of the Australian Diplomatic Service since he became Head of the Staffing Branch in 1963.
(10) Are recruits for the Diplomatic Service chosen following an exhaustive series of tests and are there established procedures for selecting the best qualified applicants.
(11) Did the Melbourne Herald report on 18 April 1983 that 1,000 applications were expected for 25-30 positions in 1984.
(12) Did Mr Henderson hold any conversations with outsiders seeking preferences for particular applicants for entry to the Diplomatic Service in 1983; if so, what are the particulars.
(13) How many successful candidates for selection were in fact included in the eventually approved intake as a result of conversations referred to above.
(14) Was the son of Sir Robert Sparkes, President of the Queensland Branch of the National Party, included in the 1983 Diplomatic Service intake.
(15) Will the Minister suspend Mr Henderson forthwith so that this matter can be properly investigated.
(16) Will the Minister introduce measures designed to ensure honest recruitment practices in the Department of Foreign Affairs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) See my answer to part (1) of Senate Question No. 195.

(3)-(9), (12)-(13), (15)-(16) In my statement to the House of Representatives on 26 May 1983 (Hansard pages 1042-1046) I responded to questions asked by the honourable senator about the appointment of Mr Adam Smith and Mr Douglas Sparkes . I informed the House of the procedures for recruitment of these two officers and made it clear that I had no reason to doubt that each had been properly appointed. I rejected the innuendo that merely because these officers had been appointed to the Department of Foreign Affairs some privilege or unfair advantage had been brought to bear. I do not consider any further investigation warranted.

(10) Yes: The selection arrangements for appointment, promotion or transfer as Foreign Affairs Trainee are set out in the Australian Public Service Conditions of Entry and Advancement, Gazette of 31 January 1983. The section of the Gazette entry relating to selection arrangements reads as follows: (Section 3 page 25)
3. Selection arrangements-The suitability of applicants is determined according to the following process:
(a) Academic achievement-the result of tertiary studies will be evaluated and the most highly rated applicants will be invited to sit for a selection test.

(b) Aptitude test-applicants selected on the basis of academic achievement will sit for a selection test which measures general ability, aptitude for administrative work and general knowledge of international affairs.
(c) Interview-Applicants will be selected for interview on the basis of selection test performance, together with an assessment of academic achievement and the statement of claims in the application.
Following interviews, shortlisted applicants may be required to attend further assessment sessions in Canberra.

(d) Final selection-In making final selections the Committee will consider all information gained during the selection process together with references which may be sought from people nominated by the applicants.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice , on 26 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Chairman of the Official Establishments Trust receive $230 per sitting and do Trust members receive $170 per sitting.
(2) Is Lady Parkinson, wife of Sir Nicholas Parkinson, former Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs, a member of the Trust.
(3) When was Lady Parkinson appointed to the Trust and what qualifications does she possess for the position.
(4) Will the Minister critically examine the need for the Trust's existence and the appropriateness of the present membership.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Lady Parkinson was appointed to the Trust on 20 September 1982.
As the wife of a former diplomat Lady Parkinson has excellent qualifications because of her extensive practical experience in the day to day management and operations of official residences.
(4) It is the Government's practice to review on a regular basis the need for and the membership of government advisory bodies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice , on 26 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What recommendations of the 1981 Review of Commonwealth Functions have been substantially carried into effect.
(2) What ongoing and once-off savings have been made in respect of each recommendation substantially carried out.
(3) How does this ongoing or once-off saving for each recommendation compare with the Government's estimates at the time of the Review.
(4) What was the approximate administrative cost of arriving at the recommendations.
(5) What recommendations of the Review have not been substantially carried into effect.
(6) What were the reasons for not substantially carrying out the various recommendations of the Review.
(7) What has been the extra expenditure incurred or the revenue lost in each case by not carrying out the recommendations.
(8) What were the administrative costs involved in each case in arriving at the decisions not to implement recommendations of the Review.
(9) What ongoing and once-off savings have been made as a result of the entire Review and how does this compare with the Government's estimates at the time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1-9) The Government is naturally concerned to achieve the maximum level of efficiency and economic responsibility in the administration of those programs and functions which are properly the concern of the Commonwealth Government. To this end, as the honourable senator would be aware, we have already moved to vary or overturn a number of decisions made by the Fraser Government following its Review of Commonwealth Functions (RCF).

For instance, we have announced that the Government clothing factory at Coburg will continue to be operated as a Government-owned factory and that the contract for the sale of the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Service (CACS) has been cancelled and further disposal action halted pending a review of the situation. We have also announced that we will stand by our commitment to retain public ownership of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation.

There are a number of other RCF decisions which have given rise to concern in the community. With a view to identifying any other decisions which are not cost -effective or which might be poorly-based, I have asked all Ministers to examine those RCF decisions affecting their portfolio responsibilities and provide me with a report of implementation or any proposals for alternative action.
When I have received reports from all Ministers I shall be happy to provide the honourable senator with further information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 31 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which ports were used to load polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB's) waste materials onto the incinerator vessel Vulcanus during its voyage to Australia last December/January.
(2) What other industrial waste material, if any, was disposed of in this manner.
(3) What quantities of PCB's and other wastes were disposed of by Vulcanus from each port and how was the material transported to the vessel.

(4) What quantities of PCB's and other industrial wastes were transported from the States and/or Territories not visited by the Vulcanus to those ports that were visited and what methods of transport were used.
(5) How were these materials transferred from shore to ship.
(6) Was the incineration of these substances monitored by the Federal Government; if so, has a report been prepared and published.
(7) Where did the burns take place.
(8) What was the percentage of waste material successfully destroyed in each burn and what happened to any undestroyed residue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Vinyl chloride manufacturing wastes were also disposed of in two separate incineration operations.
(3) (i) 215 tonnes of PCB wastes were loaded on the Vulcanus at Brisbane. The PCB wastes were transported in Brisbane by road.
(ii) 3177.7 tonnes of vinyl chloride manufacturing wastes were loaded on the Vulcanus at Sydney. These wastes were transported by road tanker to the bulk storage tanks at the terminal.
(iii) 1481.6 tonnes of vinyl chloride manufacturing wastes were loaded on the Vulcanus at Melbourne. These wastes were stored in bulk tanks at the terminal.
(4) 41 tonnes of PCB wastes from Victoria and Tasmania were transported by road and air to Brisbane.
(5) Wastes at each port were loaded onto the Vulcanus through a pipeline.
(6) The three incineration operations were monitored by officials or delegates of the Commonwealth Government and a report has been published.
(7) The wastes were incinerated at sea in an area more than 200 nautical miles off the south east coast of Australia, bounded by a circle centred at 39*00'S, 154*30'E with a 25 nautical mile radius.

(8) The combustion efficiences achieved during the three incineration operations averaged 99.975 per cent, 99.988 per cent and 99.983 per cent all of which met the requirements under the London Dumping Convention of 99.95* 0.05 per cent. It is normal practice that any remaining residues in the vessels tanks are incinerated with the next load of waste. Following the Australian operations the Vulcanus proceeded to Singapore for a refit. En route the tanks were washed and gasfreed and the resulting liquid was incinerated on board.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 1 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) To which section of the Stuart Highway does the Government's announcement on 19 May apply; that is, that if the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link is to be built, then $60m originally allocated to the sealing of the Stuart Highway will be diverted to help fund the proposed Commonwealth contribution to the railway.
(2) Is the Minister for Transport aware that all of the Stuart Highway in the Northern Territory is already sealed, though not all to national standard.

(3) Was the $60m to have been spent on the South Australian section of the highway north of Kingoonya, where several hundred kilometres of the road had yet to be sealed and which has been incorporated in the bicentennial road program.
(4) Is the Minister aware that this South Australian section yet to be sealed, services the mining, pastoral and tourist industry of the region which are not serviced by the rail link.
(5) What is the timetable for the completion of this project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

These include, for instance, bridges, reconstruction and pavement widening. Apart from this, the Government will continue to provide funds to maintain the road to its existing standard.
(5) It is expected that the sealing of the Stuart Highway in South Australia to the Northern Territory border will be completed by 1986-87.
