QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 1 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there a current industrial dispute between Telecom Australia and the Union of Postal Clerks and Telegraphists over the staff required on the 12 midnight to 6 a.m. shift at the Canberra Provincial Telegraph Office.

(2) Did citizens protesting the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 send over 200 telegrams on the night of 31 May 1983 and were they received at the Canberra Provincial Telegraph Office between 12 midnight and 6 a.m.
(3) Would Telecom's proposal to reduce the staff on the night shift from two people to one person, if implemented, have resulted in the 200 telegrams not having been processed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The industrial dispute referred to was settled on Tuesday, 7 June 1983.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs ensure that the Australian Government facilitates the reunification of East Timorese families where some members of those families are already in Australia, given that the Indonesian Government continues to deny the right of self-determination to the people of East Timor and continues to harass and intimidate the people of East Timor.
(2) Will the Minister ask the Indonesian Government to allow a free flow of migration of East Timorese people, including refugees, between Australia and East Timor.
(3) Will the Minister undertake the organisation of an Australian Parliamentary delegation to visit East Timor as soon as possible.
(4) Will the Minister undertake that the report of such a delegation will be widely circulated and discussed throughout the Australian community.
(5) Will the Minister direct the suspension of all military aid to Indonesia until the matters of reunification of families and self-determination of East Timor have been satisfactorily resolved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government's primary concern has been the finalisation of the list cases agreed to in 1978 and immediate family reunion involving particularly compassionate circumstances. When Mr Hayden visited Indonesia in April, the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Dr Mochtar, assured him that the program would proceed at a rate of 20 to 30 each month until the list was cleared.

It is estimated that about 50 to 60 persons with their dependants still have to come to Australia to complete this program. Some have yet to confirm whether they wish to proceed with their applications. In the two months since Mr Hayden visited Indonesia, 53 persons have arrived in Australia under the program.

(2) The Government's ultimate objective is to reach a situation where people wishing to come to Australia from East Timor can be processed under normal entry criteria in the same way as other applicants from Indonesia.

(3) The Indonesian Parliament has extended an invitation for an Australian parliamentary delegation to visit Indonesia. It is understood the visit will take place in July and that the delegation's itinerary will include East Timor.

(4) The question of the distribution of the parliamentary delegation's report will be for the delegation itself to decide. However, the Government hopes that the delegation's visit to Indonesia and East Timor will contribute towards informed debate in Australia on East Timor and Australia's relations with Indonesia.
(5) The Government has the question of Australia's relations with Indonesia under continuing review. In the meantime existing programs, projects and exchanges with Indonesia will be maintained.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 May 1983 (Hansard, page 112), Senator Elstob asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, a question relating to a statement made at the recent Housing Conference by the President of the Real Estate Institute of Australia, Mr Malcolm Gray, concerning the means testing of Federal Government assistance to home buyers. I undertook to obtain further information from the Minister for Housing and Construction.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following information in respect of the honourable senator's question:
On 19 May the Treasurer, as part of his economic statement, announced that:

(i) A new First Home Owners Assistance Scheme (FHOAS) will be introduced from 1 October 1983 to assist low to moderate income earners into home ownership. This new Scheme will be means tested to direct assistance to the most needy in the community.
This Scheme will replace the current Home Deposit Assistance Scheme (HDAS) which will continue to provide grants on a means tested basis to eligible first home buyers purchasing before 1 October.

The maximum grant under both FHOAS and HDAS will be available to home purchasers with family income of up to 135 per cent of average weekly earnings with assistance tapering to zero at 155 per cent of average weekly earnings. The test applies to taxable income in the year prior to purchase.

(ii) The special tax rebate for first home buyers introduced in March 1982 would be retained for lower income earners currently receiving assistance and those who enter the Scheme before 30 September 1983. No new entrants will be admitted to the Scheme after 30 September 1983. Those people who are currently receiving benefits and satisfy an income test with income limits set at the same level as the new FHOAS, will continue to receive benefits.

This will ensure that the low to moderate income first home buyers, who entered home ownership at a time of high interest rates, will continue to receive assistance for the first five years of home ownership.
(iii) Consistent with the Government's policy of directing scarce resources to the needy, it would terminate from 30 June 1983 the general tax rebate introduced in August 1982.
These changes reflect the Government's desire to ensure that assistance measures are directed to those most in need.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 May 1983 (Hansard, page 114), Senator Robertson asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister will be aware that the Darwin office of the Australian Information Service was closed by the former Government in its so-called efficiency drive. The closing of the office was keenly felt by both the Service and the people of the Northern Territory. Will the Minister undertake to consider the re-opening of the office, possibly by the reallocation of resources from one of the other capital city offices of the Service, and so provide the Northern Territory with a most needed facility.
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The re-establishment of an Australian Information Service (AIS) office in the Northern Territory is being considered as part of a general review of the location of AIS resources in Australia. However, any decision to re-open an AIS office in the Northern Territory will have to be related to the funds available to AIS in 1983-84.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 May 1983 (Hansard, page 331), Senator Coates asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology a question, without notice, concerning debris on Heard Island.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Science and Technology has porvided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

Permanent occupation of Heard Island ceased in 1955 to enable logistic resources to be directed towards establishing Mawson station on the Antarctic mainland. At the time every precaution was taken to ensure that the huts were adequately secure.
The scattered debris and the condition of the huts is mainly attributable to the severe climatic conditions which prevail on the island. Elephant seals also cause damage to the buildings.
The debris, although aesthetically unattractive, is not considered to be environmentally harmful.

The Antarctic Division is aware of the condition of the huts on Heard Island but is restricted in the effort that can be applied in tidying up the station area. The Division's heavy committment to the rebuilding program means that only short visits can be made to the island. However, it is intended that activity on Heard Island will be resumed when resources permit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 May 1983 (Hansard, page 338), Senator Elstob asked Senator Walsh as the Minister representing the Minister for Trade the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Minister representing the Minister for Trade take steps to correct the current trade practice whereby some goods produced overseas are labelled 'Made in Australia'? Will the Minister also inquire into the common practice whereby packaged goods are labelled in small print with the country of origin, but the labelling of the packaging itself, which is made in Australia, is prominently displayed, thus deceiving members of the public into thinking that they are buying locally made products?

The Minister for Trade referred the question to me as the Minister responsible for the legislation relating to the origin marking of imported goods. The answer to the honourable senator's question is:

A wide range of imported goods is required to be legibly marked with their country of origin in accordance with the Commerce (Imports) Regulations, prescribed under the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act 1905.

In addition, the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, prescribed under the Customs Act 1901, require that imported goods to which are applied wordings in a language other than that used by the people of the country of origin must have a qualifying statement in English indicating the country in which the goods were made or produced.
Imported cargo is selectively examined to ensure compliance with these requirements. Where infringements are detected the goods are not released from Customs control until they are correctly marked.

It has previously been brought to my attention that consumers are not always able to establish from the labels of locally packaged goods whether the contents are solely of Australian origin. There are certain State controls regulating the marking of locally packaged goods such as food-stuffs. In my view it is a matter for States to consider what action they might wish to take to combat any misleading or inadequate labelling that might be attached to goods after they have been released from Customs control.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 May 1983 (Hansard, page 333), Senator Macklin asked me as Minister representing the Special Minister of State the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: The Special Minister of State has in recent days declared the Government's intention of legislating for public funding of elections. Obviously one of the main concerns of the public will be the cost of such a scheme. Can the Minister inform the Senate, firstly, of the approximate cost to the public of elections under the present arrangements, particularly the current unlimited claims that can be made via the taxation system and, secondly, the prospective cost of the Government's contemplated scheme and whether it will cost more than the current scheme.
The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The cost to the Australian Electoral Office for the conduct of the election held on 5 March 1983 was $17.9m (excluding the salaries of permanent Australian Electoral Office Staff).

The details, including the cost, of a public funding scheme for federal election campaigns are not yet finalised. Amongst other considerations, the Government would wish to take into account the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform.

On the matter of the cost to the revenue arising from the tax deductibility of election expenses, this falls within the portfolio responsibility of the Minister for Finance, and I have therefore referred that aspect of the question to him.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 May 1983 (Hansard, page 520), Senator Lajovic asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, a question without notice concerning the lengthy strike at Drayton mine in New South Wales.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Following months of negotiations between coal owners, the Australian Coal and Shale Employees Federation (Miners' Federation) and the New South Wales Government, I noted with pleasure that the hiring of employees for the operation of the Drayton coal mine commenced on 30 May 1983.
The negotiations also led to agreement with the R. W. Miller coal company on the re-opening of the Preston extended mine at Gunnedah with the employment of 53 men.

Further, the New South Wales Government announced there will be continuing consultation between all of the parties in the coal mining industry involved in the negotiations with a view to minimising industrial disputation in the near future.
The Federal Government also convened a National Coal Conference which was held on 30 March 1983 to review the situation in the Australian black coal industry.

As a result of the 30 March meeting the Australian Coal Consultative Council was formed and held its first meeting on 29 April 1983. The Federal Government indicated at this meeting of its intentions to review taxes and related charges as they applied to the industry and to undertake missions to assess certain overseas market prospects.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 May 1983 (Hansard, page 515), Senator Coleman asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Trade to an article in the Melbourne Age on 21 April, headed 'Australian sugar technology costs Filipinos their jobs'. this article points out that the new equipment supplied to the Philippines sugar industry has cost sugar workers 50,000 jobs over the last three years. The Article quoted a study as having shown a reduction of between 50 per cent and 90 per cent in labour in the sugar farms. Changes of this magnitude obviously cause immense social problems. As this is just one example among many of the effects of foreign commercial activity on a local community and as private enterprise does not have a good record of exercising responsibility in such matters, can the Minister tell me what studies concerning the activities of Australian firms and their effects on underdeveloped communities?
The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The international sugar industry is a highly competitive one, and Australia's strong position in world markets is largely due to our efficient production techniques, which are characterised by a high level of mechanisation.

I am concerned that the Philippines sugar industry, in contrast, is generally less efficient. It is striving to improve its level of efficiency to maintain its viability as an important export earner for the Philippines and a continuing source of domestic employment.

Australia is not the only source of sugar technology. In fact, our manufacturing industry, which is geared to the Australian sugar industry, finds itself facing keen competition in exporting to world markets and is itself facing difficulties in the light of currently depressed sugar markets in maintaining employment in Australia, particularly in Queensland.

The Australian sugar machinery industry supplies equipment to many parts of the world. In supplying equipment to the Philippines, it is simply responding to a commercial demand which would be satisfied from elsewhere if Australia was not in the market.
The social impact of new technology, while significant, is a question for the Government of the importing country concerned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 May 1983 (Hansard, page 781), Senator Tate asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned allegations by the Tasmanian onion industry that New Zealand onions were being dumped on the Australian market.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information:

Under the Australia New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement the normal anti-dumping procedures are available to industries suffering or threatened with injury as a result of dumped imports.

An Anti-Dumping Liaison Monitoring Committee was established in the context of the Trade Agreement to monitor imports of certain sensitive horticultural products from New Zealand to facilitate early anti-dumping action when appropriate. The Committee examined the current concerns of sectors of the Australian onion industry over imports from New Zealand and concluded that there is a possibility of a threat of dumping. Officials also alerted the New Zealand authorities to Australia's concerns in regard to the low cost imports. The Committee advised the original complainant that to pursue a formal anti-dumping case it would be necessary to lodge a complaint with the Dumping Branch in the Department of Industry and Commerce and that it had passed the information collected in relation to its examination of the situation to the dumping authorities for their use in the aim of expediting action in the event of lodgement.

The Government is most concerned to ensure that Australian industries, including primary industries, are not subject to injury from predatory practices and dumped or subsidised imports and indeed an urgent review of Australia's Anti -Dumping and Countervailing Legislation and procedures is currently underway. However, the conduct of fair trade is fundamental to our future development and well being and it is essential that the interests of all parties involved be properly protected by adherence to the procedures laid down in compliance with our international obligations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 May 1983 (Hansard, page 756), Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, a question without notice concerning the number of people covered by private health insurance funds.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:
The latest complete information on the number of persons covered for basic medical and basic hospital benefits throughout Australia is:

If the position that existed under the original Medibank scheme can be used as a guide, it could be expected that the majority of people now insured for hospital benefits would maintain that insurance for the purposes of treatment as a private patient under the Medicare Program.
Medicare will be introduced on 1 February 1984 and by the time the rebate would have become payable most Australians will have had the benefit of reduced health costs for several months.

For the 1 per cent health levy on taxable incomes, all Australians will be automatically entitled to medical benefits representing at least 85 per cent of doctors' Schedule fees (where doctors agree to bulk-bill, there will be no charge to patients), medical services without charge at community health centres , and access to inpatient and outpatient treatment at public hospitals by hospital employed doctors without charge. There will be a ceiling for high income earners and minimum income levels below which the levy will not be payable.

There will be no need for anyone to take out private health insurance if they are prepared to accept the benefits and treatment that will be available under Medicare. For those that wish to have further cover, private health insurance funds will be able to offer benefits for treatment as private patients (i.e. doctor of choice) in public hospitals, accommodation in private hospitals and for ancillary services (e.g. physiotherapy and dental services).

Given the proposed reduction in public hospital charges that will apply under the Medicare arrangements, the cost of private health insurance for those electing to be treated as private patients should be considerably less than applies under the present system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 May 1983 (Hansard, page 979), Senator Hearn asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. Her question concerned the level of potato imports in 1980-81.

ANSWER.PARA: Further to the honourable senator's question I have obtained the following information:

Imports of potato products into Australia amounted to approximately 2,800 tonnes in 1981-82, a relatively high level in comparison to the 320 tonnes imported in 1980-81 and the 177 tonnes imported in the first nine months of 1982 -83. However, imports over this period have accounted for only a very small share of Australian consumption which is met predominantly by local production of some 900,000 tonnes (fresh weight) per annum.

The imports in 1981-82 comprised mainly frozen potatoes from Canada and were imported by a major Australian processor to overcome what he perceived as a short term difficulty in securing local supplies of processing potatoes of the required quality. The Australian potato growing industry was advised of the background relating to these imports through the National Potato Panel (an industry/government consultative and advisory body to the Minister for Primary Industry) by the processor's representative on the Panel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 June 1983 (Hansard, page 1279), Senator Boswell asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the financial difficulties facing the sugar industry in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Government is deeply concerned with the problems of the sugar industry which are largely attributable to low world prices and adverse seasonal conditions.

Since coming to office I have had a number of meetings with sugar industry leaders in an endeavour to more clearly identify assistance needs. In addition the Government has had for consideration a specific request by the Queensland Government for assistance for canegrowers as well as the recommendation contained in the Industries Assistance Commission interim report into the short term assistance needs of the sugar industry.

Following this consideration the Commonwealth announced on 7 June that it would provide $11m to New South Wales and Queensland to extend the carry-on provisions of Part B of the Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS) to canegrowers. Under this arrangement, $20m will be available for concessional loans to eligible canegrowers in Queensland and $2m to eligible canegrowers in New South Wales on the basis of dollar for dollar funding between the Commonwealth and the participating States.

In reaching its decision the Government gave full consideration to the sugar industry's proposal for general loan assistance by way of an injection of funds through the No. 1 Pool mechanism. However, given the need for financial stringency by the Government in the light of the current budget deficit situation, it has become a matter of ordering priorities strictly on a needs basis. Extensions to the sugar industry of the Part B carry-on provisions of the RAS will meet this requirement and will enable carry-on assistance to be provided to some 600-700 canegrowers in need. It also directly meets the Queensland Government's request for such assistance. An additional $5.5m will be provided to Queensland and $8.6m to New South Wales to assist rural industries including the cane growing industry, under the general industry rural provisions of the Rural Adjustment Scheme.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Government received any information that Albertino Neto has been in custody since February 1978; if so, when did the Government first obtain such information.
(2) What action has the Government taken to protest at the continued detention of the abovenamed.
(3) Has the Government taken any action; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government is aware from the Amnesty International report for 1982 that Mr Albertino Neto is serving a sentence of 21 years' imprisonment, having been convicted in March 1979 of conspiracy against the Government of Sao Tome and Principe. The Government has no previous information on this case.

(2) Enquiries have been made of the Embassy of Sao Tome and Principe in Lisbon concerning Mr Neto's imprisonment. The information provided indicated that Mr Neto was implicated in a coup attempt shortly after Sao Tome and Principe achieved independence in 1975 and that he and another alleged conspirator Mr Alcindo de Lima were tried and convicted under the due process of local law. It was stated that both were still imprisoned but were in good health. The Embassy undertook to convey Australia's interest in the case to the Government of Sao Tome and Principe.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 22 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Attorney-General seen the annual report of the Director of Consumer Affairs in Victoria, Mr John Miller, calling for a 'crack down on companies with a paid up capital of only $2'.
(2) Did Mr Miller state that the present system, which allows people to 'enjoy the luxury of limited liability behind a $2.00 corporate veil is open to abuse'.

(3) Did Mr Miller also state that linking a $2.00 company with a discretionary trust is 'a further complication . . . such that the consumer, in effect, has no idea with whom one is dealing, nor is it feasible to so discover easily'.
(4) Have the above problems been brought to the Federal Government's attention.
(5) What action will the Federal Government take to rectify these problems.
(6) Does legislation in the United Kingdom provide for a compulsory minimum paid up capital for companies which trade with the public, and what is the amount.
(7) Do any similar provisions exist in other countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (4) and (5) The Government is aware of the matters referred to in the honourable senator's question and is concerned about the abuse of the privilege of limited liability. The linking of a proprietary company having minimal paid up capital with a discretionary trust gives considerable scope for frustrating creditors. The suggestion that companies trading with the public be subject to minimum paid up capital requirements as a means of overcoming these abuses is one that needs to be considered along with other suggestions for improving protection for creditors and enployees of companies. Whether or not provision for minimum paid up capital requirements is the most appropriate course may depend on satisfactory resolution of issues such as the effect on existing small businesses and, in particular, the employment consequences for any existing companies that may not be able to meet any new capital requirements. I will be recommending to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities at the next meeting that these issues should be considered by the proposed Companies and Securities Law Review Committee in the context of a general examination of the legitimate use of the corporate form. The next Ministerial Council meeting will also be considering proposals for amendment of legislation concerning the operation of trading trusts.

(6) and (7) Yes. The Company Law Act 1980 of the United Kingdom imposes a requirement that public companies have a minimum paid up capital of #50,000 sterling. There is no minimum paid up capital requirement for private companies. It is understood that other members of the European Economic Community have progressively introduced legislation in accordance with the Second Directive on Company Law Harmonization to require companies to have a subscribed minimum capital of not less than 25,000 'units of account', the monetary value of which is defined by the European Economic Commission from time to time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs been drawn to a report in the National Times dated June 6-12 1982 that a Mr Gehring assisted a Mr Hand's departure from Australia in June 1980 by getting him a false passport.
(2) Will the Minister take action to investigate this supply of a false passport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The matter was investigated by a joint task force comprising officers of the Australian Federal Police and the New South Wales Police Force, and the papers have been referred to the Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Activities of the Nugan Hand Group.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 22 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Adelaide Telegraph Office been closed between the hours of 9 p.m. to 9 a.m. since 7 February 1983.
(2) Has this closure also applied on weekends.
(3) What arrangements, if any, were made for telegrams to be delivered in South Australia during the period that the Adelaide Telegraph Office has been closed.
(4) What arrangements, if any, were made for members of the public wishing to use the public telex facility located in the Adelaide Telegraph Office.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) No. A full 24-hour lodgement and delivery service for both telegrams and public telex is currently available at the Adelaide Chief Telegraph Office.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Australian Bureau of Statistics, under its methods of settlement section in the explanatory notes which accompany statistics on industrial disputes, list the following-'Intervention, assistance or advice of Federal Government officials or inspectors'; if so-

(a) does the Government possess statistics which give an answer to part 5 of Question No. 1799, using the criterion in the methods of settlement notes in the ABS Industrial Disputes publications; if not, does the Government only collect statistics for using whatever means of Federal intervention when such intervention is successful;

(b) is any information about Federal intervention, using whatever means fits with the ABS notes but is not successful, not kept on record anywhere within the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations or the ABS; and

(c) what is the Government's role in the area of settlements of industrial disputes if it does not keep accurate records of what participation it has had in the past. (See Hansard, answer to Question on Notice No. 1799, 18 August 1982 page 175.)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) No. The official industrial dispute statistics collected by the Australian Bureau of Statistics concerning intervention, assistance or advice of Federal Government officials or inspectors cover only those instances where parties to disputes involving stoppage of work of ten man-days or more report such intervention, assistance or advice as the method directly responsible for ending the stoppage.

(b) The Australian Bureau of Statistics does not collect information concerning instances in which intervention, assistance or advice of Federal Government officials or inspectors was considered by the parties to each relevant stoppage to have been unsuccessful, or not directly responsible for ending the stoppage.

(c) The Government's role in the area of settlements of industrial disputes is undertaken in a wide variety of ways both of a formal and informal character. A succinct expression of this Government's approach is to be found in the statement of accord by the Australian Labour Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions regarding economic policy.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment and Industrial Relations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many motor vehicle accidents involved officers of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations whilst on duty, in the financial year 1981- 82.

(2) How many of these accidents were in: (a) Commonwealth cars used by the Department; (b) officers' private vehicles; (c) rental vehicles; (d) chauffeur- driven vehicles or taxis; and (e) other forms of vehicle transport.
(3) How many officers were injured and what was the breakdown for each mode of transport listed in (2).
(4) Were any of the accidents fatal; if so, how many and in what mode of transport listed in (2).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) All these accidents were in group (a).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 3 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the attention of the Minister for Primary Industry been drawn to an article published in an American beekeeping magazine in December 1982 stating that scientists at an Australian Government analytical laboratory have discovered previously undetected levels of glucose syrup in Australian pure honey designed for export markets.

(2) Is the further statement in this article that 'some honey in Australia is sold with up to 30 per cent glucose content, but this is clearly marked on the jar' correct or does honey and glucose sold and labelled as such have to be 50 per cent honey and 50 per cent glucose.
(3) Would the analysis referred to have detected glucose being added to honey in excess of the natural glucose which always shows in honey and is of acceptable levels.

(4) Was one sample taken of honey for export which actually came from the Honey Corporation of Australia Limited, wrongly accredited to having been found in the Western Australian Honey Pool, which has never had glucose in their packing plant.

(5) Has it been verified that some exporters have been adulterating honey by adding glucose yet labelling the product as honey; if so, what action has been taken against them and what measures are necessary to ensure that this is not still occurring.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) It is understood that product sold as honey and glucose mixtures in Australia can contain varying percentages of up to 50 per cent of added glucose. Labelling requirements for such products marketed domestically are the responsibility of State health departments, but they are generally guided in this regard by the recommendations of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH and MRC). The NH and MRC model food standards include a recommendation that ingredients in the product be listed on the product label in the descending order of their proportion by weight, but do not require a percentage declaration;

(3) The method used to test honey for adulteration detects the presence of higher saccharides which are not commonly found in honey. It cannot be used to conclusively prove adulteration because certain types of honeys exhibit a gradual build up of higher saccharides when stored for extended periods of time. These higher saccharides cannot be distinguished from those of glucose syrup by the HPLC test. The terms glucose, which in this content refers to natural glucose of honey, and glucose honey, which refers to the product obtained by the hydrolysis of starch, are often confused. Glucose syrup contains glucose, maltose and higher polysaccharides. Glucose and maltose are natural constituents of honey, however the higher polysaccharides are not commonly found. While the text cannot conclusively provide adulteration by glucose syrup, it does detect higher saccharides which point to adulteration, thereby enabling further investigations to be undertaken.

(4) Information on the results of initial analysis and companies implicated is not publicly disseminated, given the need for follow up action. I am not in a position to comment on whether or not the Western Australian Honey Pool has ever had glucose syrup on its premises.

(5) Follow-up investigation into the causes of the adulteration indicated by analysis have generally been inconclusive. In all cases, once analytical results were to hand the exporters in question were advised accordingly. Further shipments from them were subject to individual sampling and analysis, as opposed to routine random sampling procedures, and withheld from export until cleared by analysis. Normal inspection procedures in such cases are not reverted to until satisfactory results have been obtained for at least ten consecutive shipments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications , upon notice, on 4 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Telecom Australia remove a telephone from the Commonwealth Government Centre, 232 Adelaide Street, Brisbane, on 24 September 1981; if so, why.

(2) Did the Department of Administrative Services opppose the removal of the telephone on the grounds that it served elderly or incapacitated members of the public availing themselves of the hearing aid service.

(3) Did Telecom Australia suggest to the Department of Administrative Services that if it had wanted a telephone in that location it should install a red telephone; if so, has Telecom Australia suggested to other Government departments that a red telephone should be installed where a telephone is required to service that department's clients.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Detailed studies into usage levels over the preceding three years revealed that patronage of this particular facility had been consistently poor and far below the level normally required to justify retaining the public telephone in service.

The unit was located in the ground floor foyer where it was available for use by all visitors to the Commonwealth Offices including those persons using ther services of the National Acoustic Laboratories Hearing Centre located on the second floor. The public telephone had not been specially modified to accommodate users with hearing aids.

The Department of Administrative Services was advised in writing on 28 May 1981 of the imminent removal of this telephone as well as a similar facility installed in the foyer of the Taxation Building located at the corner of Adelaide and Wharf Streets, Brisbane.

(2) Yes. A reply was sent on 28 July 1981 explaining the reasons for the withdrawal of this telephone. In the letter Telecom supplied details of other public telephones located nearby and made specific reference to those units which had been modified to enable use by disabled persons as well as people with hearing difficulties. There are a number of such services in close proximity to the Commonwealth Government Centre at 232 Adelaide Street.

(3) The suggestion was put to the Department of Administrative Services that, in full knowledge of the circumstances surrounding the withdrawal of the public telephone, if it still considered a telephone service should be available, then the Department should consider leasing a Redphone.

The action taken in this instance is consistent with Telecom's policy of allocating public telephone equipment to those areas where significant public usage of the facilities will occur. In those situations where the installation or retention of public telephones cannot be justified, leased coin telephones are often recommended as a viable and realistic alternative.

(4) What action is the Government taking to remedy the established spur line policy to finance remote-area projects in a more equitable manner.
(5) Is Telecom Australia unable to finance these projects at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

(Replacing existing troposcatter system and increasing capacity (1,920 circuits )

(3) The Davidson Committee recommended that the Australian Telecommunications Commission should be abolished and replaced by an incorporated company-Telecom Australia Limited-owned 100 per cent by the Commonwealth Government. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 17 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the proposed Arbitration Inspectorate, which is to replace the Industrial Relations Bureau, be independent and autonomous as foreshadowed in the prices and incomes accord and in the Australian Labor Party's platform.

(2) Have officers of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association expressed their concern to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations that the Inspectorate may be entirely absorbed into the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations.
(3) Will the Government be making a statement in the near future to outline its intentions with respect to the proposed Arbitration Inspectorate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Act 1983 amends the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 by abolishing the Industrial Relations Bureau and establishing an Arbitration Inspectorate within the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. The provisions of the Act relating to the Arbitration Inspectorate give effect to the Australian Labor Party 1982 Platform, Constitution and Rules which provide inter alia, for 'the restoration of the Arbitration Inspectorate function within a Department of Employment and Industrial Relations on an adequately resourced basis . . . '. The Statement of Accord reflects the ALP Platform in providing that an independent Arbitration Inspectorate should be re-established.

The provisions of the Act meet the requirements of the International Labour Organisation Convention No. 81 on Labour Inspection for the independence of the Inspectorate staff. They will be public officials whose status and conditions of service are such that they are ensured of stability of employment and are independent of changes of Government and of improper external influences. In this respect, the Act provides for inspectors to be appointed or employed under the Public Service Act 1922 for the purposes of carrying out their functions under the Act. Inspectors have now been formally appointed by my delegate for the purposes of the Act. They will exercise their powers and perform their duties under the Act in accordance with guidelines which I have determined and which were promulgated in the Special Gazette No. S 139 of 4 July 1983. The duties of inspectors and their powers and functions as promulgated are based upon those duties and functions for the Inspectorate published by the coalition Government when that Inspectorate operated within the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations prior to the establishment of the Industrial Relations Bureau. The provisions of the Act and the duties of inspectors have been fully endorsed by the ACTU and employers through the National Labour Consultative Council.

(2) Officers of the ACOA did express their concern about the independence of the Inspectorate but their attention has been drawn to the provisions of the Act and the Australian Labor Party 1982 Platform Constitution and Rules.

(3) My second reading speech in relation to the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1983 covered the Government's intentions with respect to the Arbitration Inspectorate (House of Representatives, (Hansard,) 11 May 1983, pp. 397-400).

These submissions, together with evidence of other community attitudes, will be taken into account by the Tribunal in its review of the standard.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications , upon notice, on 24 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are television and radio election commercials on behalf of political parties and candidates permitted in Canada and the United Kingdon during election campaigns; if not, what system operates to enable political parties and candidates to reach the electorates through the electronic media.

(2) Is broadcast time on commercial radio and television stations in Canada and the United Kingdom allocated to political parties and candidates on a strict formula; if so, what are the formulas and do they provide equal time for the major parties.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Tirbunal:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In Canada, advertisements for political parties and candidates are permitted on radio and television during election campaigns.

In the United Kingdom, advertisements on behalf of a political body are not permitted on radio or television. During a general election, in that country, however, broadcasting time is made available to the political parties for election broadcasts.
(2) In regard to the formula for allocation of time in these countries the following practices apply:

In Canada political programs, advertisements or announcements are broadcast by stations in accordance with the directions of the Canadian Radio Television and Telecommunications Commission. These directions refer to the proportion of time devoted to these items and to the assignment of this time to political parties and candidates.

In the United Kingdom a committee, comprising representatives of political parties and the two broadcasting authorities (the British Broadcasting Corporation and the Independent Broadcasting Authority), agree annually on the detailed arrangements for party political broadcasts, the number of broadcasts, allocated to each party being determined by a formula based on the number of votes cast for the party at the previous general election. Other parties not included in these arrangements, may qualify for a broadcast if they have 50 or more candidates.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 May 1983 (Hansard, page 505), Senator Mason asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice, a question in relation to improper behaviour at the Royal Military College, Duntroon, and sought an undertaking from the Government that it keep a close eye on the matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

As the honourable senator is aware, I made a statement on this matter in the House of Representatives on 11 May. In that statement, I noted that while a number of steps had been taken to improve behaviour, I had also asked for a further report on what future action needed to be taken.

I have now received this report, and I am satisfied that the Chief of the General Staff and the Commandant of the Royal Military College agree that the kind of improper behaviour that has occurred is quite unacceptable and must be stopped. To this end, new procedures have been and are being introduced to ensure that effect is given to four fundamental principles:
(a) Harassment is not a necessary adjunct to Army training
(b) Harassment and unacceptable behaviour cannot survive in a properly regulated military environment
(c) Physical and mental violence have no place in the training of tough professional Army officers
(d) It is not sufficient to issue orders on these or any other matters. It is always up to the officer issuing an order to see it is continually obeyed, both in spirit and the letter.
I have asked the Chief of the General Staff to report to me periodically on the effectiveness of the new arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On May 4 1983 (Hansard, page 154) Senator Zakharov asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning electronic monitoring devices for elderly and handicapped people. I undertook to seek further details from the Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following additional information:

The Department of Health is currently examining the feasibility of the use of electronic monitoring devices for elderly and handicapped people living alone, and whether such devices might enable a partial reduction of the need for continuous care of aged or handicapped relatives at home. This has particular relevance to the Domiciliary Nursing Care Benefit. This does of course, depend on the level of care required for, and the particular needs of, particular patients. These devices are expensive both to install and operate continuously; their efficacy in reducing the need for nursing home admission has not yet been demonstrated. It is likely that the need to summon help in an emergency is only one of a large number of factors which lead to people being admitted to residential care.

In the development of a comprehensive policy of care for the frail aged, including expanded domiciliary care, the Government will be considering a range of community based alternatives to institutional care, from the perspective of both patient needs and cost-effectiveness. Electronic monitoring devices and other applications of modern technology will be examined in this context.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Council of Egg Marketing Authorities in Australia

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 June 1983 (Hansard, page 1165) Senator Jack Evans asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the Council of Egg Marketing Authorities of Australia allegedly preparing to support, co-ordinate or fund a public campaign against a group called Animal Liberation.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Minister for Primary Industry is aware that the Council of Egg Marketing Authorities of Australia has published a booklet containing statements designed to counter comments on the egg industry by some animal welfare groups.
CEMAA is a non-statutory body composed entirely of representatives of all State egg marketing authorities, and its operations are funded by the State Egg Boards .

CEMAA makes recommendations to the Minister for Primary Industry on a wide range of egg industry matters, including on the operation of the Poultry Industry Trust Fund, which is a co-operative arrangement between the Commonwealth and the States. The source of PITF funds is a hen levy paid by egg producers.

It is considered that PITF moneys could not be used legally for a CEMAA publicity campaign designed to counter comments by animal welfare groups. No moneys have been paid to CEMAA by the Commonwealth from the PITF, or any other source, for this purpose.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 May 1983 (Hansard, page 755) Senator Coates asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning a possible ban on the advertising of tobacco products in areas under direct Commonwealth control, such as at airports and in the Australian Capital Territory

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

I share the honourable senator's concern for the harmful effects of tobacco consumption on health, as do my fellow Health Ministers. At the April 1983 Australian Health Ministers' Conference, Ministers agreed to a series of anti- smoking measures aimed at reducing tobacco consumption, based on a paper ' Recommendations for a National Policy on Smoking' prepared by the Tobacco Products Subcommittee of the Standing Committee of the Health Ministers' Conference. The matter of tobacco advertising has been closely examined by that sub-committee since it was established in March 1981.

Following the April conference, I wrote to the Minister for Aviation seeking to have tobacco advertising banned at airports. He has advised that a condition of all new airport concessions will be that there be no new sub-contracts for advertisements for tobacco products. Therefore, this form of advertising at airports will be phased out as existing sub-contracts expire (1986).

In addition, my Department has sought information from other relevant departments concerning restrictions on tobacco advertising in areas under Commonwealth control, including within the Australian Capital Territory.

I can inform the honourable senator that the Capital Territory Health Commission, in co-operation with its advisory body, the Health Services Council, is currently seeking the views of the Australian Capital Territory community on whether there is a need for more anti-smoking legislation. Information received is to be considered in relation to the development of the Australian Capital Territory Tobacco Ordinance. Control of the advertising of tobacco products is one of the main issues to be considered.
